What Is Gestalt?

Gestalt is a character building variant that is a little like multiclassing, except that instead of taking two classes at alternate levels you take both classes simultaneously.

  1. You select the greater value or progression for your HD, BAB, base saves, and skill points.
  2. You gain the class features from both classes, including class skill list.
  3. Class features that two classes share accrue at the rate of the faster class. For example, a slayer 3 gets Sneak Attack +d6, and a Rogue 3 gets Sneak Attack +2d6. A gestalt slayer//rogue gets Sneak Attack +2d6 like the rogue, not +3d6 like a multiclass Slayer 3 / Rogue 3.

This results in characters that are more powerful and versatile than usual. However, they do not get any more actions, non-bonus feats, or gear, which means it's easy to spread a gestalt character too thin.

Gestalts are often used to compensate for small parties by making sure that the party still has access to a diverse range of abilities. For example, one PC could be both a fighter and a cleric while the other is both a rogue and a wizard. Alternatively, gestalting can be enjoyed in a party of normal size as a high-power gaming experience in which players employ abilities from multiple classes for spectacular synergy. It can also be used to explore unusual concepts through combining classes; for example, a band of thieves consisting of a fighter//rogue, cleric//rogue, and wizard//rogue.

More detailed information about the gestalting concept can be found on the 3.X SRD.

What is this Guide For?

Pointing out synergies, weaknesses, and build ideas for various gestalt class combinations. While I give combinations ratings describing their level of synergy in terms of power and versatility, it’s important to note that gestalting isn’t always about making the most powerful character - you can have a lot of fun with mediocre gestalts that express interesting concepts. However, if that’s your goal then you might want to make sure that the group is on the same page. Don’t bring a Brawler//Magus to an Alchemist//Wizard game, and vice-versa.

Optimization Principles

Like creating any other character, gestalting is about balancing the need to do well in your primary role with a level of versatility. Actions, feats, stats, and gold are limited resources that have to be split between a character's possible roles (archer, swordsman, healer, scout, and so forth) and the more things a character tries to do, generally speaking, the less good they will be at any one thing. On the other hand, if your primary strategy is not effective in a given fight you want other options.

Most classes are designed with particular synergies, focuses, and secondary options in mind; for example clerics are designed to be better in melee than wizards, and their spell list grants them more spells that increase their weapon damage. Gestalt combinations don't have these preselected synergies – you have to find them yourself. And while it's easy to see why a Barbarian//Wizard might not be a great idea, other problems or synergies aren't always obvious. The questions you should be asking are:

1) How well does each class support the character's primary role in combat? Ideally both classes should contribute in some way to whatever you want the character’s main focus to be.

2) What else can I do? Any character will eventually run into a situation where their usual strategy isn't so useful, and it's good to have a backup. You'll also want to be able to contribute out of combat. This is especially important in a small party where each gestalt is expected to cover multiple roles.

3) How are my defenses? Either you're in a small party and taking more hits per PC or you're fighting higher CR encounters, so it's important to be able to take (or avoid) more damage and make your saves. Remember that arcane spell failure can limit a gestalt's armour choices.

4) What actions am I using? You'll get more use out of your actions if you have a good mix of action types – standard, move, and swift – available, rather than having a lot of competing actions of the same type. Abilities which are free actions or no action are especially useful.

5) Can I get the stats and feats I need? Picking a primary role helps, but you still want to make sure gestalting doesn't add too many secondary stats, and that you're not trying to do something complicated like shield bashing without bonus feats. Conversely, if you do have bonus feats it's easier to fill out your secondary role or strategies.

Example: Fighter//Bard:

(1) Primary role is weapons combat, whether ranged or melee. The fighter provides full BAB and HD, lots of feats, and weapon and armour training, and the bard can self-buff with performance or spells. Archetypes such as the arcane duelist offer extra combat benefits like weapon enhancement and the ability to cast bard spells in heavier armour. (2) Secondary roles include support, some healing, and a variety of skills, thanks to the bard. (3) Lots of HP and all good saves. Arcane spell failure limits your AC a bit, but you can still use shields and at minimum light armour (or mithral breastplate). (4) Attacks and spells compete for your standard action, but many of your spells are swift actions and bardic performance can eventually be used as any action type, which is very handy. Most of the fighter's class features passively augment either attacks or defenses, and a few bard benefits (such as versatile performance) are passive. (5) Stats are a little spread out, but not more than a single-class bard. Plenty of feats. Verdict: Very good gestalt, potent but still versatile.

Example: Fighter//Wizard:

(2) The Fighter//Wizard gets a lot of abilities that support combat, and a versatile casting list, so it has a lot of options. (1) However relatively few abilities such as Weapon Focus (Ray) or the diviner's initiative bonus benefit the other side of the combination. (3) You get plenty of HP and two good saves, but can't cast spells in armour at all without spending feats and swift actions on Arcane Armour Training, which means your defenses are not a whole lot better than a standard wizard – certainly not great for melee. (4) The Fighter//Wizard also suffers from competition between spells and attacks since it has fewer swift action spells. Eventually Quicken becomes a factor, but then you're quickly eating up high level spell slots. (5) It's hard to get an Int high enough for good spell DCs and also have physical stats high enough for weapons. Bonus feats help you from getting too spread out between fighting and casting, but it's not enough. Verdict: Under-specialized. You either try to split your focus (and end up not great at either) or you gain little benefit from one class's features most of the time.

Example: Sorcerer//Wizard

(1) The sorcerer-wizard gets tons of spell slots and both prepared and spontaneous casting. The wizard's bonus feats, some school abilities, and the sorcerer's bloodline arcana can be used with casting abilities from the other class. (2) However, it doesn't do much aside from cast from the sorcerer/wizard list – something either class could do before gestalting. While it's more flexible and effective in how it uses those spells, it has few or no abilities to support weapon combat, no increase in the range of spells it gets access to, and no improvement in mundane skills or in (3) defenses compared to either class individually. And since almost all your spells and special abilities use standard actions (4), usually you will spend your turn casting as one or the other class. At higher levels you can afford to burn through a few extra slots with Quicken, but it's still costly. (5) Finally, splitting focus between two casting stats means that your spell DCs from one or both classes will be lower than usual. You can fix this with the Sage bloodline, but then your bloodline arcana doesn't add anything extra to either class's spells. Verdict: Over-specialized in arcane casting.

The Fighter//Wizard and Sorcerer//Wizard are representative of problems with similar combinations.

Full BAB // full arcane caster seems like a great idea, because you get the best of both worlds. However you often actually end up with a split focus, trying to spend feats, stats, and gold on being competent at two deeply dissimilar things while not having the actions or synergistic class features to actually do both. Some combinations such as the Ranger//Sorcerer in addition can stretch your stat requirements by requiring a second above-average mental stat on top of physical requirements. These constraints aren’t impossible to work around, and some specific full-BAB mages can be more effective. Using a combat class that's comfortable in light or no armour helps. You can also make your actions stretch farther by delivering multi-touch spells like Chill Touch using unarmed strikes or natural attacks, or by using a reach/AoO build that lets you sneak in more attacks on turns when you cast. However taking advantage of these often takes very careful building, and these characters have a low optimization “floor” in that it’s easy to execute it very poorly. It’s usually safer to pair either the combat or caster class with a partial caster who can offer a little of the other feature, while still supporting your primary focus. The Magus is a particularly good choice because it actually does offer the ability to cast and fight in the same turn via spell combat.

Pairing two full arcane casters is popular among players who want ALL THE MAGIC but since full arcane casters invariably have d6 HD and poor CMD, Fort and Ref saves you end up REALLY FRAGILE. You also don't get as much as you'd think out of the second spell list thanks to action limitations. I highly recommend instead pairing with a partial or divine caster, which will improve your durability while typically also granting you more versatility in your spell list and special features.

Finally, note that while the Sorcerer and Wizard are considered very strong classes, they aren't as good in combination as the Fighter//Bard. In gestalt it's common for the generally weaker classes to be very good choices when combined with classes that complement their strengths and weaknesses well.

Multiclassing in Gestalt

It is possible to multiclass a gestalt character by taking different class combinations at different levels, but it adds a layer of complexity and I will cover it only briefly.

There are two mechanical complications involved in multiclassing gestalt. First, BAB and saving throws can become a little difficult to keep track of if you're not using the same progressions at each level. For example, a Wizard//Swashbuckler gets full BAB and good Ref and Will saves, while a Wizard//Magus gets average BAB and good Fort and Will saves, so how do you handle a Wizard// Swashbuckler/Magus? Some believe that it's only whether the stat is increased that counts, and that a Fighter 1 / Sorcerer 19 // Wizard 20 would get full BAB by staggering the levels at which they get an increase from Sorc or Wiz, but I believe that's counter to the intent. The second issue is that some prestige classes can become unbalanced if you can qualify too easily or too early. For example, taking Sorcerer 4 // Oracle 4 and then switching to Mystic Theurge // Fighter gives you two full casting progressions, only one point shy of full BAB, and barely-delayed fighter features; that’s OP even by gestalt standards.

One option for dealing with the first issue is counting BAB and saves fractionally, such that a character gets 1/2, 3/4, or 1 point of BAB each level, and gets 1/3 of a save bonus for every “poor” save and 1/2 of a save bonus for every “good” save, using the higher value between each class taken that level. Round all fractions down to get your actual modifier, with a one-time + 2 to every “good” save.  In this case you may need to follow the 3.X SRD’s suggestions on restricting prestige classes: no prestige class levels before level 5 even if gestalting allows you to qualify early, no gestalting two prestige classes at once, and no prestige classes that advance two classes at once (such as Mystic Theurge, Arcane Trickster, or Rage Prophet).

Alternatively, you can count each “side” of the gestalt as a separate character before gestalting, taking the best total at each level. This not only handles the BAB and saves progression but also balances prestige classes: each “side” can take a prestige class if and only if that “side” can qualify for that prestige class on its own. For example, a Fighter // Sorcerer 4/Oracle 4/Mystic Theurge is legal because a Sorc 4/Oracle 4 can qualify for Mystic Theurge levels. However a Sorcerer 4/Fighter 4 // Oracle 4/Mystic Theurge 4 would not be allowed because an Oracle 4 does not qualify for Mystic Theurge.

From an optimization point of view, the easiest way to make an effective multiclassed gestalt is to select one primary class that you will progress to level 20 on one “side” of the gestalt, and then use the other “side” to cherry-pick useful and complementary abilities from multiple classes. Examples:

  1. Wizard 20 // Swashbuckler (Inspired Blade) 1 / Magus 6 / Fighter 13. The Wizard gets its full casting progression while the Swashbuckler contributes a quick early-game advantage in durability and rapier competence, the Magus brings spellstrike and spell combat (usable with wizard spells at character level 7 thanks to the Broad Study arcana) and the fighter rounds out the build's combat ability, resulting in a character with full casting, almost full BAB, lots of combat feats, and the ability to cast and fight in the same round.
  2. Unchained Monk // Cleric / Empyreal Sorcerer / Mystic Theurge gets a mobile, unarmoured combat focus on the one side and a diverse set of casting abilities on the other side, including combat buffs, a lot of Bad Touch potential, and Wis stat synergy.
  3. Bard 6+ // Swashbuckler 1 / Urban Bloodrager 2+ / Paladin 3+ gives you full bardic music and casting plus full BAB, finesse, parry and riposte, Dex rage, fast movement, uncanny dodge, smite, Cha to saves, and immunity to fear and disease. From there you can invest more heavily in either paladin or bloodrager, or even switch to fighter for some bonus feats.

Summons and Pets in Gestalt

The power of these options depends largely on why you are gestalting.

If you are compensating for a small party, extra bodies are great! They reduce the chances you'll be overwhelmed by numbers and help your character to effectively full multiple roles at the same time instead of just filling multiple roles at different times.

If you are gestalting for a high-power experience, pets and summons have a harder time contributing meaningfully because they are balanced for a standard game; thus they are relatively weak compared to a gestalt party and the challenges such a party will face. There are four ways to handle this. From most investment to least:

  1. Devote lots of resources to making the pet powerful enough to contribute. This is difficult, but possible with some combinations such as Barbarian//Hunter or Bard//Summoner.
  2. Use the pet for support (usually a mount or flanking partner) and instead of giving it offensive feats and items concentrate on making it mobile and tough enough to fill a support role without dying.
  3. Keep the pet out of combat and use it for utility, such as scouting. This is usually only worthwhile when the pet is not very strong to begin with and doesn't come with a high opportunity cost - familiars and ranger's companions work well in this role.
  4. Don't take the pet! Even the most pet-based classes in the game do have options for playing without pets, so if you like the class as a whole but don't want the complications described above, consider trading the pet for something that will benefit you directly.

Class Combinations

I discuss both general gestalting guidelines for each class and each combination of two classes for gestalting. Each combination entry contains a summary of the basic abilities (BAB/HD, saves, skills, casting, and stats needed), and specific comments on synergy or how to build the gestalt.  Entries are listed in alphabetical order by the first appearing class in the combination, so for example Barbarian // Oracle is found under the “Barbarian” section.

Rating System:

Red: Very bad. Combination fails to synergize or works at cross-purposes, has significant weaknesses.

        Basics: Poor BAB/HD, one good save, 2 skill points, no casting, needs all stats

Orange: Fair. May have little synergy or significant weaknesses.

        Basics: Med BAB/HD, two good saves, 4 skill points, partial casting, needs 5 good stats

Green: Good. Some synergy and acceptable weaknesses, or very versatile.

        Basics: Good BAB/HD, all good saves, 6 skill points

        Full casting or two synergistic* part-casters

        3 key stats, or two key stats and two secondary

Blue: Great, combination of synergy and versatility, few weaknesses.

        Basics: d12, save or skill bonuses ('+'), 8 skill points, two full casters or synergistic full and part

        2 key stats, no more than one secondary

Purple: Best, either ridiculously potent in the chosen area or both strong and very versatile.

        Basics: 8 skill points with skill bonuses ('+'), two synergistic full casters, single key stat

*Synergistic casting generally means two of: varied lists, shared stat, both prepared and spontaneous.

With reference to stats, “physical” indicates a need for physical stats in variable arrangement depending on build, usually with Dex or Str key and the other two secondary.

Guide is a work in progress; pink text indicates comments to myself, while different fonts are comments from other sources not yet integrated into the guide. Not all classes are currently rated.

Alchemist

An unusual pseudo-part-caster, the Alchemist doesn't suffer typical restrictions of casters like arcane spell failure, but also doesn't offer access to caster abilities like crafting, and has different good saves. It does best when paired with a strong martial class that benefits from the alchemist's self-buffing abilities and ability to wear armour, or with an int-based caster for increased durability. Explosive missile discovery works nicely with martial builds focusing on ranged weapons.

Beastmorph (for pounce) and Vivisectionist (for sneak attack) are good archetype choices for combat focused gestalts, and can be combined. The Mindchemist archetype or the Cognatogen discovery are good for gestalting with casters. The Metamorph archetype is an interesting way to reduce MAD, since it removes your Int-dependent class features (bombs and extracts) leaving the mutagen and giving you a powerful shapeshifting ability. Gun Chemist provides a very nice explosive ordinance ability to pair with other firearm-focused features - and you get to keep Mutagen.

*Update - Archetypes: The Herbalist alchemist uses Wis for all class abilities, and the Mnemostiller uses Cha for some class abilities including bomb DCs. Full analysis of the effect of these archetypes is pending, but it is safe to assume that the Herbalist will combine well with Wis-based casters as well as Monks. The Mnemostiller is more complex and may not work as well with martial classes such as Paladin but may be superior to base alchemist for Cha-based full casters such as Sorcerer or Oracle.

Alchemist // Arcanist **** (Mindchemist)

Basics: Med BAB, d8, all saves, 4 skills+, full & part casting, Int Cha

Extremely versatile casting with casting stat synergy and as much durability as you can expect from a gestalt arcane caster. The way the alchemist is written, you can copy any spells on your spellbook into your formula book as well, paying copying costs only instead of copying plus research. You won't be able to take advantage of the Alchemist's light armour proficiency.

Alchemist // Barbarian ****/*

Basics: Full BAB, d12, Fort and Ref, 4 skills, 6 level casting, Str Con Int

Drugged Rager. Between Mutagen and Rage your physical stats can easily get absurdly high. Defenses are great, aside from the poor Will save: medium armour, natural armour from mutagen, DR, miss chance from extracts, and discoveries granting healing or fortification. Plus other support/utility extracts. You can use prepared infusions while raging – they don't require concentration. Strongly consider the Drunken Rager archetype, which lets you consume potions (and possibly prepared infusions) as a move action that does not provoke an AoO. Consider beastmorph and a non-beast totem. Metamorph can provide massive strength and durability without Int requirements. At level 1 you’re looking at +10 to strength between rage, mutagen, and alter self, and that increases to +18 with greater rage, greater mutagen, and monstrous physique III (huge) at level 12. Note that you’re fatigued for 1 round after transforming, which can prevent you from raging if you wait to transform until the start of a battle. Loss of the versatility from extracts is also a bummer, but you still get access to a variety of senses and modes of movement.

Alchemist // Bard

Basics: Med BAB, d8, all saves, 6 skills+, two 6 level casting, physical Int Cha

Lots of skills and support, but offensive options are tricky due to a combination of MAD and medium BAB progression. The mutagen (or cognatagen) helps, but you'll likely still be well behind more focused gestalts. Best options are probably an archer-grenadier, dervish dancer (with Dex mutagen), metamorph (less MAD, neat infiltrator), or natural weapons demoralizer with Feral Mutagen (grants +2 to Intimidate), Power Attack, and Cornugon Smash. Defense about as good as a standard alchemist, plus the option of a shield. Am I unfairly discounting a casting focus?

Alchemist // Bloodrager

Basics: Full BAB, d10, Fort and Ref, 4 skills, 6 & 4 level casting, Physical Int Cha

Similar to Alchemist//Barbarian, but you're more MAD, and the bloodrager's ability to self-buff is less exciting when you can also do that with extracts. However you can make a really nasty natural weapons build using Feral Mutagen and multi-touch spells like Frostbite or Chill Touch. Depending on how generous your stats are and whether you have a flanking buddy, you probably want Viviscectionist (great damage when flanking, still needs Int) or Metamorph (less utility but no need for Int and physical stats through the roof).

Alchemist // Brawler

Basics: Full BAB, d10, Fort and Ref, 4 skills, 6 level casting, physical & Int

Hard to go wrong combining alchemist buffs with full BAB and combat features. Still, no particularly good synergy. Save a feat for Iron Will.

Alchemist // Cavalier

Basics: Full BAB, d10, Fort and Ref, 4 skills, 6 level casting, physical & Int

An odd combination that has some non-obvious synergy. Rather than riding your mount, use it as a flanking partner with the Vivisectionist archetype, and use pounce from Beastmorph to get use out of your charge bonuses. Alternatively, you can take Daring Champion for a dex build – though this adds a Cha requirement and you'll also want a good Wis to make up for your poor save.

Alchemist // Cleric

Basics: Med BAB, d8, all saves, 4 skills, full and part casting, all stats

Very MAD, even ignoring Cha and giving up on channeling. You're also not getting much in the way of the basics, and no particular synergy.

Alchemist // Druid ** (Beast Viv//Nature Fang ***)

Basics: Med BAB, d8, all saves, 4 skills, full and 6-level “casting,” physical Int Wis

The alchemist and druid bring a lot of the same stuff to the table in terms of basic numbers and available buffs. Also, Natural Spell doesn't allow you to use extracts or bombs while wild shaped, so you'll need to either use extracts for pre-buffing, pass out infusions, and ignore bombs; or else de-emphasize wild shape. One neat archetype combination is Beastmorph Vivisectionist//Nature Fang. Beastmorph+Feral Mutagen gives you back many of the advantages of wild shape but in a humanoid form, Studied Target improves your accuracy and to-hit (and becomes a swift action a level before you get Pounce from Beastmorph), and slayer talents modify your full progression sneak attack. The natural weapons combat style is not very strong – consider archery for versatility. Metamorph//Nature Fang similarly shifts your shapeshifting to alchemist, but is easier to pull off with no requirement for an Int bonus or flanking partner. Druid (Urushiol)'s poison is thematic and effective.

Alchemist // Fighter

Basics: Full BAB, d10, Fort and Ref, 4 skills, 6 level casting, physical & Int

Alchemist buffs work very nicely with the fighter's combat competence - you can easily get a massive AC and very strong physical stats with this combo. Action economy is good with a lot of passive abilities and long-duration buffs. The main question is whether to keep bombs. Vivisectionist gives great damage for styles with lots of attacks such as TWF, but there’s something to be said for the versatility of being able to lob a ranged energy attack. Ranged fighters should keep bombs and take Explosive Missile discovery. Note that you can use Fighter feats (ex: Weapon Specialization) to improve your bombs. Weapon training doesn't apply to bombs, but the Opportunist fighter does give you +1 to attack and damage with bombs, Int to splash weapons (in case you traded it away with an alchemist archetype such as Vaultbreaker) and adds a few other bonuses including 2 extra skill ranks (to be used on Bluff, Sense Motive, Stealth, and Sleight of Hand). The cost is that your normal weapon training is delayed until level 9, and you swap half your bonus feats for other alchemical tricks and rogue talents. Gun Chemist // Trench Fighter is a great combination between explosive ordinance, gunsmithing, and trench warfare.

Alchemist // Gunslinger *** (Gun Chemist)****

Basics: Full BAB, d10, Fort and Ref, 4 skills, 6 level casting, Dex Wis Int

Alchemists have excellent buffs for ranged specialists, and vestigial arms help with reloading pistols. You can take Explosive Missile to launch bombs out of your weapon, though only as a standard action. Gun Chemist allows you to launch explosive ordnance from your gun starting at first level, and multiple shots per round at level 8.

Alchemist // Hunter

Basics: Med BAB, d8, Fort and Ref,  6 skills, two 6 level casting, physical Int Wis

Animal companion is a handy flanking partner for a vivisectionist, but that's the extent of this synergy.

Alchemist // Inquisitor

Basics: Med BAB, d8, all saves, 6 skills, two 6 level casting, physical Int Wis

No particular synergy here, too unfocused. Living Grimoire reduces MAD, which makes it marginally better for a bomber build that wants to be able to hit something over the head in a pinch – but not strong enough for a good combat build.

Alchemist // Investigator

Basics: Med BAB, d8, all saves, 6 skills+, two 6 level casting, physical Int

You don't get much in the way of increased combat capability or magical versatility. Still, you've got all your saves and a lot of options for utility between discoveries and talents, so that's something. You'll want to look into archetypes that trade away overlapping abilities like swift alchemy and poison resistance/immunity – Empiricist being the easiest choice. Not a bad place for metamorph – you'll miss bombs, but you get extracts from Investigator anyway, and the shapeshifting is very useful.

Alchemist // Magus

Basics: Med BAB, d8, all saves, 4 skills, full and part casting, Int & Physical

Various magical combat-boosting abilities all based on Int. Let the alchemist handle self-buffs and area debuffs via bombs while the magus focuses on touch spells and group buffs. For a combat-focused gestalt your BAB/HD are disappointing (and if you're not planning on doing weapons combat magus is a waste). Note also that your Str-boosting mutagen will decrease your Int; Dex or Con mutagens are a safer bet. Extracts don't work with spellstrike or spell combat. You can however deliver a bomb and ray at the same time using Grenadier and Myrmidarch or Eldritch Archer.

Alchemist // Kineticist

Basics: Med BAB, d8, Fort and Ref, 4 skills, 6 level casting, Con Dex Int

A fairly versatile blaster with some utility. The bomb and kinetic blast have similar effects and separate mechanics, so they don't really synergize, but at least you can diversify damage types. Alternatively, elemental annihilator is much more attractive when you can get utility from extracts and pairs well with vivisectionist for melee – which also decreases your need for Int to improve your bombs.

Alchemist // Medium ** (Metamorph ***)

Basics: Med BAB, d8, all saves, 4 skills, two partial casting, Int Cha

The archmage and hierophant seance bonuses don't work with your extracts or bombs, so no casting synergy. Metamorph + Champion or Guardian spirit works well enough for melee.

Alchemist // Mesmerist ***

Basics: Med BAB, d8, all saves, 6 skills, two 6 level casting, Int Cha Dex

Moderately versatile; primary strength in debuffing with potential for area control, support, healing, ranged damage, social utility, and knowledge skills. Not a ton of synergy between features, though the Mesmerist's stare will soften targets up or add extra damage to bombs -  the Lethality improvement is good for a poisoner alchemist. Another option is the Interrogator Alchemist, which lets you add another penalty to Will saves, but at the cost of bombs and mutagen (thus most of your versatility). Biggest challenge is in keeping two mental stats high enough for strong DCs. Metamorph is the only decent option for a melee build – alternatively try Alchemist//Medium or Occultist.

Weirdo’s Comment on the above: those are definitely some interesting synergy options, and next time I have time to put some thought into this guide I’ll see if the rating for this combo needs to be bumped up to Blue. However, having to invest in two casting stats is still a definite handicap for this build, especially since the Medium’s mind-control (and most alchemist bombs) are very DC-dependent. While Cognatogen can somewhat compensate, it isn’t as good as being able to really emphasize one stat, especially if you get full casting as with Alchemist//Psychic. Overall, as I mentioned in the introduction, one of my criteria for a really good gestalt is whether it can bring both a high level of versatility and at least one strong area of specialization, and I’m not sure this build manages the latter.

Alchemist // Monk ***/*

Basics: Med/Full BAB, d8/d10, all saves/Fort Ref, 4 skills, 6 level casting, physical Int Wis

Best build options are Vivisectionist//Unchained for mobile melee shredding, Grenadier//Zen Archer for Int & Wis heavy ranged damage & control, or a more general bomb build with Sensei and optionally Ki Mystic for extra support. In all cases you get some additional buffing and utility from extracts. Metamorph Alchemist also works reasonably as a melee option, though I recommend Goliath Druid for more utility and better Wis synergy. Consider Investigator//Monk.

Alchemist // Occultist ***

Basics: Med BAB, d8, all saves,  4 skills, two 6-level casting, Int & Physical

You can get very good stats between mutagen and transmutation implements, giving you a decent base for melee despite only medium BAB. Combat style involves some heavy tradeoffs. Natural weapons work well with lower BAB but can't be enhanced with Legacy Weapon. Two-handed makes good use of high strength but may cause problems with Trappings of the Warrior (your GM may let you use a shield strapped to your back – otherwise Shield Brace will work or failing that a buckler at -1 to attack). Sword-and-board is easier to use with Trappings of the Warrior but not otherwise a great combat style.  A bomb build is pretty easy to make as you can focus on Int and invest in implements that do things other than combat buffs. For implement schools consider powers that the alchemist doesn't have access to – which are largely in conjuration (servitor, teleportation), divination (mind eye), enchantment, illusion (mirror image), and necromancy.  Note that the champion bonus from haunt collector improves bomb damage since it's not a spell.

Alchemist // Oracle **/*

Basics: Med BAB, d8, all saves, 4 skills, full & 6-level casting, Cha Int (physical?)

Not a lot of synergy, but a good spread of options and solid defenses. You can make a decent natural weapons build with the Lunar Mystery, taking Prophetic Armour to reduce MAD, and using Gift of Claw & Horn with Feral Mutagen (or the Metamorph archetype) to get four natural attacks by level 3. Alternatively, the Lore mystery’s Mental Acuity is a nice boost if you prefer bombs, though Sidestep Secret’s Cha to AC isn’t as useful when you want Dex for throwing and initiative.

Alchemist // (Anti)Paladin **/*

Basics: Full BAB, d10, all saves+, 4 skills, 6 & 4 level casting, physical Cha Int

Good damage and durability, and you get a nice bundle of buffs and debuffs to play with, but the stat requirements are awkward. Metamorph fixes that but at the cost of versatility.

Alchemist // Psychic *****

Basics: Med BAB, d8, all saves, 4 skills, full & part casting, Int and Wis or Cha

Excellent variety of ranged damage, debuffing, control, and support abilities with Int synergy and solid, armoured durability. When there's overlap on your spell lists, use Psychic for effects you'll use reliably and for multi-target effects (Haste!) while preparing extracts for more circumstantial effects (Water Breathing). The psychedelia discipline is thematic, but isn't too useful with Mindchemist because it gives you an inferior form of cognatagen. As an alternative consider Rebirth for sweet knowledge checks (the bonus stacks with the Mindchemist's) and more casting versatility and durability.

Alchemist // Ranger ***

Basics: Full BAB, d10, Fort and Ref, 6 skills, 6 and 4-level casting, physical Int Wis

Fairly versatile; a strong melee specialist or switch hitter. Good at damage, self-buffing, stealth, some ability to support others. Vivisectionist and/or beastmorph work particularly well for TWF or natural weapons builds and are thematic. Splitting stats between Int and Wis means your bomb DCs won't be high enough for strong battlefield control, so a switch hitter would be better off using bows as the ranged option. If natural weapons are your melee option you don't even need quickdraw.

Alchemist // Rogue **

Basics: Med BAB, d8, Fort and Ref, 8 skills, 6-level casting, physical & Int

Very thematic combination, with sneak attack; poison enhancement; and poison, smoke, and confusion bombs. Big weaknesses are lack of full BAB, with no accuracy booster, and low will save. Bombs hit touch AC, increasing accuracy, but ranged attacks are harder to sneak with, and vivisectionist is pointless. Ninja is not recommended – the ki pool increases MAD and poison use is a duplicate without archetypes. Dirty Tactics, Metamorph?

Half-Orc rogue (skulking slayer/scout) with either alchemist (Beastmorph) or barbarian with beast totem. Bludgeoneer feat makes your natural attacks non-lethal, sap adept/ master feats gives you double sneak attack damage. Scout's charge with pounce and you get flat-footed sneak attacks with all your natural weapons. The enforcer feat puts the fear in them. Dragon style lets you charge almost anywhere.

Alchemist (Saboteur/Trap Breaker)/Rogue (Filcher/Sapper).

Alchemist // Skald **

Basics: Med BAB, d8, Fort and Ref, 4 skills, two 6-level casting, physical Int Cha

Alchemist // Slayer ***

Basics: Full BAB, d10, Fort and Ref, 6 skills, 6-level casting, physical Int

Good combat buffs on both ends and some Intelligence synergy with slayer talent DCs. Sneak attack won't stack, so don't bother with vivisectionist.

Alchemist//Spiritualist

Basics: Med BAB, d8, all saves, 4 skills, two 6-level casting, Int Wis physical?

Alchemist // Sorcerer ***

Basics: Med BAB, d8, all saves, 4 skills, full and partial casting, Int Cha

Nice defences and a lot of casting power. However, two casting stats means that this is far from the best way to combine the alchemist with an arcane caster - or to add durability and melee prowess to your sorcerer. Not horrible, just unimpressive compared to similar alternatives. Consider a bloodline arcanist.

Alchemist // Summoner **

Basics: Med BAB, d8, all saves, 4 skills, two 6-level casting, Int Cha

Not a lot of synergy. Recommend building as a bomber with minimal Cha and using the summoner mostly for group buffs, plus eidolon. Metamorph is your best bet if you want to melee since it gives your physical stats a boost (partly by reducing MAD), though Synthesist might work if you're allowed to apply your Mutagen to your synth suit stats.

Alchemist // Swashbuckler **/* (Inspired Blade ***/*)

Basics: Full BAB, d10, Fort and Ref, 4 skills, 6-level casting, Dex Int Cha

I'd suggest skipping vivisectionist and using bombs as a ranged/control option – since precise strike and sneak attack are both precision damage it sucks if something is immune. You'll want higher Int, but Inspired Blade gives you extra panache out of the deal.

Alchemist // Warpriest ** (Vivisectionist Beastmorph or Metamorph ***)

Basics: Med BAB, d8, all saves, 4 skills, two 6-level casting, physical Int Wis

Has issues with MAD and BAB, but OK for a natural weapons build. Start with Weapon Focus (claws) and consider taking an extra Weapon Focus or two at high levels to get sacred weapon damage on all your attacks (it's worth it for bite around level 15). Consider Martial Versatility to apply key feats to all attacks. There's not much synergy between bombs and the warpriest's weapon enhancements, and you'll need too much Int, so if you want to switch-hit, use archery.

Alchemist Bombs deal 1d6 as their base damage, and then get extra, not critting damage later. Alchemist/Warpriest and Weapon Focus(Bomb). That base damage now scales with level and still gets the extra d6's on top of that!

Alchemist // Witch *****

Basics: Med BAB, d8, all saves, 4 skills+, full and partial casting, Int

Plenty of thematic overlap with affinity for potions, poisons, and informal, strange magic. Mechanically offers casting stat synergy and durability. Lots of options for debuffing between bombs, hexes, and spells, some good buff options, and the potential to be a capable healer. Mindchemist / Cognatogen are good for an Int boost. You won't be able to take advantage of the Alchemist's light armour proficiency.

Alchemist // Wizard *****

Basics: Med BAB, d8, all saves, 4 skills+, full and partial casting, Int

Extremely versatile casting with casting stat synergy and about as much durability as you can expect from a gestalt arcane caster. The alchemist can provide healing, filling the biggest gap on the wizard's list. Plus, the way the alchemist is written, you can copy any spells on your wizard spellbook into your formula book as well, paying copying costs only instead of copying plus research. Mindchemist or Cognatogen are good for an Int boost. You won't be able to take advantage of the Alchemist's light armour proficiency.

Arcanist

This odd little hybrid is one of two casters to require two good mental stats (Int for spells, Cha for arcane reservoir), so it's particularly important to pair it with a class that uses complementary stats. The best choices are Int or Cha-based hybrids or divine casters that improve or diversify a casting role, and add durability. Wis-based casters and martials tend to have issues with MAD, split focus, or armour, though some such concepts are passable.

Blade Adept is also worth mentioning since it does give you a few combat advantages including an arcane bonded black blade and Spellstrike – however the blade's limited progression makes it a mixed blessing, since you can't enhance it on the fly like a magus can with their arcane pool. If your GM bends the rules to let you improve the enchantment (since it is also an arcane bonded weapon) or you're in a low wealth gestalt it's a good archetype, particularly for one of the few martial arcanist gestalts.

Arcanist // Barbarian * (Dreadnought **)

Basics: Full BAB, d12, Fort and Will, 4 skills, full casting, physical Int Cha

Little synergy, and inconvenient to cast while raging.

Arcanist // Bard ***/*

Basics: Med BAB, d8, Ref and Will, 6 skills+, full and partial casting, Int Cha

A solid troubleshooter – lots of skills and spells.

Arcanist // Bloodrager **

Basics: Full BAB, d10, Fort and Will, 4 skills, full casting, physical Int Cha

A tough full caster, capable of casting arcanist spells in rage with the Mad Magic feat. However, Sorcerer-Bloodrager is stronger thanks to better stat synergy.

Arcanist // Brawler **/*

Basics: Full BAB, d10, all saves, 4 skills, full casting, physical Int Cha

The AC bonus is nice on a caster, and unarmed strike works well for delivering touch spells, especially multi-touch spells like Chill Touch or Frostbite. Otherwise not a lot of overlap in the skill set.

Arcanist // Cavalier **

Basics: Full BAB, d10, Fort and Will, 4 skills, full casting, physical Int Cha

Arcanist // Cleric (Ecclesitheurge, Elder Mythos Cultist)

Basics: Med BAB, d8, Fort and Will, 2 skills, two full casting, Int Wis Cha

Extremely versatile spell lists, but quite MAD for a caster. I'd recommend sticking to support spells on the cleric end to minimize Wis requirements - or pick up Elder Mythos Cultist.

Arcanist // Druid ** (Feyspeaker ***)

Basics:  Poor/Med BAB, d8, Fort and Will, 6/4 skills, two full casting, Int Wis Cha

Feyspeaker gets rid of one of your stat requirements.

Arcanist // Fighter * (Blade Adept **)

Basics: Full BAB, d10, Fort and Will, 2 skills, full casting, physical Int Cha

Steep stat requirements and no real synergy. Fighters and full arcane casters are rarely great and the extra stat requirements from the arcanist don't help. Blade adept gives you a little extra combat synergy but it's still not very effective.

Arcanist // Gunslinger (Mysterious Stranger)

Basics: Full BAB, d10, all saves, 4 skills, full casting,  Dex Int Wis Cha

Arcanist // Hunter

Basics: Med BAB, d8, all saves, 6 skills, full and 6-level casting, Int Wis Cha

You don't have the stats to support real weapons combat, but can do pretty well casting from the rear while your pet enters melee, or just using your pet as a mount. Try Empyreal Sorcerer // Hunter.

Arcanist // Inquisitor **/*

Basics: Med BAB, d8, Fort and Will, 6 skills+, full and 6-level casting, Int Cha Wis

Not going to do well in martial combat, so might as well take Relic Hunter – or in a smaller party, Sacred Huntmaster as a reach build. Living Grimoire?

Arcanist // Investigator *** (Empiricist, Blade Adept ****)

Basics: Med BAB, d8, Ref and Will, 6 skills+, full and partial casting, Int Cha

A fine pair if you want an arcane caster with a lot of skills, though consider replacing Investigator with Mindchemist for its good Fort save and Cognatagen. Remember you can write spells from your formula book into your spellbook without researching twice. Blade Adept together with Studied Combat gives you a credible melee option so that brings this up a step – as does Empiricist for Int synergy.

Arcanist // Kineticist **

Basics: Med BAB, d8, all saves, 4 skills, full casting, Con Int Cha Dex

You can do this with fewer stats.

Arcanist // Magus ***/* (Kensai *****)

Basics: Med BAB, d8, Fort and Will, full and partial casting, physical Int Cha

The extra mental stat is a bit rough when you want to be in combat, but it's still a very potent combo. Take Broad Study at level 6 to use arcanist spells with spellstrike and spell combat. The Kensai gives up armour, which the arcanist doesn't want, and spell slots, of which you have plenty, in exchange for Int to AC and some great tricks with a favoured weapon.

Arcanist//Medium

Basics: Med BAB, d8, Will, 4 skills, full and 6-level casting, Int Cha

Not a whole lot of synergy and having only one good save hurts. Pretty much any partial-arcane caster will give you better defenses, at least equal skills, and comparable versatility to the medium.

Arcanist//Mesmerist ****

Basics: Med BAB, d8, Ref and Will, 6 skills, full and 6-level casting, Int Cha

Mesmerist's stare and Mental Potency help Arcanist spells land.

Arcanist // Monk ** (Scaled Fist ***)

Basics: Med/Full BAB, d8/d10, all saves, 4 skills, full casting, Int Cha Wis

The scaled fist is definitely the way to go with this one – even then it will be a bit tricky to get high enough physical stats to use your weapons combat features. You can maybe pull together a maneuver build with Sensei or turtle up with Master of Many Styles, but you'd do better pairing Monk with either Wizard or Sorcerer, or taking Kensai or Alchemist if you want an Arcanist with physical prowess.

Arcanist//Occultist

Basics: Med BAB, d8, Fort and Will, 4 skills, full and partial casting, Int Cha

Strongly consider silksworn to get extra mileage out of your Cha – the only thing you really lose is access to panoplies, which are not fantastic for the arcanist. Recommend conjuration implement between resonant power and access to healing.

Arcanist // Oracle ***/*

Basics: Med BAB, d8, Will, 4 skills, two full casting, Int Cha

Great variety of spellcasting options and some stat synergy with your arcane pool (possibly supplemented with the Lore mystery’s Int boost), brought down by mediocre HD, only one good save, and no armour.

Arcanist // (Anti)Paladin **

Basics: Full BAB, d10, Fort and Will+, 2 skills, full casting, physical Int Cha

The paladin packs a punch and Divine Grace makes up for the lack of a strong reflex save. However, many of your abilities use swift actions, and you've got an armour problem. Paladin//Sorcerer is a better choice.

Arcanist // Psychic **

Basics: Poor BAB, d6, Will, 2 skills+, two full casting, Int Cha

Durability issues, but good stat synergy as long as you pick a Cha-based discipline, and since your spell DCs are both Int based you can make that a primary stat. Psychic spell selection should prioritize staple spells, class-specific spells, and usability with phrenic amplifications – Arcanist fills in the gaps.

Arcanist // Ranger *

Basics: Full BAB, d10, Fort and Will, 6 skills, full casting, all stats

Lots of issues here. Extremely MAD. Armour wearing class plus arcane spell failure. No thanks.

Arcanist // Rogue **

Basics: Med BAB, d8, Ref and Will, 8 skills, full casting, physical Int Cha

Arcanist // Skald ***

Basics: Med BAB, d8, all saves, 4 skills, full and partial casting, Int Cha

Arcanist // Slayer *** (Blade Adept ****)

Basics: Full BAB, d10, all saves, 6 skills+, full casting, physical Int Cha

Sturdier than arcanist//rogue for minimal cost. Intelligence helps slayer DCs and you can use Studied Target and Sneak Attack with rays and similar spells as long as they deal HP damage. Not fantastic but a decent combat arcanist.

Arcanist//Spiritualist (Fractured Soul)

Basics: Med BAB, d8, Fort and Will, 4 skills, full and partial casting, Int Wis Cha

Arcanist // Sorcerer *

Basics: Poor BAB, d6, Will, 2 skills, two full casting, Int Cha

Very fragile, two casting stats, both classes have the same spell list so not much of a versatility boost... bad idea.

Arcanist // Summoner **

Basics: Med BAB, d8, Will, 4 skills, full and partial casting, Int Cha

The eidolon and standard action summoning are very useful. The low saves are a big weakness so you'll want a stronger than usual Dex and Con, and maybe even Great Fortitude.

Arcanist // Swashbuckler ** (Blade Adept // Inspired Blade ***)

Basics: Full BAB, d10, Ref and Will, 4 skills, casting

Not bad, but runs into the typical action economy problem with non-Magus gish builds – without Spell Combat it's very costly to both cast and attack. Inspired Blade is the most synergistic since you'll get more out of the Arcanist's high Int.

Arcanist // Warpriest *

Basics: Med BAB, d8, Ref and Will, 2 skills+, full and partial casting, all stats

Terrible because you need all three mental stats, which leaves you no room for the physical stats you'd need to make warpriest a better option than cleric. Go Arcanist//Cleric for casting, or Empyreal Sorcerer//Warpriest if you want to fight.

Arcanist // Witch ***

Basics: Poor BAB, d6, Will, 2 skills+, two full casting, Int Cha

Super fragile by gestalt standards but hugely magically powerful by combining two forms of int-based full casting with different lists, and an extremely versatile set of goodies between hexes and exploits.

Arcanist // Wizard **

Basics: Poor BAB, d6, Will, 2 skills+, two full casting, Int Cha

Marginally better than Arcanist//Sorcerer because the half-spontaneous casting complements true prepared casting better than true spontaneous casting, you've got faster access to the most powerful spells, you don't need quite as much Cha since it's just for exploits, and you might be able to share spells across your spellbooks. Still a bad idea because you're terribly fragile and even if you've got lots of spells they're all from the same list. Try Arcanist//Witch or Kineticist//Wizard.

Barbarian

The barbarian is a strong martial class, tough and capable of massive damage in melee or, with the right build, solid damage at range. Note: spell sunder works at range. It works best with hybrid classes that enhance the barbarian's combat options while also providing some utility options. Pure martials generally don't add a lot of versatility to the barbarian. Pure casters rarely synergize well.

The barbarian's trickiest element is the inability to cast while raging. There are a few ways to manage this. The easiest, if your spell list co-operates, is picking out of combat spells, prebuffs, or occasionally first round buff or control options. Moment of Clarity and Mad Magic give you a limited ability to ragecast (specifically, one round per rage), at the cost of 1-2 rage powers and possibly a feat depending on how badly you care about keeping rage bonuses while you cast. It’s a reasonable route if you want to be able to cast an emergency mid-combat spell - or if you can find an easy way to rage cycle. Alternatively, the Dreadnought suffers no penalties or limitations during a rage, but also gains only half the usual benefits. This archetype makes it possible to build a broader array of gestalt barbarians that actually integrate casting with combat, including reach casters.

Some GMs may interpret the restriction against “abilities that require patience or concentration” more broadly than spellcasting. With respect to psychic casters, it's also important to check whether rage counts as a “hostile emotion effect.” Descriptions note if a combination's effectiveness is subject to this table variation.

Barbarian // Bard ****

Basics: Full BAB, d12, all saves, 6 skills+, 6-level casting, physical Cha

Strong melee capability, good support and utility. In early levels bardic abilities compete with your attacks, but at higher levels you can spend a round at most starting a performance and maybe casting a group buff before wading in. Lots of options out of combat, too. Avoid debuffs, charm, and other effects with saves – you probably won't afford a high enough charisma to pull it off. In the event that your GM won't let you use performance while raging (uncommon, but not unheard of) consider Archaeologist – otherwise the combination is green at best.

Barbarian // Bloodrager *

Basics: Full BAB, d12, Fort, 4 skills, no casting, physical Cha

You get two non-compatible sets of rage abilities and fail to shore up your weaknesses. If your GM allows you to merge your rages and use rage powers and bloodrage abilities at the same time, this could be yellow, but only if you choose archetypes to swap out duplicate abilities (for example, Invulnerable Barbarian and Spelleater Bloodrager). You'll also want Superstition for your saves.

Barbarian // Brawler ***/*

Basics: Full BAB, d12, Fort and Ref, 4 skills, no casting, physical

Lots of damage, great durability, and some control options, but shy on utility. The strength bonus is great when you're using TWF with full Str on each attack. Soak damage as well as you deal it with Stalwart and Improved Stalwart – bonus feats and Brawler's Cunning take the edge off the stiff prerequisites and Combat Expertise is great for the Brawler since you can fill in maneuver feats with Martial Flexibility, adding control options. If you're interested in rage cycling, consider Barbarian//Martial Artist Monk.

Barbarian // Cavalier

Basics: Full BAB, d12, Fort, 4 skills, no casting, physical

Barbarian // Cleric *** (Dreadnought ****)

Basics: Full BAB, d12, Fort and Will, 4 skills, full casting, physical Wis

A solid combat combo with support capability, but relatively low on out of combat utility and you'll find it more difficult to balance fighting with casting than the similar Barbarian//Oracle, Barbarian//Druid, or Bloodrager//Cleric gestalts. Dreadnought makes a good reach build – the Quick Reflexes rage power can compensate for a less than stellar Dex.

Barbarian // Druid ****

Basics: Full BAB, d12, Fort and Will, 4 skills, full casting, physical Wis

The raging beast! You have plenty of out of combat utility spells and long duration pre-buffs to avoid ragecasting; a reach casting build with Dreadnought is possible, but Moment of Clarity will suffice for the occasional mid-combat spell. Beast Totem, while thematic, is less useful in this gestalt since the natural armour and pounce overlap with wild shape's bonuses. Consider Goliath Druid for massive strength with weapons-based combat.

Barbarian // Fighter ** (Mutation Warrior ***)

Basics: Full BAB, d12, Fort, 4 skills, no casting, physical

If you want to do something feat-intensive with your barbarian, this works OK. Mutation Warrior takes this up a step because of the stat boost and extra tricks from alchemist discoveries. Martial Master is worth considering for flexibility – as with the Brawler, it works nicely to add Combat Expertise-based feats if you want the Stalwart/Improved Stalwart chain.

Barbarian // Gunslinger * (Urban Barbarian **, Savage Technologist ***)

Basics: Full BAB, d12, Fort and Ref, 4 skills, no casting, Dex Wis

Normally the barbarian and gunslinger have incompatible combat styles, but the Urban Barbarian and Savage Technologist archetypes offer Dex-based rages that work moderately well with the gunslinger.

However, you're still low on out of combat utility and have a poor will save, so meh.

Barbarian // Hunter ****

Basics: Full BAB, d12, Fort and Ref, 6 skills, 6-level casting, physical Wis

Both you and your pet will be strong fighters with this combination; strongly consider the Ferocious Mount line of rage powers, along with Pack Flanking. Like the druid, casting can be used for utility and long-duration prebuffs rather than while raging. Strongly consider Iron Will, especially since the Int 13 requirement for Pack Flanking means your Wis will likely be modest.

Barbarian // Inquisitor ****/*

Basics: Full BAB, d12, Fort and Will, 6 skills+, 6-level casting, physical Wis

Bane and either judgement or studied target pile on more hurt to the devastating fury of the barbarian. You have plenty of options to make use of Intimidate, and a good range of other utility potential including scouting, tracking, social and knowledge skills. Sacred Huntmaster gives you access to a mount with Amplified Rage, making it one of the stronger pet gestalts.

Barbarian // Investigator **/**

Basics: Full BAB, d12, all saves, 6 skills+, 6-level casting, physical and Int

Depends entirely on one question: will your GM let you use Studied Combat while raging or does that ability require patience and concentration? If they are compatible this is a fantastic combination with full BAB, lots of combat buffs, plenty of durability and good skills and magical utility. I recommend Mutagen and Quick Study as your 3rd and 5th level talents. If the two classes' combat boosts aren't compatible then the usefulness plummets compared to similar full BAB/hybrid gestalts.

Barbarian//Kineticist * (Dreadnought ****)

Basics: Full BAB, d12, Fort and Ref, 4 skills, pseudo-casting, physical

Blasts, as spell-like abilities, can't be used while raging, which makes Dreadnought practically mandatory. The high-investment alternative means taking the Moment of Clarity and Perfect Clarity rage powers and the Mad Magic feat, and then becoming immune to fatigue (eg: android with the Empathy feat) so as to use Moment of Clarity every round. Either way, the Con bonus and extra HP makes this combo a heavy hitter with blasts. Raging Vitality is a must-have for another +2 Con. Rage Powers Surprise Accuracy and Reckless Abandon are useful for increasing accuracy on physical blast users. Make sure to patch the low will save.

Barbarian // Magus * (Dreadnought ***)

Basics: Full BAB, d12, Fort and Will, 4 skills, 6-level casting, Str Con Int

Rage makes spell combat and spellstrike impossible, unless you take Dreadnought, in which case you're looking at a pretty decent strength based frontliner. The halved bonuses for rage aren't fantastic with a one-handed style, and rage powers requiring activation hamper the magus' action economy. Specific rage power suggestions?

Barbarian//Medium

Basics: Full BAB, d12, Fort and Will, 4 skills, partial casting, physical and Cha

Barbarian // Mesmerist **/*

Basics: Full BAB, d12, all saves, 6 skills, 6-level casting, physical and Cha

Check with your GM if the Hypnotizing Stare, which requires “focus” is compatible with rage, which doesn't allow “patience and concentration.” If you can use the two together, proceed to trantrum your way to victory, glaring at your foes to shake their resolve and increase the damage of your assault. Otherwise, the main benefits for the barbarian are the good saves and utility or pre-buffing spells, which isn't bad but you can get it elsewhere. Consider Barbarian//Bard or Bloodrager//Mesmerist.

Barbarian // Monk *****

Basics: Full BAB, d12, all saves+, 4 skills, no casting, physical and Wis

To get around the alignment restriction, I recommend Martial Artist, which gets immunity to fatigue at level 5, and that means rage cycling. That's not all. Offensively you can flurry while “rage pouncing” – consider Dragon Style to increase unarmed strike damage and allow you to pounce through difficult terrain. Defensively you have all good saves, evasion, the option to take Superstition for even better saves, a boatload of immunities and resistances besides fatigue, DR, and loads of HP. You can even manage a pretty good AC between beast totem, the dodge bonus on exploit weakness, and the monk's AC bonus. If your stats aren't great consider Urban Barbarian for a Dex build. If you take Enlightened Warrior, there is also some potentially interesting synergy between the Drunken Monk and the Drunken Brute archetype, which would let you gain drunken ki points and drunken rage points at the same time. Evasion overlaps – consider additional monk archetypes that swap that ability out (such as Monk of the Sacred Mountain, compatible with Drunken Monk). Unchained is meh; you’d rather have the Will save than redundant BAB.

Barbarian // Oracle *****

Basics: Full BAB, d12, Fort and Will, 4 skills, full casting, physical and Cha

I'm assuming you're taking the lame curse here, because immunity to fatigue at level 5 allows you both to rage cycle and to drop out of rage whenever you want to cast - or invest in Mad Magic and keep raging while you cast. (Other curses drop this down to green.) Lunar is ideal for a natural weapons build and using Cha for AC reduces MAD.

Barbarian // Occultist ***

Basics: Full BAB, d12, Fort and Will, 4 skills, 6-level casting, physical Int

Hard to go really wrong taking a ragemonster and adding self-buffs and utility. On the other hand, the Occultist needs more Int investment than most partial casters and most of its active focus powers are SLAs that can't be used in rage, so this isn't ideal. Essentially, you have two options. You can take Dreadnought and build like a standard battle occultist with rage powers and reduced rage bonuses. Or, you can enjoy full barbarian bonuses but avoid in-combat focus powers (side step, danger sight) in favour of utility and careful prebuffing. Abjuration has a lot of in-combat powers, so it's skippable for the latter ragecultist – Transmutation is still great, aside from sudden speed. Thematically, you can describe implements as talismans if you'd like a consistent tribal feel. The Psychodermist archetype's trophy implements may also be thematic.

Barbarian // (Anti)Paladin **/**

Basics: Full BAB, d12, Fort and Will+, 4 skills, 4-level casting, physical Cha

The alignment restriction normally limits you to the Antipaladin, which doesn't add a lot to the barbarian. However if your GM allows it the Barbarian//Paladin is a massively durable combination, truly terrifying against evil, and the fatigue mercy allows you to rage cycle. The lesser celestial totem, in addition to being thematic, lets you add your level to your lay on hands during a rage.

Barbarian // Psychic **

Basics: Full BAB, d12, Fort and Will, 4 skills, full casting, physical Int and Wis or Cha

MAD, not much synergy. Unless you're keen on a Wis-based discipline I'd recommend Bloodrager//Psychic for a little more stat synergy and easier access to Mad Magic.

Barbarian // Ranger ***

Basics: Full BAB, d12, Fort and Ref, 6 skills, 4-level casting, physical Wis

Makes a pretty good switch-hitter with the archery ranger style and a natural weapons barbarian build (boosted by ranger spells). It's easy to get three primary natural attacks by level 2 with careful race selection (tiefling is a good option). You also get quite a bit of utility between skills and spells.

Barbarian // Rogue ***

Basics: Full BAB, d12, Fort and Ref, 8 skills, no casting, physical

The barbarian shores up the rogue's weaknesses – poor accuracy and fragility – while the rogue gives the barbarian a nice chunk of extra damage, a ref save, and some skills. The Urban Barbarian archetype is thematic and works well with a finesse rogue. The scout archetype gives you a sneak attack on your first attack after moving, which works well with pounce. Nice candidate for Sap Adept and Sap Master with Enforcer to add demoralization. For Strength-based TWF or ranged combat, see barbarian//slayer.

Barbarian // Skald

Basics: Full BAB, d12, Fort and Ref, 4 skills, casting

Barbarian // Slayer ***/*

Basics: Full BAB, d12, Fort and Ref, 6 skills, no casting, physical Int

Strong combat abilities, good utility. Big advantage over barbarian//rogue is access to Str-based TWF, which is pretty devastating with rage and the Double Slice feat. Also less invested in sneak attack since it shares space with the studied target buff – which, together with combat styles, also makes this a good choice for a ranged character or switch hitter.

Barbarian//Spiritualist

Basics: Full BAB, d12, Fort and Will, 4 skills, 6-level casting, physical & Wis

 

Barbarian // Sorcerer * (Dreadnought ***)

Basics: Full BAB, d12, Fort and Will, 4 skills, full casting, physical & Cha

You’re going to spend a lot of effort working around arcane spell failure and the casting while raging restrictions, and the barbarian doesn't normally use Cha. If you’re a big fan of rage powers you’d do OK with Dreadnought and a combat-focused bloodline. Otherwise look at Bloodrager.

Barbarian // Summoner ***

Basics: Full BAB, d12, Fort and Will, 4 skills, 6-level casting, physical Cha

Best as a lightly armoured mounted build, since Ferocious Mount and Greater Ferocious Mount are big boosts to your eidolon. Use pre-buffs and tap Moment of Clarity if you need to drop a control spell (Mad Magic optional). If you're not going mounted, consider Bloodrager//Summoner instead.

Barbarian // Swashbuckler * (Urban Barbarian or Savage Technologist **)

Basics: Full BAB, d12, Fort and Ref, 4 skills, no casting, Dex Con Cha

Normally the barbarian's rage does little to help the swashbuckler's combat style, but the variant rages of the Urban Barbarian or Savage Technologist increase Dex. Savage Technologist can act as a switch hitter, or maybe a thrown weapons build thanks to the Str/Dex combo, but its TWF ability doesn't work with Precise Strike or the Dex-to-damage feats. Only moderately strong in its melee niche, and not very versatile. Consider instead Urban Barbarian // Unchained Rogue, which gives you a dexterous barbarian with better skills, or Alchemist // Swashbuckler, for a more versatile swashbuckler enhanced by alchemy instead of rage.

Barbarian // Warpriest ***/* (Dreadnought ****)

Basics: Full BAB, d12, Fort and Will, 4 skills, 6-level casting, physical & Wis

Killer combatant with solid self-buffing ability and some support/healing/debuff potential. Warpriest allows more variety in combat styles than your average rager; notably TWF (take Double Slice), throwing (Hurler barbarian + Arsenal Chaplain warpriest for Ricochet Shot), unarmed (Sacred Fist) and even archery (Savage Technologist or Primal Hunter barbarian). You'll need Dreadnought or Moment of Clarity and Mad Magic to get the most use out of fervour's spellcasting action economy. If you aren't interested in Beast Totem you can significantly increase the usefulness of fervour's self-healing using lesser celestial totem.

Barbarian // Witch **/* (Old Scarred Witch Doctor ****)

Basics: Full BAB, d12, Fort and Will, 4 skills, full casting, physical & Int

You can use hexes while raging, and the pre-errata scarred witch doctor offers excellent Con synergy. Spells still cause problems between rage and armour. Overall the best true arcane class to pair with Barbarian.

Barbarian // Wizard *

Basics: Full BAB, d12, Fort and Will, 4 skills, full casting, physical & Int

Armour spell failure, needs investment to cast while raging, no stat synergy. Try Bloodrager//Arcanist.

Bard

The bard is a versatile part-caster with two big draws for gestalt: utility and action types. Swift action spells and move or swift action performance can often be combined with attacks or spells from another gestalt class. As typical for hybrids bard pairs best with charisma-based full casters and with martial characters. When gestalting with a caster, take advantage of neat bard-only spells like Glibness or Saving Finale. Geisha is a nice archetype for unarmoured gestalts – you lose just weapon proficiency and bardic knowledge in exchange for a bonus on courtly skills, the ability to use performance as a long-duration buff (tea ceremony) in addition to its normal form, and Scribe Scroll. When combining bard with a martial class, consider Arcane Duelist and Chelish Diva for the ability to cast bard spells in medium or even heavy armour. The dervish archetypes and the archaeologist (“selfish bards”) let you  activate your main buff more quickly at low levels, and for the Dawnflower Dervish and Archaeologist your personal combat bonus is bigger than Inspire Courage's group buff. That makes them strong options if you're in a small party or someone else has Inspire Courage.

Bard // Bloodrager ****

Basics: Full BAB, d10, all saves, 6 skills+, 6- and 4-level casting, physical Cha

Strong melee capability, good support and utility. In early levels bardic abilities compete with your attacks, but at higher levels you can rely more on pre-buffing and swift actions. You should be able to avoid casting bard spells after the first round of combat but Mad Magic is there for you if you need it. Casting stat synergy is nice, though it may not be worth investing enough charisma and feats to have strong offensive spells.

Bard // Brawler ***/*

Basics: Full BAB, d10, all saves, 6 skills+, 6-level casting, physical Cha

Good combat base with a light armour preference, support abilities, and skills. Very versatile in and out of combat. Good candidate for archaeologist since the Brawler doesn't use many swift actions.

Bard // Cavalier *** (Daring Champion ****)

Basics: Full BAB, d10, all saves, 6 skills+, 6-level casting, physical Cha

The Don Quixote. Good combination of melee skill and support, with the best option being the Daring Champion for a Dex build with extra charisma synergy and a preference for lighter armour.

Bard // Cleric *** (Elder Mythos Cultist ****)

Basics: Med BAB, d8, all saves, 6 skills+, full and 6-level casting, physical Cha Wis

Good pair for a support character. You may also be able to build for a secondary weapon-using role (though your stats make reach style difficult) or offensive spells with either class. With a good charisma consider channelling – or make an effective Undead Lord. The Dirge Bard is thematic for this but doesn't directly enhance the cleric's ability to Command Undead. Elder Mythos Cultist has a bit better synergy thanks to the single casting stat. The Cultist is particularly recommended if you want to make others’ minds your plaything, or want a reach build but don’t quite have the stats. Bokrug grants the Ranseur for reach builds, while Hastur is otherwise thematic and the Rapier isn’t bad as a backup weapon. Mute Musician is thematic with the Elder Mythos and as written the Mute ability lets you use your instrument for verbal components from any class (though check with your GM, and note that your Dulled Horror save bonus is partially wasted). Or try Bard//Oracle for stat synergy with fewer strings attached.

Bard // Druid *** (Feyspeaker ****/*)

Basics: Med BAB, d8, all saves, 6 skills+, full and 6-level casting, physical Wis Cha

Lots of support, control, and utility, but MAD and short on martial skill. Feyspeaker is thematic and adds Cha synergy, which gives you more room for the stats to support a secondary combat role. Recommend reach or Songbird of Doom (with actual singing).

Bard // Fighter ****

Basics: Full BAB, d10, all saves, 6 skills+, 6-level casting, physical Cha

Good commander with a strong combat base, support, and utility. Note that the bonus skills from Lore Warden apply in addition to the bard’s 6+Int skill ranks.

Bard // Gunslinger *** (Juggler ****)

Basics: Full BAB, d10, all saves, 6 skills+, 6-level casting, Dex Cha Wis

Mostly lends itself to using the gun with a little buffing on the side, but you should also be able to afford a high enough Charisma for offensive or in-combat casting if desired, and since you don't have a lot of Swift actions, you can make good use of Arcane Strike or Quickened spells at higher levels. Note: Mysterious Stranger eats into those swift actions, so it's usually not worth the Cha synergy. Juggler gets a special mention since juggling your pistols lets you dual-wield, reload, and cast spells at the same time (plus it looks cool).

Bard // Hunter

Basics: Med BAB, d8, all saves, 6 skills+, two 6-level casting, physical Wis Cha

Good support and utility build in a small party. Otherwise consider Bard//Druid, Ranger, or Slayer.

Bard // Inquisitor **

Basics: Med BAB, d8, all saves, 6 skills+, two 6-level casting, physical Wis Cha

Too unfocused. You have to spend a lot of actions buffing yourself into a competitive combatant – though bardic music, judgment, bane, and spells all provide good boosts, you'll need two or three at least to catch up to most full BAB gestalts, and three of them are eventually competing for your swift actions.

Bard // Investigator ***

Basics: Med BAB, d8, Ref and Will, 6 skills+, two 6-level casting, physical Int Cha

A good support/utility gestalt. You get lots of skill points and even more skill-enhancing abilities, plus utility spells/extracts. You're also fairly strong in melee with Studied Combat giving you a hefty accuracy and damage boost which can be combined with Bardic Music. Mutagen is also a useful buff to have in your pocket. A little MAD, and a little fragile for a melee gestalt, but not disastrously so.

Bard // Kineticist

Basics: Med BAB, d8, all saves, 6 skills+, 6-level and pseudo-casting, Con Dex Cha

Bard // Magus ** (Dawnflower Dervish *** / Eldritch Scion)

Basics: Med BAB, d8, all saves, 6 skills+, two 6-level casting, physical Int Cha

Lack of full BAB or full casting and MAD issues make this one a tepid combo. The dawnflower dervish gives you a leg up on the popular dervish dancing magus build, including enough of a self-buff to keep up in combat with medium BAB. Eldritch scion makes the combination less MAD but makes it harder to use key magus features.

Bard // Medium

Basics: Med BAB, d8, Ref and Will, 6 skills+, 6- and 4-level casting, physical Cha

Note that the Marshal's Inspiring Call ability doesn't stack with Inspire Courage. Spirit Dancer is thematic and really lets you get the most out of the versatility of the combination.

Bard // Mesmerist ***

Basics: Med BAB, d8, Ref and Will, 6 skills+, two 6-level casting, physical Cha

This combination enables a lot of mind games with many different ways to mess with your opponents or assist your allies, but it doesn't do a lot to diversify your concept.

Bard // Monk **/* (Zen Archer, Sohei, *** Unchained Scaled Fist ****)

Basics: Med/Full BAB, d8/d10, all saves, 6 skills+, 6-level casting, physical Wis Cha

Unsurprisingly, Unchained Scaled Fist is the best option with Cha synergy, full BAB, and all saves. Works best as a melee build, though with Cha investment you can debuff pretty well between stunning fist, intimidation, and spells. Since you're already dropping armour, consider Geisha. If you're looking for a different combat style, you could make something half-decent with Zen Archer or Sohei (reach or switch-hitter).

Bard // Occultist ***

Basics: Med BAB, d8, all saves, 6 skills+, two 6-level casting, Int Cha physical

Lots of utility, only passable offence made more difficult due to MAD. When considering implement schools, you'll want to give extra weight to spells not on the bard list.

  • Abjuration has a lot of these: Shield, Resist Energy, Magic Circle Against [], Protection from Energy, Life Bubble, Dimensional Anchor, Stoneskin, Spell Immunity, Antimagic Field, and Globe of Invulnerability.
  • Conjuration's got a few goodies across multiple levels: Mage Armor, Mount, Minor Creation, Major Creation, Teleport, Wall of Stone, Heal, and Create Demiplane.
  • Divination also has a handful of new spells: Augury, Status, Arcane Sight, Commune, True Seeing, and Prediction of Failure.
  • Enchantment mostly features bard spells without the early access the bard gets. There are a handful of additions - Inflict Pain, Mind Swap, Mindwipe, and Antipathy/Sympathy – but overall it's just inferior to bard options.
  • Evocation is almost entirely new ground. It's not great ground, but versatility is handy.
  • Illusion, like enchantment, is almost entirely shared with the bard, with minor exceptions such as Mask Dweomer or Illusory Wall. On the other hand, the occultist does at least get these spells at the same level as a bard does, and being able to learn them as an occultist frees up bard slots for something else.
  • Necromancy has quite a lot of new stuff. Notables include the Inflict spells, Animate Dead, False Life, Bestow Curse, Gentle Repose, Riding Possession, Death Ward, Possession, Major Curse, Object Possession, Suffocation, Harm, and Greater Possession.
  • Transmutation of course has the widest variety of spells. Many of the good ones are shared with the bard. Occultist-only options include Enlarge Person, Lead Blades, Gravity Bow, Pass Without Trace, Greater Magic Weapon, Magic Vestment, Air Walk, Overland Flight, Telekinesis, and Disintegrate.

Now, looking at build options:

  • For a combat build you'll want Panoply Savant(Warrior), ideally with a combat bard archetype such as Arcane Duelist (strength-based melee with medium armour and a heavy shield) or Arrowsong Minstrel (longbow with buckler panoply implement – counts as full BAB for feats). For a “selfish” Dex build the dervish dancer and archaeologist work with fencing or slashing grace, which allow bucklers. The archaeologist is also thematic. You won't have a lot of extra focus after the panoply, so chose your other implements based on spells and maybe one or two utility focus powers. Conjuration and Illusion are good choices. Purge Corruption and Shadow Beast are worth considering. Divination's resonant power will probably not see much use due to the high cost, and its spell list is only meh, but Mind Eye is great. Enchantment, Necromancy, and Evocation generally rely too much on DCs.
  • A caster has more options depending on how they prioritize stats. Transmutation and Abjuration are still excellent choices for the spell lists alone. Divination gets a lot more attractive when you have the focus to invest in it. Evocation and Necromancy also look a lot better if you can get your Int high enough for competitive DCs. Silksworn is a strong choice here, though unlike some gestalts losing armour hurts. I'd recommend it particularly for manipulator builds. Focus on Cha for mental focus, high DCs on superior bard enchantment spells, and social skills. Enjoy the sneaky bonuses from silksworn eloquence and silksworn deception. Use implements for buffing and utility. Note an interesting synergy between the Dirge Bard's ability to influence undead with mind-affecting effects, and the necromancy implement's resonant power applying a penalty to undead saving throws.

Bard // Oracle ****

Basics: Med BAB, d8, Ref and Will, 6 skills+, full and 6-level casting, Cha

Great for support, healing, and debuffs. If you want a weapon, make it a reach build. Lore mystery is thematic and gives you access to crazy Cha synergy, though the Lunar and Nature mysteries also suffice for the latter. Voice of the Wild Bard//Nature Oracle makes a neat druidic sage. If you take the Heavens mystery make sure to have options for dealing with mindless opponents.

Bard // (Anti)Paladin ****

Basics: Full BAB, d10, all saves, 6 skills+, 6 and 4-level casting, physical Cha

A real do-everything build: combat, support, buffing, debuffing, and skills. The Dawnflower Dervish is both thematic and effective for a paladin of Sarenrae.

Bard // Psychic ***

Basics: Med BAB, d8, Ref and Will, 6 skills+, full and 6-level casting, Int Cha

Enchantment, divination, and illusion – buffs and mind-affecting spells –  there's a lot of overlap on your spell lists. Since both classes are spontaneous you shouldn't run out of useful stuff, though I'd still prefer the versatility of a more divergent spell list. I recommend selecting any debuffs as a psychic since it'll be easier to achieve high DCs and you have access to Will of the Dead with those spells. Rapport is a thematic and useful discipline, though anything Cha-based will be fine. Plays like a support caster bard only more so.

Bard // Ranger ***

Basics: Full BAB, d10, all saves, 6 skills+, 6-level and 4-level casting, physical Wis Cha

A little MAD, but still plenty competent in combat with good support and diverse utility. Archery and TWF (including shield bashing) are both valid styles with lots of static damage bonuses – consider Dervish Dancer archetype for the latter.

Bard // Rogue **

Basics: Med BAB, d8, Ref and Will, 8 skills+, 6-level casting, physical Cha

The “selfish” archetypes add enough combat ability to keep the rogue competent, and invisibility helps with sneak attack, but this is still a sub-par combination with too much overlap in its basic abilities. Try bard//slayer.

Bard // Skald *

Basics: Med BAB, d8, all saves, 6 skills+, 6-level casting, physical Cha
