You can't use both forms of performance at the same time, and getting access to the same spell list twice doesn't improve your versatility much.

Bard // Slayer ***/*

Basics: Full BAB, d10, all saves, 6 skills+, 6-level casting, physical Int Cha

Bonus feats are handy; weapon finesse, TWF and archery are all handy for the bard depending on your archetype choice (Dawnflower Dervish is great for TWF). Greater Invisibility plus Sneak Attack at level 10 is all kinds of lovely, especially for archers. You've also got a great array of skill bonuses depending on bard archetype and slayer talents – and Studied Combat is actually really nice for social interactions. Avoid talents with DCs and use buff spells to minimize your need for the mental stats.

Bard // Sorcerer ****

Basics: Med BAB, d8, Ref and Will, 6 skills+, full and 6-level casting, Cha (physical)

Fine durability, charisma synergy, expanded spell options, lots of skills, and swift action abilities from the bard to complement a primarily casting focus. You can load up on charisma, or if your physical stats are decent take one or two combat feats (weapon finesse and arcane strike are good choices)  and step into melee in a pinch. Reach build works if you can get proficiency in the Elven Branched Spear. For a bloodline consider something that works well with your bard spells (such as Fey for the boost to compulsions), or aim for Great Fortitude as a bloodline feat.

Bard//Spiritualist (Fractured Mind)

Basics: Med BAB, d8, all saves, 6 skills+, two 6-level casting, physical Cha

Bard // Summoner ****

Basics: Med BAB, d8, Ref and Will, 6 skills+, two 6-level casting, Cha

The One-PC army, good choice for a small party. Lots of support for your summons (and other party members) with a little debuffing and control.

Bard // Swashbuckler ***/*

Basics: Full BAB, d10, Ref and Will, 6 skills+, 6-level casting, Dex Cha

Bard // Warpriest ** (Dervish ***)

Basics: Med BAB, d8, all saves, 6 skills+, two 6-level casting, physical Wis Cha

You need TWF, one of the Dervish archetypes, and high stats to get good enough in combat for this to be worth it – otherwise Bard//Cleric or Bard//Paladin is better. Also a bit heavy on swift actions once bardic performance becomes one, though you can still perform as a move.

Bard // Witch

Basics: Med BAB, d8, Ref and Will, 6 skills+, full and 6-level casting, Int Cha

Bard // Wizard

Basics: Med BAB, d8, Ref and Will, 6 skills+, full and 6-level casting, Int Cha

I personally would go for Arcanist//Bard to get a little more synergy out of Charisma.

Bloodrager

Like the barbarian, the bloodrager is a strong martial class, tough and capable of massive damage in melee. It also works best with hybrid classes that enhance combat options while also providing some utility, but with the Mad Magic feat allowing free casting while bloodraging, charisma casters work particularly well. As a bonus, when you hit level 11 Mad Magic increases the DCs of all your spells.

Note that for the bloodrager, Mad Magic does not allow you to use spell-like abilities. And like the barbarian, psychic bloodragers still have to check with their GM about whether rage is considered a “hostile emotion effect” that would interfere with psychic components. The Id rager does explicitly prevent rage from interfering with your emotion spells (which may or may not imply anything about the base rage); otherwise it’s not a great archetype.

Loss of barbarian archetypes negatively affects some combinations, and it becomes MAD when combined with classes using Int or Wis.

Bloodrager // Brawler ***/*

Basics: Full BAB, d10, Fort and Ref, 4 skills, 4-level casting, physical Cha

A solid combination for adding more combat tricks to your bloodrager. Check out Stalwart and Improved Stalwart – Combat Expertise is great for the Brawler since you can fill in maneuver feats with Martial Flexibility. Consider Blood Conduit to add a bit more hurt to your maneuvers. Still a little shy on utility, but spellcasting gives you a few extra options.

Bloodrager // Cavalier

Basics: Full BAB, d10, Fort, 4 skills, casting

Bloodrager // Cleric ***/* (Elder Mythos Cultist ****)

Basics: Full BAB, d10, Fort and Will, 4 skills, full and 4-level casting, physical Wis Cha

A little demanding on the stats, but otherwise an excellent combat build with some support. Consider Crusader Cleric for extra feats, or Evangelist for extra buffing. If you don’t mind losing healing potential, Elder Mythos Cultist has better stat synergy and the Aberrant Bloodline is both thematic and supports a reach style.

Bloodrager // Druid **/* (Feyspeaker ****)

Basics: Full BAB, d10, Fort and Will, 6/4 skills, full casting and 4-level casting, physical Wis Cha

Normally the stat requirements spread this one a little thin, but Feyspeaker makes a big difference. Wild Shape delay an issue?

Bloodrager // Fighter

Basics: Full BAB, d10, Fort, 4 skills, casting

Bloodrager // Gunslinger * (Urban Bloodrager **)

Basics: Full BAB, d10, Fort and Ref, 4 skills, 4-level casting, Dex Wis Cha

You need the Dex rage for this to work at all, and even then it's a little lacklustre since many of the bloodline powers and feats are geared more towards melee combat. Switch hitting stretches your resources either with feats or with stats, and you're lacking in both magical and spell utility. You can do some fun stuff with Arcane if you have Snap Shot, though. Iron Will as a bloodline feat is a bonus.

Bloodrager // Hunter ***/*

Basics: Full BAB, d10, Fort and Ref, 6 skills, 6- and 4-level casting, physical Wis Cha

The Barbarian//Hunter gets more use out of Greater Ferocious Mount, and the extra stat requirements are not fantastic.

Bloodrager // Inquisitor ***/*

Basics: Full BAB, d10, Fort and Will, 6 skills+, 6- and 4-level casting, physical Wis Cha

Stats are stretched a little thin here, but if you can make it work this is very nice. Inquisitor's combat buffs help you pile on the hurt, and you still have a good range of utility potential including scouting, tracking, social and knowledge skills. Your Intimidate can be absolutely devastating. Primalist // Sacred Huntmaster gives you access to a mount with Amplified Rage, though you'll have fewer rage powers to share than the Barbarian.

Bloodrager // Investigator **/**

Basics: Full BAB, d10, all saves, 6 skills+, 6- and 4-level casting, physical Int Cha

If you can use Studied Combat while Bloodraging this is a strong albeit a little MAD combination with highly damaging melee abilities and a good selection of utility. If you can't, this is not exciting.

Bloodrager // Magus ***

Basics: Full BAB, d10, Fort and Will, 4 skills, 6- and 4-level casting, physical Int Cha

Mad Magic makes this better than Barbarian//Magus, but the requirement for Int and Cha is a bit steep. To make better use of the strength bonus, recommend grabbing a one-handed weapon that you can also two-hand for extra damage when not using Spell Combat. Alternatively, take Urban Bloodrager for a Dex rage.

Bloodrager//Kineticist */****

Basics: Full BAB, d10, Fort and Ref, 4 skills, pseudo-casting, physical Cha

Like the barbarian, the bloodrager can't use spell-like abilities when raging. If you can convince your GM to let Mad Magic apply to your blasts this goes all the way to purple, thanks to the Con boost while raging.

Bloodrager // Monk ****

Basics: Full BAB, d10, all saves+/Fort and Ref+, 4 skills, 4-level casting, physical Wis Cha

Very good melee and self-buffing, potential for debuffing, light on party support and utility. No alignment restriction and less value for rage cycling mean you have more archetype options than just the martial artist. Unchained is notable for adding 1.5 Str when flurrying two-handed, and for giving you good mobility without having to trade bloodline powers for Beast Totem, though your Will save drops. Add Scaled Fist for Cha synergy. Sohei pairs well with Bloodrider. Alternatively, you could also take Master of Many Styles, wear armour, and suppress your monk fast movement. Kata Master is notable for giving you some Cha-based swashbuckler tricks in exchange for nothing significant. On the Bloodrager side, Blood Conduit is a good archetype due to maneuver synergy, especially if you keep fast movement on the monk end. Consider spelleater or untouchable if you can't afford 14 Cha. Skip Bloody-Knuckle Rowdy.

Bloodrager // Medium ****

Basics: Full BAB, d10, Fort and Will, 4 skills, two 4-level casting, physical and Cha

A solid and thematic combination. Champion grants nice, reliable offensive power; the Guardian's defensive features are more useful for a spelleater or steelblood bloodrager since the DR will not overlap and you can deal with heavy armour spell failure. The medium spell list and minor class features add a bit of magical utility to the bloodrager's combat-focused list.

Bloodrager // Mesmerist ***/*

Basics: Full BAB, d10, all saves, 6 skills, 6- and 4-level casting, physical and Cha

Like the barbarian, this gets an extra boost if Hypnotizing Stare, which requires “focus” is compatible with bloodrage, which doesn't allow “patience and concentration.” If so, you get exceptional self-buffing and debuffing action economy with your magic tantrums, forcing opponents to wither before you. Charisma synergy and easier access to Mad Magic puts this a touch above Barbarian//Mesmerist.

Bloodrager // Oracle *****

Basics: Full BAB, d10, Fort and Will, 4 skills, full and 4-level casting, physical Cha

Pairing great combat abilities with a full casting list rich in self-buffs and which complements your bloodrager casting stat? Excellent choice. Once greater bloodrage kicks in rage cycling comes with a cost, but Lame Curse is still a good idea, especially for a Primalist with per/rage abilities. Bloodrager casting complements the Oracle list nicely with goodies like Shield, and you get more out of a Cha-focused build (Lore/Lunar/Nature) than the barbarian. Once again, Lunar is great for natural weapons.

Bloodrager // Occultist ***

Basics: Full BAB, d10, Fort and Will, 4 skills, 6-level and 4-level casting, physical Int Cha

You get rage, self-buffs, and utility. On the other hand, you need two mental stats.

Recommend transmutation for offence (and fly), illusion for miss chance defences, divination for utility, conjuration for healing and teleportation, and evocation for a backup ranged blast. Check if your GM will let you use focus powers during a rage. As supernatural abilities they don't require concentration mechanically, but some stricter GMs might decide that expending “mental focus” requires concentration thematically. Mad Magic does not, RAW, help with this. This would make the evocation school and certain focus powers such as danger sense or side step much less useful.

Bloodrager // (Anti ***)Paladin ****

Basics: Full BAB, d10, Fort and Will+, 4 skills, casting

No alignment restrictions means you can go for paladin and the great durability that implies. Primalist gives you access to Lesser Celestial Totem to boost your healing, and the fatigue mercy is great to have if you need to rage cycle. You're low on out of combat utility but at least the bloodrager brings a few extra skill points to the table. Antipaladin is less fantastic but still good. Consider Steelblood for heavy armour.

Bloodrager // Psychic ***

Basics: Full BAB, d10, Fort and Will, 4 skills, full and 4-level casting, physical Int Cha

Aside from MAD, a decent warrior-mage. The psychic gives you access to a greater range of buffs than bloodrager alone, and adds a lot of more subtle mental magic, though you'll want to avoid anything with DCs. The Pain discipline is notable for its limited Lay on Hands (which allows fatigue removal and pairs well with the Lesser Celestial Totem for significant healing) and is a good thematic fit.

Bloodrager // Ranger ***

Basics: Full BAB, d10, Fort and Ref, 6 skills, two 4-level casting, physical Wis Cha

Strong melee character or switch-hitter with decent utility. Rage + Str-based TWF is a good combo. Barbarian//Ranger is marginally better thanks to not needing the second mental stat.

Bloodrager // Rogue ***

Basics: Full BAB, d10, Fort and Ref, 8 skills, 4-level casting, physical Cha

The bloodrager shores up the rogue's weaknessess – poor accuracy and fragility – while the rogue gives the bloodrager more out of combat ability, a ref save, and sneak attack for a nice damage boost. If you're going primalist with the beast totem, consider scout rogue archetype to sneak attack on a pounce.

Bloodrager // Skald

Basics: Full BAB, d10, Fort and Ref, 4 skills, casting

Bloodrager //  Slayer ***

Basics: Full BAB, d10, Fort and Ref, 6 skills, 4-level casting, physical Int Cha

Strong combat skills, good utility. Rage + Str-based TWF is a good combo. Also a little less invested in sneak-attack than bloodrager//rogue.

Bloodrager // Sorcerer ***

Basics: Full BAB, d10, Fort and Will, 4 skills, full and 4-level casting, physical Cha

Has some issues with arcane spell failure and action economy, but works pretty well if you can keep your casting mostly to utility spells and long-duration buffs, or go for a reach build. At higher levels you can throw a few quickened spells into the mix. Mad Magic is a no-brainer. Bloodlines take some thought as they need to match. Abyssal is notable – the first level claws are redundant but strength of the abyss is great on a bloodrager and you can use sorcerer spells like mirror image or displacement to cover for the Abyssal bloodrager's terrible AC. Aberrant is great for reach builds - in theory the reach increases stack, though Unusual Anatomy doesn’t. Overlapping bloodlines can trade out these abilities using primalist bloodrager or crossblooded (sorcerer is usually a better deal for crossblooded). The feat lists are almost identical so it's worth expanding them with crossblooded or blood conduit.

Bloodrager//Spiritualist

Basics: Full BAB, d10, Fort and Will, 4 skills, 6- and 4-level casting, physical & Cha

Ectoplasmacist & Aberrant bloodrager for massive reach?

Bloodrager // Summoner ***

Basics: Full BAB, d10, Fort and Will, 4 skills, 6- and 4-level casting, physical Cha

Strong melee with a side serving of charisma-based casting, though you need to stick with light armour. If you go synthesist you can add goodies like pounce without giving up on your bloodline powers, but have to skip the armour entirely. Ferocious Mount (via Primalist) is a nice buff, though unlike Barbarian//Summoner you probably don't have enough rage powers for Greater Ferocious Mount to be worth it.

Bloodrager // Swashbuckler * (Urban Bloodrager ***)

Basics: Full BAB, d10, Fort and Ref, 4 skills, 4-level casting, Dex Con Cha

If you don't get Dex rage, there's no point, but with your stats pointing in the right direction this can be pretty effective. You're nice and mobile (and eligible for pounce) and have some good defense options between decent AC, parry, and bloodline abilities - though unfortunately no DR or Con bonus. Switch hitting is possible, but out of combat utility is not great.

Bloodrager // Warpriest ***/*

Basics: Full BAB, d10, Fort and Will, 4 skills, 6-and 4-level casting, physical Wis Cha

Packs a heck of a wallop. You have fewer options for ranged combat than the Barbarian//Warpriest, but Greater Bloodrage (and possibly Arcane Bloodrage) plus easier access to Mad Magic for Fervour gives you better action economy for self-buffing. Consider Steelblood to cast bloodrager spells in heavy armour – in which case also consider adamantine full plate, when you can afford it, to replace your DR. Alternatively, Spelleater is handy if you don't want to invest in the Cha to actually cast your bloodrager spells.

A destined steel blooded bloodrager/ warpriest. The most protected warrior of luck ever. Scaling luck bonus to saves, armor class, attack rolls, and damage. Have access to all the good low level spells arcane and divine. Full bab and caster level, swift action buffing, and no spell failure in full plate. Rage... 
Faster movement in full plate. 
Pick up the feat mad magic and you can cast all your spells in a rage. Pick up the trait fates favored all your luck bonuses go up by one. 
Storywise worship a war God and rage makes sense. 
You are a holy/unholy avenger of your deity. Stat wise a wis 16 cha 14 allows you to cast all your spells. 
Plus you get enough feats to make almost any combat style viable. 
Any weapon can be viable in your hands with the sacred weapon bonus. 
If you can vmc too go magus for a very powerful magical warrior. 

Bloodrager // Witch *** (Scarred Witch Doctor ****)

Basics: Full BAB, d10, Fort and Will, 4 skills, casting

Bloodrager // Wizard **

Basics: Full BAB, d10, Fort and Will, 4 skills, casting

Brawler

Brawlers get a large number of attacks with unarmed strikes, close, or monk weapons and can have good AC with light armour and a shield, losing no attack potential for the latter thanks to the way their Flurry works. Brawlers are also among the most flexible combatants in the game, thanks to – what else? - Martial Flexibility. This ability lets you pick up circumstantially useful feats as needed. They benefit from accuracy bonuses, damage bonuses, a good will save, out of combat utility, and any abilities that help them full attack more often due to dependence on Flurry.

If you don't want to have to keep track of all those combat feats, Mutagenic Mauler and Snakebite Striker gives you worthwhile passive damage boosts instead, plus a few minor abilities. Snakebite is especially good when your other class gives you a pet to flank with. Shield Champion is a really neat build for switch-hitting; the Brawler is otherwise weak at ranged combat, though you can do OK with shuriken or wushu darts in a pinch, and the Winding Path Renegade (Wind) gives you an extra bit of range.

Compared to the similar Monk, the Brawler's main advantages for gestalt are (1) Martial Flexibility (2) not needing Wis (3) ability to use armour and shields. It's also very good at pulling out combat maneuvers very effectively when needed, compared to the maneuver archetypes for monk (maneuver master and tetori) which are severely hampered when their speciality maneuvers become impractical. The Monk, depending on the build, can get better maneuverability, better defenses against non-weapon attacks, better ranged damage, and of course mystical powers. Monks tend to be better than Brawlers for characters that are overall Wis-based or that want combat to be a secondary role to casting.

Brawler // Cavalier (Snakebite Striker, Daring Champion)

Basics: Full BAB, d10, Fort and Ref, 4 skills, no casting, physical (Cha optional)

The usual mounted lance charge is really hard to pull off with the weapons the Brawler uses. You're better off using your mount as a flanking partner, especially with Snakebite Striker; your teamwork feats are handy with this. Daring Champion has better combat style synergy if you like Martial Flexibility; just snag a light piercing close or monk weapon and a buckler. Since Flurry doesn't actually use two weapons, it does as written work with Precise Strike. Accuracy is a little low, but my goodness the damage.

Brawler // Cleric

Basics: Full BAB, d10, all saves, 4 skills, full casting, physical Wis

Solid choice for a combat cleric. OK for bad punching, though Monk//Cleric gives you more out of the high Wis you need for debuffing and supports a greater range of builds.

Brawler // Druid (Goliath, Nature Fang)

Basics: Full BAB, d10, all saves, 4 skills, full casting, physical Wis

You can't use Feral Combat Training with the Brawler's Flurry, so that's one major point against this build. You can technically unarmed strike as a bear, but this is much more effective fighting in humanoid shape, with Goliath or Nature Fang. The druid's buffs are very useful to the Brawler, and the Goliath's size increases work especially well with the Brawler's big weapon dice. Lemeres suggests pairing Goliath Druid with Outslug Style for "I am punching you from the next town over." See also: Monk//Druid.

Brawler // Fighter (Viking/Shield Champion)

Basics: Full BAB, d10, Fort and Ref, 4 skills, no casting, physical

Too much overlap to be really good – do you really need that many combat feats? You'll also want to take a fighter archetype that gets rid of armour training since the brawler prefers light armour – the unarmed fighter, brawler, free hand fighter, and two weapon warrior are worth a look. Viking and shielded fighter work well with shield champion (brawler), and viking has the additional advantage that you can trade excess combat feats for rage powers. Lack of a strong will save or out of combat abilities is a major downside.

Brawler // Gunslinger

Basics: Full BAB, d10, Fort and Ref, 4 skills, no casting, physical Wis

You're working with two incompatible combat styles and no other bonuses of note.

Brawler // Hunter

Basics: Full BAB, d10, Fort and Ref, 6 skills, 6-level casting, physical Wis
Remember how I said Snakebite Striker works well with a pet for flanking? Well, Hunters get a pet AND teamwork feats for even better flanking. Base class and other archetypes also work well as a Feral Hunter.

Brawler // Inquisitor

Basics: Full BAB, d10, all saves, 6 skills+, 6-level casting, physical Wis

Powerful and versatile in and out of combat. Brawler's Flurry with a single bane weapon is great, judgment or other buffs improve accuracy, and you get a good selection of bonus feats for fun stuff. Remember to consider teamwork feats when using martial flexibility! You also have a good selection of utility spells and skills. Consider Snakebite Striker//Sacred Huntmaster or Wild Child//Sacred Slayer for sneak attacking with a flanking pet.

Brawler // Investigator

Basics: Full BAB, d10, all saves, 6 skills+, 6-level casting, physical Int

Remember how Sherlock Holmes liked himself some fisticuffs? It is really handy for a detective to be able to walk around fully armed without a weapon, and to restrain suspects without killing them. It's also very effective in this combination. Studied Combat, Studied Strike, and the Weapon Training talent are great accuracy and damage boosters – Brawler's Flurry will hit and hit hard. Combat Expertise, which opens you up to take maneuver feats, allows you to trade excess accuracy for defense. Quick Study is a good 5th level Investigator talent; you are not heavy on swift actions. You're not hurting for utility, either, with extracts, lots of skill points, every skill except Fly and Survival on your combined class list, and miscellaneous talents.

Brawler // Kineticist

Basics: Full BAB, d10, Fort and Ref, 4 skills, pseudo-casting, physical

Kinetic blasts don't generally work with the Brawler's style, but you can use Kinetic Fist and elemental overflow for a modest offensive bonus with UAS (mostly useful after level 5, when infusion specialization lets you use Kinetic Fist without burn). Having a ranged blasting option is also handy, and depending on element you can add significant defense, control, or utility options. Elemental Ascetic reduces the burn for Kinetic Fist, but takes away most of your ranged options and swaps your elemental defense for a monk's unarmoured AC. I'd use it only if you can afford a good Wis and only for a kinetic element that has a weak elemental defense and ranged options that don't rely on attack rolls: air, fire, and void.

Brawler // Magus

Basics: Full BAB, d10, all saves, 4 skills, casting

Brawler's Flurry doesn't work with Spell Combat, and weapons in the close weapon group aren't the best choices for the Magus.  If you want Martial Flexibility, take Martial Master Fighter//Magus.

Brawler//Medium

Basics: Full BAB, d10, all saves, 4 skills, partial casting, physical Cha

The champion's main powers don't work with flurry, but the static damage bonus and spirit surge are good and the ability to give up your extra flurry attacks for a semi-pounce is useful if you don't want to take Pummeling Style.

Brawler // Mesmerist

Basics: Full BAB, d10, all saves, 6 skills, 6-level casting, physical Cha

Lots of physical and mental control options. Consider Brawler//Bard since buffing is a bit easier on the stats than debuffing.

Brawler // Monk

Basics: Full BAB, d10, all saves/Fort and Ref, 4 skills, no casting, physical Wis

There's a lot of overlap here, but you can reduce it by trading out flurry. Master of Many Styles and Maneuver Master are at the top of my list; Brawler//MoMS works especially well with Outslug Style and optionally Ascetic Style. Alternatively if you like Unchained Monk's mobility, Strangler gives you very effective grappling abilities with very little lost. Note that due to odd writing you'll have to actually take Improved Grapple, likely as your 1st level monk bonus feat. Overall, the combo gives you lots of options in melee, but drastically drops in usefulness at range or out of combat.

Brawler // Occultist

Basics: Full BAB, d10, all saves, 4 skills, 6-level casting, physical Int

Transmutation implement is a must for accuracy & damage boosts. On top of the juicy stat bonuses, Legacy Weapon is great with Flurry (note: Bane). Enlarge Person is fantastic for increasing damage dice, and you can take it as a focus power or spell. After that, you can improve defence and utility to taste with abjuration, divination, and illusion. Conjuration is also worth considering at levels 6 or 10 for Side Step, or earlier if your group needs a secondary healer. It's also got the most painless resonant power to give up with Haunt Channeller – followed by Illusion.

Brawler // Oracle

Basics: Full BAB, d10, all saves, 4 skills, full casting, physical Cha

Well-balanced character for combat and support. Cha-to-AC works well here as a strength-based fighter wearing light armour, and the animal companion from Lunar or Nature is nice with Snakebite Striker. Other notable options include demoralizing (Intimidate) and Revelation Strike. Alternatively, Dance of Blades from Metal Mystery works nicely with Outslug Style when using a metal close weapon, like the emei piercer or tri bladed katar.

Brawler // (Anti)Paladin

Basics: Full BAB, d10, all saves+, 4 skills, 4-level casting, physical Cha

Great melee combatant with potential for support and control. Flurry works really nicely with Smite's big bonuses. Shield Champion//Paladin is the gestalt Captain America build, and the ranged flexibility is nice. Champion of Irori (Enlightened Paladin) is also worth a look, particularly if you want to use unarmed strikes and your campaign isn't expected to feature a lot of evil enemies. The antipaladin's debuffs are less useful than the paladin's support, healing, and immunities, but it's still a pretty punishing match.

Brawler // Psychic

Basics: Full BAB, d10, all saves, 4 skills, full casting, physical Int and Wis or Cha

Phrenic Strike is a very useful amplification because it lets you deliver a touch spell with an  UAS in the same round as you cast it, instead of needing to carry a charge.

Brawler // Ranger

Basics: Full BAB, d10, Fort and Ref, 6 skills, 4-level casting, physical Wis

TWF fighting style is less useful since Brawler's Flurry duplicates the main line and Double Slice; You can still pick up Quick Draw, Two-Weapon Defence, and Two-Weapon Rend, but you're better off taking archery style for thrown weapons. Weapon and Shield is an excellent style for a Shield Champion, though note that if you take Shield Master as a combat style feat at level 6 it's redundant with the Brawler's feat at level 11. Retraining is a good option if available since you get early access without giving up a feat.

Brawler // Rogue

Basics: Full BAB, d10, Fort and Ref, 8 skills, no casting, physical

Flurry and Sneak Attack gives you high damage potential, but poor accuracy is an issue; this makes Mutagenic Mauler particularly attractive. Also consider Wild Child for the flanking partner, and ninja for supernatural tricks. Consider pairing Brawler with Archaelogist Bard, Vivisectionist Alchemist, or Investigator for a more versatile character with better self-buffing potential.

Brawler //  Skald

Basics: Full BAB, d10, all saves, 4 skills, 6-level casting, physical Cha

Brawler // Slayer

Basics: Full BAB, d10, Fort and Ref, 6 skills, no casting, physical Int

High damage potential with flurry + sneak attack, plus an accuracy booster! Combat style feats are best spent on throwing – or just skip them and grab more utility options. Alternatively, Weapon and Shield works well for a shield champion, especially if you can retrain Shield Master when it's duplicated at level 11.

Brawler // Sorcerer

Basics: Full BAB, d10, all saves, 4 skills, full casting, physical Cha

Multi-touch spells are pretty nasty when delivered using a flurry of unarmed strikes, the brawler can easily handle melee combat unarmoured, and some bloodlines like Abyssal, Infernal (Pit-Touched), or Orc are really nice for a melee character. Buff spells like Shield or Mirror Image are also great.

Brawler // Spiritualist

Basics: Full BAB, d10, all saves, 4 skills, 6-level casting, physical Wis

Brawler // Summoner

Basics: Full BAB, d10, all saves, 4 skills, 6-level casting, physical Cha

Adding a bit of magical versatility to a solid combatant is never a bad call. Both classes favour light armour, so that's a plus. Snakebite Striker likes the flanking partner.

Brawler // Swashbuckler

Basics: Full BAB, d10, Fort and Ref, 4 skills, no casting, Dex Cha

Not a lot of synergy, but you can at least use both styles together if you take a piercing weapon in the close weapon group, like the fighting fan or emei piercer – and if your GM agrees that since brawler's flurry only actually needs one weapon to attack it doesn't prevent you from using precise strike.

Brawler // Warpriest (Arsenal Chaplain)

Basics: Full BAB, d10, all saves, 4 skills, 6-level casting, physical Wis

Solid self-buffing ability, good action economy, and some feats to play with. Arsenal Chaplain is a great pick since the Brawler continues to advance your weapon damage dice. Most Brawlers don't get much out of Sacred Fist, but it works well with Strangler.

Brawler // Witch (White Haired Witch, Scarred Witch Doctor)

Basics: Full BAB, d10, all saves, 4 skills, casting

Brawler // Wizard

Basics: Full BAB, d10, all saves, 4 skills, full casting, physical Int

Not a lot of synergy, but extremely versatile.

Cavalier

The cavalier is particularly poorly suited to gestalt with arcane casters.

Cavalier // Cleric (Elder Mythos Cultist)

Basics: Full BAB, d10, Fort and Will, 4 skills, full casting, physical Wis

Cavalier // Druid

Basics: Full BAB, d10, Fort and Will, 4 skills, casting

Reasonably well-rounded combination. Use druid for utility and longer-duration pre-buffs like Barkskin and Greater Magic Fang, then cavalier about in combat. Consider Urban Druid or Nature Fang if you want to play a proper mounted cavalier, since wild shape isn't as useful in that case. Consider taking a domain as a druid instead of duplicating the animal companion – but keep in mind that means you can't Share Spells with druid spells. Alternatively if you'd like a backup firearm and can justify the flavour, Musketeer drops the cavalier mount, but none of the mounted combat abilities.

Cavalier // Fighter

Basics: Full BAB, d10, Fort, 4 skills, casting

Cavalier // Gunslinger

Basics: Full BAB, d10, Fort and Ref, 4 skills, casting

Cavalier // Hunter (Musketeer) (Huntmaster)

Basics: Full BAB, d10, Fort and Ref, 6 skills, 6-level casting, physical Wis

Musketeer gives up the duplicate mount for a decent ranged backup, but leaves the charging abilities alone and is even compatible with Gendarme. The Huntmaster is fun and thematic if you don't mind a lot of pets – use the Hunter's companion for your mount and then take a couple dogs or birds as hunting beasts.

Cavalier // Inquisitor

Basics: Full BAB, d10, Fort and Will, 6 skills+, casting, physical Wis

Cavalier // Investigator

Basics: Full BAB, d10, all saves, 6 skills+, 6-level casting, physical Int

It takes a round to set up, but Challenge + Studied Combat gives you massive damage bonuses (up to 2.5x level with Daring Champion's precise strike) as well as an accuracy boost. Combine them with a lance charge and Sudden Strike and things just die.

Daring Champion Cavalier with Order of the Dragon, there's a Gestalt option for an Investigator. Play Human, grab Fencing Grace at level 1, and put a single Feat into Extra Panache when you hit 5th, and you're good to go. +2 and 1/2 my level to damage and +3/4 my level on to-hit? Why yes, thank you, that sounds lovely. All good Saves and awesome skills as well? Why thank you! It's a fun, thematic, build. You even get Tactician on an Int character.

Cavalier//Kineticist

Basics: Full BAB, d10,  Fort and Ref, 4 skills, casting

Cavalier // Magus (Daring Champion)

Basics: Full BAB, d10, Fort and Will, 4 skills, casting

While normally not completely incompatible, mounted charges and spellstrike aren't exactly synergistic. The daring champion archetype, however, is a great pair for a finesse magus.

Cavalier//Medium

Basics: Full BAB, d10, Fort and Will, 4 skills, casting

Cavalier//Mesmerist

Basics: Full BAB, d10, all saves, 6 skills, 6-level casting, physical Cha

A thematic combination that works best when able to single out a particular opponent.

Cavalier // Monk (Sohei, Daring Champion)

Basics: Full BAB, d10, all saves/Fort and Will, 4 skills, no casting, physical Wis

Normally the monk doesn't synergize well with the cavalier. However the Sohei's light armour and mount-enhancing abilities (sans mount) make this a good pair. At 6th level, take weapon training (spears) and not only do you get attack and damage bonuses with the lance but you get to flurry with it when not charging. Mounted Skirmisher lets you lance flurry when moving, though unfortunately not while charging. I'd say Order of the Sword is a good choice, coupled with Beast Rider. You can full attack from the back of your mount at level 1, and eventually your mount can pounce. Try to avoid charisma-dependent order abilities to reduce MAD. Biggest downside is lack of utility thanks to mediocre skills and no casting. Daring Champion is also not a bad choice thanks to adding massive static damage bonuses to flurry. It works with Sohei for a switch-hitting thrown weapon build. (Unchained, Weapon Adept?) Order of the Eastern Star gives you a welcome boost to attacks, DR, and saves when you have Combat Reflexes (and probably Crane Style) going. Alternatively, you could get Pummeling Style and laugh at any and all DR. If you're really determined, you could pick up those Chakra feats.

Cavalier//Occultist

Basics: Full BAB, d10, Fort and Will, 4 skills, 6-level casting

Cavalier // Oracle

Basics: Full BAB, d10, Fort and Will, 4 skills, full casting

Cavalier // (Anti)Paladin

Basics: Full BAB, d10, Fort and Will+, 4 skills, 4-level casting

Cavalier//Psychic

Basics: Full BAB, d10, Fort and Will, 4 skills, full casting, physical and Int or Wis and Cha

Cavalier // Ranger

Basics: Full BAB, d10, Fort and Ref, 6 skills, casting

Cavalier // Rogue (Scout)

Basics: Full BAB, d10, Fort and Ref, 8 skills, casting

Combo Rogue (Scout archetype) with Cavalier. Once you get to level 8, you get all the power of a Cavalier's Charge, plus every charge is a Sneak Attack.

Cavalier // Skald

Basics: Full BAB, d10, Fort and Will, 4 skills, casting

Cavalier // Slayer

Basics: Full BAB, d10, Fort and Ref, 6 skills, no casting, physical Int

Cavalier // Sorcerer (Daring Champion)

Basics: Full BAB, d10, Fort and Will, 4 skills, casting

The cavalier is usually reliant on heavy armour and lance combat doesn't lend itself well to the sorcerer's strengths. The Daring Champion is a step up because it supports light or no armour and has a charisma-based panache ability – though finesse is a mixed blessing since it means you can't take advantage of the usual strength-based melee bloodlines like Orc or Abyssal.

Cavalier//Spiritualist

Basics: Full BAB, d10, Fort and Will, 4 skills, casting

Cavalier // Summoner

Basics: Full BAB, d10, Fort and Will, 4 skills, casting

The eidolon can serve as an extra-powerful mount (in which case strongly consider Daring Champion or Musketeer on the cavalier side to get rid of the duplicate) or you can keep the cavalier's mount and play around with the eidolon a little more. Note that Order of the Sword adds your mount's Str to your damage, which can be a big deal if you have a well-muscled eidolon mount.

Cavalier // Swashbuckler

Basics: Full BAB, d10, Fort and Ref, 4 skills, casting

Take Daring Champion and gestalt it with something else, like bard, ninja, or paladin.

the swashbuckler/samurai is an interesting concept but you end up with only 4 skill points (which isn't a dealbreaker but is kind of low for gestalt), a poor will save (which you should always try to avoid), and no casting ability... you might be better off going swashbuckler/kensai or swordsaint/arcane duelist- both could give you a lot of the same feel but with all good saves and 6 level casting (though if you want a Dex build the swordsaint/arcane duelist would either need a 1 level dip in swashbuckler or a dueling sword and weapon finesse/slashing grace).

Cavalier // Warpriest

Basics: Full BAB, d10, Fort and Will, 4 skills, 6-level casting, physical Wis

Cavalier // Witch

Basics: Full BAB, d10, Fort and Will, 4 skills, casting

Cavalier // Wizard

Basics: Full BAB, d10, Fort and Will, 4 skills, casting

Cleric

This powerful but somewhat bland caster can be gestalted most effectively by playing to the main types of cleric build. It mostly suffers from lack of skill points. If your other class has only 2 skill points, I recommend either the Roaming Exorcist or Herald Caller (but not Cloistered Cleric) archetypes for 4 skill points, or Cardinal for 6. The Cardinal works best with martial classes that restore the BAB and armour proficiencies (in which case you're trading a domain and spontaneous cures for 4 skill points and some class skills).

Combat: combine cleric with a full-BAB class, ideally one that doesn't use Int or Cha. Use cleric buffs to improve your own combat ability; check out the Strength or Growth domains. You can also cover healing out of combat, and have options to buff your allies or summon things. Herald Caller is handy for the latter – your combat half should provide the armour proficiencies you need anyway. Avoid enemy-targeting spells since you probably won't have a high enough Wis to deal with saves and SR. Tends to be a well-balanced gestalt.

Casting: combine cleric with another casting class, ideally one that also uses Wisdom, for increased versatility and possibly increased durability. This build is usually the best positioned for debuffing and controlling undead in addition to having support and summoning options.

Reach: use your standard actions to cast and a reach weapon to make attacks of opportunity. While this build requires heavy investment in feats and stats (you need better Dex than most combat clerics) it pays off in excellent action economy. This build can work when paired with either martial or casting classes, but it's especially important that the other class not use Int and Cha, and bonus feats or reach-enhancing abilities are extra welcome. I also like this build when combining clerics with classes that, like clerics, have both melee-focused and casting abilities, like Inquisitor or Druid. Using full-BAB AoO instead of iterative attacks can make up for having only an average BAB progression.

It's also notable that while clerics are MAD enough that they often end up with a low or middling Cha, they do have some useful Cha-dependent features that you should look into if your second class uses Cha. Channeling can be used not only to restore HP but grant buffs (eg through variant channeling) or remove conditions (Merciful Healer archetype), and with the Quick Channel feat you can Channel as a move action, which is very nice action economy for a caster cleric. The Evangelist archetype gives you a limited bardic performance – it's a generally worthwhile archetype that gets better with a higher Cha for more rounds/day. Controlling Undead (Undead Lord archetype recommended but optional) is also much improved by a higher Cha, since the Command Undead feat grants a Cha-based save to your prospective minions.

Alternatively, if you want to really go Cha-focused, consider the Elder Mythos Cultist. This archetype switches your casting stat to Cha and lets you use Cha for Will saves instead of Wis, but comes with limitations: vulnerability to insanity, restricted deity and domain choices and CN/CE alignment. You also trade Channel Energy for a more universally damaging Channel the Void effect, and lose spontaneous casting. Overall the restrictions on domains and loss of spontaneous casting and Channel make this a sub-par healer and ineffective undead controller. However, it can still excel at debuffing (including “bad touch”), summoning, and melee or ranged combat.

The Sacred Attendant gives you a small AC bonus if your other class doesn't wear armour.

Cleric // Druid

Basics: Med BAB, d8, Fort and Will, 4 skills, two full casting, physical Wis Cha

This nature priest gets a very nice range of spells with casting stat synergy.  You should be able to take domains from both classes (though remember you still only prepare each class's domain spells in their own domain slots). Good candidate for a reach build, though it also works as a focused caster. Supernaturalist Druid // Herald Caller has good summoning synergy. If you want a primarily combat build, look at Cleric//Ranger, or at least try combining Inquisitor or Warpriest with Druid, or Hunter with Cleric, for easier buffing. A charisma-focused build is also possible with Feyspeaker//Elder Mythos Cultist. It’s not a particularly good or thematic combination, but you get extra skills without giving up either BAB or medium armour.

Cleric // Fighter

Basics: Full BAB, d10, Fort and Will, 2 skills, full casting, physical Wis Cha

Effective in a variety of combat styles. The bonus feats and lack of additional stat requirements are also useful for a reach build; plus, armour training lets you wear heavy armour while still benefiting from an above-average dex. Recommend an archetype with more skills: Lore Warden, Roaming Exorcist, Herald Caller, or Cardinal.

Cleric // Gunslinger

Basics: Full BAB, d10, all saves, 4 skills, full casting,  Dex Wis Cha

Definitely a combat cleric, but you should also be able to afford the Wis for good save DCs when you want them, and possibly even a solid Cha for channeling.

Cleric // Hunter

Basics: Med BAB, d8, all saves, 6 skills, full and 6-level casting, physical Wis Cha

Slower progression of Druid offensive spells and medium BAB means this works best as primarily support/healer character. However, Animal Focus and teamwork feats do give you a leg up on weapons combat, whether with a reach build (highly recommended), as a secondary role, or even in a more combat-focused build (preferably melee to make the most of your teamwork feats). Good utility, especially for scouting.

Cleric // Inquisitor

Basics: Med BAB, d8, Fort and Will, 6 skills+, full and 6-level casting, physical Wis Cha

Priest and more priest. You can rely on your cleric's spontaneous casting of cure spells, use your inquisitor list for staples (like Divine Favour) or unique spells (Blistering Invective), and then fill out your cleric list with whatever else you want, including situational spells (Negate Poison, Banishment). While medium BAB is disappointing for gestalt, judgment and other buffs make weapons combat a viable option. Alternatively Relic Hunter or Monster Tactician improve magical versatility. The mix of casting and combat overall plays similarly to a non-gestalt cleric but with expanded options – including strong skills.

Cleric // Investigator

Basics: Med BAB, d8, all saves, 6 skills+, full and 6-level casting, physical Wis Int Cha

I prefer the Cleric//Inquisitor but if you've got good stats to work with, this has some things to recommend it: a strong Ref save, a more potent (if less versatile) primary combat buff, and the ability to pass out infusions of Shield or polymorph buffs like delicious candy.

Cleric // Kineticist

Basics: Med BAB, d8, all saves, 4 skills, full casting, Con Dex Wis

Kineticist has better offensive options, so I'd recommend focusing on those and using Cleric mostly for extra support. Divine Favour is more useful when making multiple attacks via Kinetic Blade or Flurry of Blasts. You might consider Elemental Ascetic for a bad punch build – and only for a bad punch build, because otherwise it's not worth it. Note however you don't get Wis to AC until level 2, which is dangerous. As always, Ecclesitheurge is a good archetype for gestalt clerics who don't wear armour.

Cleric // Magus

Basics: Med BAB, d8, Fort and Will, 4 skills, full and 6-level casting, physical Int Wis

This is another MAD combination for the cleric, and the basics are pretty poor. You can land some pretty punishing spellstrikes with Broad Study, though – try rolling a crit for Harm.

Cleric // Medium (Elder Mythos Cultist or Spirit Channeler)

Basics: Med BAB, d8, Fort and Will, 4 skills, full and partial casting, Wis Cha physical?

The hierophant doesn't add much since you already have the ability to pick new spells from the cleric list day-to-day and the ability to channel energy. You need champion spirit, cleric buffs, and a good stat spread to be competitive in combat. Elder Mythos Cultist gives you stat synergy - which could make for a serviceable reach build. Voice of the Void is thematic as a pair for Cultist on the Medium side. You could also try (Rivethun) Spirit Channeler to switch your Medium stat to Wis, but that also makes significant changes to how your spirits work. Overall I recommend Oracle//Medium instead for better stat synergy and better use of the hierophant – or pick Cleric//Inquisitor or Ranger for a more synergistic way to add utility.

Cleric // Mesmerist

Basics: Med BAB, d8, all saves, 6 skills, full and 6-level casting, Wis Cha

A real cult leader (archetype optional), nice and durable with a variety of support, debuff, and utility options.

Cleric // Monk

Basics: Med/Full BAB, d8/d10, all saves, 4 skills, full casting, physical Wis

Works wonderfully for many flavours of cleric. You can make an excellent SAD support or bad touch/punching build with Sensei (and optionally Ki Mystic). Sohei with Weapon Training (polearms) makes a good reach build, though it takes a few levels to pull together; the initiative bonus is handy for a caster, but skip armour. For a more combat-focused build with secondary support, go Zen Archer or Unchained. Note that Unchained can also make a pretty strong and very mobile bad touch build, though it's more MAD unless you pick up Guided Hand for your unarmed strike. Crusader's Flurry is another feat to keep in mind to open up weapon choices, but note that the Sensei doesn't qualify and the feat may not qualify a weapon for Ascetic Style (monk weapon quality =/= monk weapon group – check with your GM). Panther Style is also worth considering if you're going to do a lot of running around the battlefield. Ecclesitheurge is a good choice on the cleric end since you won't wear armour anyway.

Cleric // Occultist

Basics: Med BAB, d8, Fort and Will, 4 skills, full and 6-level casting, Wis Int Cha physical

In order from best to worst builds:

  • Caster. Keep Wis and Int high, and maybe an above-average Cha for a bit of channelling. It's not a powerhouse of a gestalt caster but fairly versatile. Conjuration implement is a great tool for a summoning cleric (see Herald Caller), and also adds teleportation. Evocation gives you a bit more blasting and boosts spells like searing light or holy smite as well as any domain-based blasts you get your hands on. Transmutation and Divination are just plain good. Enchantment and Illusion have some nice stuff if you can keep Int-based DCs high. Abjuration is skippable. Necromancy has a handful of spells you won't get from the cleric and lets you dabble in minions, but overall it's also skippable unless you want the Mage's Panoply or an:
  • Undead Master. For this one, prioritize Cha followed by Wis and Int. Necromancy implements are a no-brainer, though you'll want to cast animate dead as a cleric and use your occultist spells known elsewhere. Necromantic Servant and Soulbound Doll give you early-game minions and scouts. Necroccultist is a solid archetype here as it boosts your Necromancy DCs – useful since your Int won't be as high as you'd like – and gives you access to more necromancy spells from the wizard list. Alternatively, if you're hurting for stats or want more versatility and you can deal with losing armour, take Silksworn. This lets you rely on Cha for Mental Focus and only keep Int high enough to cast spells. Since this hurts occultist DCs you'll want to pick up spells like spectral hand, death ward, or sands of time with necromancy, and take support/utility schools like transmutation, divination, abjuration, illusion (mirror image, displacement) and conjuration (mage armor, teleportation). If you're hungry for stats but are OK with fewer focus powers and want your armour, substitute Relic Hunter Inquisitor for occultist.
  • Battle cleric. Stat requirements and not getting inherent full BAB are both major downsides here, but it's possible. I'd recommend Panoply Savant (Warrior) for the extra focus since your Int will be middling – you'll need all the help you can get keeping your Panoply implements topped up. For later implements I recommend Illusion and Conjuration since spells like Mirror Image and Dimension Door will be useful even without much focus – though Side Step and Shadow Beast may be worth a point or two. Also consider crusader cleric for the bonus feats – in particular note that Shield Focus qualifies you for Shield Brace at level 5 if you want a polearm with your Panoply. If your GM allows Relic Hunter to take Panoplies, take that instead.

Cleric // Oracle  (Elder Mythos Cultist)

Basics: Med BAB, d8, Fort and Will, 4 skills, two full casting, Wis Cha (physical?)

Different casting stats, and same spell list twice, so no big improvement on versatility, though it is handy to be able to use oracle for your most frequently-cast spells and save cleric for more circumstantial things. With your high Cha, take advantage of channeling or Evangelist (you'll get armour and spontaneous casting back anyway).

Cleric // (Anti)Paladin  (Elder Mythos Cultist//Antipaladin)

Basics: Full BAB, d10, Fort and Will+, 2 skills, full and 4-level casting, physical Wis Cha

Stats will probably be stretched too thin for a reach build, but makes a fine combat build with versatile support spells and abilities. Take a skill points archetype for cleric (Roaming Exorcist, Herald Caller, or Cardinal), and note that the latter two don't lose armour or BAB after gestalting. Consider also Inquisitor//Paladin, which trades casting versatility for better skills, personal buffs, and slightly lower Wis requirements.

Cleric // Psychic

Basics: Med BAB, d8, Fort and Will, 2 skills+, two full casting, Int Wis Cha

Good variety of healing, buffing, debuffing, and divination spells with both prepared and spontaneous options. Faith discipline is a little redundant, though still useful overall. Self-perfection is also worth considering if you're interested in Ecclesitheurge cleric for casting versatility. If your stats are generous or you take Elder Mythos Cultist you could even consider a Cha-based discipline. Reach build would be nice if you can manage the stats and feats.

Cleric // Ranger

Basics: Full BAB, d10, all saves, 6 skills, full and 4-level casting, physical Wis Cha

Very well balanced across combat, skills, and spells. A reach build with the two-handed weapon style makes good use of this versatility, though a more combat focused build will also do fine and Inner Sea Combat has some neat deity-specific combat styles for the ranger. Thematically good for a diety of travel or wilderness, or for a hunter of undead or outsiders.

Cleric // Rogue

Basics: Med BAB, d8, all saves, 8 skills, full casting, physical Wis Cha

Not much weapon skill for gestalt – accuracy is particularly poor – and the rogue doesn't add much to a casting build. Try Cleric//Slayer.

Cleric // Skald

Basics: Med BAB, d8, all saves, 4 skills, full and 6-level casting, physical Wis Cha

Cleric // Slayer

Basics: Full BAB, d10, all saves, 6 skills, full casting, physical Wis Int Cha

Another well balanced and versatile combination, leaning a bit more to melee combat thanks to studied target and sneak attack. Try to avoid class features using Int or Cha.

Cleric // Sorcerer (Empyreal or Elder Mythos Cultist)

Basics: Med BAB, d8, Fort and Will, 2 skills, two full casting, Wis Cha

Wide variety of spells and meets basic durability standards, though without armour you should be behaving more like a sorcerer than a cleric in terms of exposing yourself to danger. Empyreal and Elder Mythos Cultist are significant upgrades thanks to consolidating your casting stats. Ecclesitheurge is a good archetype for an unarmoured cleric, adding casting versatility. However, it's incompatible with Evangelist, the Cultist, and the skill-granting archetypes.

Cleric//Spiritualist

Basics: Med BAB, d8, Fort and Will, 4 skills, full and 6-level casting, Wis Cha

Cleric // Summoner (Elder Mythos Cultist)

Basics: Med BAB, d8, Fort and Will, 2 skills, full and 6-level casting, Wis Cha

Versatile support spells, some debuffs & control, plus meat shield. Note that Herald Caller's Divine Heralds ability doesn't improve your summoner summoning, but the Augment Summons feat works just fine. Alternatively, Elder Mythos Cultist is extremely thematic and improves stat synergy. See also Oracle//Summoner for better stat synergy and skills, or Feyspeaker Druid//Summoner for better everything.

Cleric // Swashbuckler  (Elder Mythos Cultist)

Basics: Full BAB, d10, all saves, 4 skills, full casting, Dex Wis Cha

Pretty well-rounded combat/support character. Since your stat needs are minimal, you should be able to afford a higher starting Wis than most combat clerics, and you should be able to line up your key combat feats by level 5, both of which give you room to shift to a more casting-focused build at higher levels. Consider Evangelist since proficiency loss is irrelevant and performance synergizes well with your high Cha. See also Oracle//Swashbuckler.

Cleric // Warpriest

Basics: Med BAB, d8, Fort and Will, 2 skills, full and 6-level casting, physical Wis

Overlapping BAB, saves, spell lists. You can make a decent combat cleric, but it's not particularly powerful and definitely not versatile. Try Cleric//Inquisitor, or gestalt either Cleric or Warpriest with something full BAB.

Cleric // Witch

Basics: Med BAB, d8, Fort and Will, 2 skills, two full casting, Wis Int

Cleric // Wizard

Basics: Med BAB, d8, Fort and Will, 2 skills+, two full casting, Int Wis

Two great spell lists, and more durable than a wizard. Strongly recommend Ecclesitheurge for added casting versatility at the cost of one die of channel energy.

Druid

A very versatile class. Spells include a good selection of control spells, buffs (especially long-duration defensive buffs like Barkskin and Resist Energy, good for your action economy), and utlity. Wild shape offers mobility, scouting, pointy teeth, and sometimes reach. Natural Spell lets you cast spells from any class while Wild Shaping. Gestalting usually consists of doubling down on a “combat druid” build by picking a complementary full-BAB class, or on a “caster druid” build by selecting a full caster. However some hybrids also complement the class well, and many combinations work well as reach casters. The Feyspeaker archetype notably swaps your casting stat to Charisma, which makes a very good match with Cha-based casters.

There are a few ways to use Wild Shape, each of which relates differently to gestalt. The “tiger” is the easiest combat build and involves taking a form with lots of natural attacks and ideally pounce. It works well with most melee classes, but particularly those with large per-attack damage bonuses. The “T-rex” involves taking a big form with one powerful attack. It's usually less effective than the tiger but can work well with Vital Strike or other specific combos. The “Songbird of Doom” involves taking the form of something tiny and dextrous, getting Dex to hit and damage (usually Weapon Finesse + Agile Amulet of Mighty Fists) and attacking with large increases to accuracy to AC and good damage. Works nicely with classes that encourage dex-based combat or improve reach, but sometimes considered “cheesy.” The “turtle” involves turning into a defensive form (usually not actually a turtle; small fliers and air elementals work well) and casting. Can overlap with the “Songbird” if you want to put in the investment to have a viable non-casting strategy.

If you want to stay humanoid in combat, you should choose an archetype that limits or eliminates Wild Shape in exchange for other powers. The standout options are Goliath Druid, Nature Fang, Skinshaper, and Supernaturalist. Goliath Druid is best for strength-focused combat builds, especially two-handers. Nature Fang and Skinshaper are more versatile and have better utility options. Supernaturalist is a neat option if your other class grants natural weapons that can’t be used with wild shape, or improves summoning. Note that the Supernaturalist’s summoning improvement does enhance celestial/fiendish animals, but not true outsiders. The Sunrider is a niche archetype that grants modest bonuses to allied mounts – it could be interesting if the entire party chooses to play mounted gestalts of one flavour or another.

The Animal Shaman archetypes with their standard-action summoning can work well if your second class enhances summoning. Lion and Saurian Shamans are generally the strongest.

Druid // Fighter

Basics: Full BAB, d10, Fort and Will, 4 skills, full casting, physical Wis

Martial Versatility (Feral Combat Training) is a good deal since it lets you use unarmed strike feats to boost all of your natural attacks. Notable fighter archetypes include the Unarmed Fighter (which works well with the FCT trick) and Lore Warden (for +2 skill points and maneuver skills). Nature Fang also works fine as a druid archetype if you want to feel more like a fighter with nature magic than an extra-fighty druid – in which case, consider a reach build.

Druid // Gunslinger (Nature Fang, Skinshaper)

Basics: Full BAB, d10, all saves, 4 skills, full casting, Dex Wis

Decidedly weird flavour-wise, and despite promising basics you'll have a bit of trouble combining your gun with Wild Shape. Nature Fang and Skinshaper are significant improvements on that front, granting more synergistic combat bonuses on top of a good range of magical backup and utility. I prefer Nature Fang since it gets studied target in the low levels before Gunslinger pulls together, and slayer talents provide a flexible selection of feats (archery or crossbow style are useful for guns; finesse rogue talent gives you a melee backup) and utility.

Druid // Hunter

Basics: Med BAB, d8, all saves, 6 skills, full and 6-level casting, physical Wis

A fairly seamless gestalt that doesn't add many options, but does let you do more at once via more spell slots and your pet. Without full BAB or significant buffs, works best as a casting or reach build. The latter works well for supporting your pet through teamwork feats – the former should consider Divine Hunter. Make sure to use archetypes to trade out overlapping features (nature training, wild empathy, woodland stride). Snapping Flank? Consider Druid//Inqusitor (Sacred Huntmaster) since you'll expand your skill and spell options more.

Druid // Inquisitor

Basics: Med BAB, d8, Fort and Will, 6 skills+, full and 6-level casting, physical Wis

Versatile set of skills and spells. A little behind on martial skills, but you can get there through vigorous buffing. Reach builds and tiger wild shape also help by giving you multiple attacks at full BAB instead of relying on your weaker iterative sequence. In a small party, try Sacred Huntmaster for a stronger pet, and use your nature bond for a domain. Alternatively, Supernaturalist // Monster Tactician gives you a pack of enhanced summons. Either way, check out Snapping Flank; either wild shape or totem transformation should qualify you for the bite.

Druid // Investigator

Basics: Med BAB, d8, all saves, 6 skills+, full and 6-level “casting,” physical Wis Int

Great variety of buffs (including most major healing), control, and utility. A few issues: it's a bit MAD, needs quite a lot of buffing to function well in combat, can't use extracts in Wild Shape, and doesn't really come together until level 4 when Wild Shape and Studied Combat both come online. Different builds address some of these issues. Goliath Druid, Nature Fang, and Skinshaper all fix the extract use issue. Nature Fang gives the build an early-level combat boost, but at higher levels the extra actions for buffing are clumsier than long-duration shapechanging. Dex builds help reduce MAD but take even longer to come online thanks to the feat requirements to get Dex to damage. Personally I like Skinshaper because the “Master of Disguise” thing is super thematic for an investigator, but follow your own tastes. Urushil is also thematic. Should I be encouraging combat at all?

Druid // Kineticist

Basics: Med BAB, d8, all saves, 4 skills, full casting, physical Wis

Moderate attack potential in melee and at range and lots of magical options for support, control, and debuffing. You can use various appendages to direct blasts, so they should be usable in wild shape, and kinetic fist is reasonably useful with natural weapons (I'd take kinetic blade for early levels and then swap it out at level 5). Being able to turn into an elemental is lots of fun and thematic, but note that the size bonuses to stats don't stack with elemental overflow. You can still get decent bonuses if you assign the overflow bonuses to different stats from your wild shape – for example turning into a medium air elemental  with +4 Dex at level 8 and assigning a +2 overflow bonus to Con gives you +2 Dex or Con compared to either alone. And since wild shape works when you don't have burn and provides natural armour, scouting utility, and other special qualities it's still a good ability to have. However if you want something simpler, consider taking Nature Fang or Skinshaper and sticking with kinetic blade, or taking Elemental Ally for a thematic pet (more useful in a small party).

I made a Druid/Geokineticist. Once they can change into elementals they can do some interesting things with their powers (there's something about a burrowing air elemental or a flying water elemental that amuses me). 

Druid // Magus

Basics: Med BAB, d8, Fort and Will, 4 skills, full and 6-level casting, physical Int Wis

Natural attacks aren't the best choices for the magus, and the combo is both MAD and low on BAB. There is potentially some synergy with Green Scourge’s improved Shillelagh and the Staff Magus, though Shillelagh’s inability to enhance a magic quarterstaff is a pain. You’ll want to enhance your staff with Shillelagh right before combat if possible, and in the first round with spell combat otherwise. Arcane Pool gives you a better bonus but probably needs to be applied after Shillelagh or else it will make your staff magic, and thus a non-valid target. Consider stacking Green Scourge with Skinshaper for this build for humanoid shapeshifting bonuses. Alternative weapon-based builds with Skinshaper or Nature Fang?

Druid // Medium

Basics: Med BAB, d8, Fort and Will, 4 skills, full and partial casting, Wis Cha physical?

The champion's damage bonuses are quite nice for natural weapons. The hierophant's nature code taboo is a freebie for you since you already need to follow it. Consider the kami medium for thematics, though it may be difficult to access the champion.

Druid // Mesmerist (Feyspeaker)

Basics: Med BAB, d8, all saves, 6 skills, full and 6-level casting, Wis Cha

Control the entire battlefield: your allies, your enemies, and the terrain itself. Feyspeaker is thematic, gives you a bit more Cha synergy (possibly allowing a melee backup option if your stats are good), and adds some extra enchantment & illusion spells to your arsenal.

Druid // Monk (Unchained)

Basics: Med/Full BAB, d8/d10, all saves, 4 skills, full casting, physical Wis

Really strong defenses with Wisdom synergy. Unchained Monk significantly improves your combat ability and just costs you a few monk immunities (including poison immunity, which you probably get as a druid anyway). Magic Fang can enhance your Unarmed Strike. Shillelagh and quarterstaff flurry is great for lower levels, though the inability to enhance a magic staff means it doesn’t retain value well at higher levels - Green Scourge mitigates this by giving you a better-scaling bonus, but the short duration is inconvenient. Recommended builds:

  • For a wild shape build, take Feral Combat Training with a natural weapon that typically does a lot of damage or has rider effects on it (generally bite). You can now use flurry and UAS feats with that bite. Note: tigers get 2d6 damage on a bite, plus pounce, so you can cross the map and then flurry for 2d6+Str from level 6. The monk's AC bonus also means that you have a solid AC without expensive Wild Armour – and note that some interpretations of the Wild property rule it doesn't encumber you, letting you wear wild armour on top of your monk's bonus. Note also that the Amulet of Mighty Fists improves your Unarmed Strike as well as your natural attacks in the event you're caught without Wild Shape.
  • For grappling specifically, try Tetori. Kraken Caller is also thematic, but mechanically a bit of a draw. Kraken Style is both thematic and mechanically useful.
  • For melee without Wild Shape, Goliath is your best bet. On top of the excellent strength bonus, your increased size does wonders for UAS damage dice and combat maneuvers.
  • For ranged, Zen Archer + Nature Fang or Skinshaper.
  • For a support/caster build, take Sensei instead of Unchained. The druid half is flexible, but note that you do not get Wis to hit with natural attacks.
  • Cha build option: Feyspeaker//Unchained Scaled Fist. Flavour's a bit odd but the mechanics line up well. Combat capability is a little lower than the above options thanks to weaker wild shape and the opportunity cost of not taking other archetypes, but it's not much of a drop and in some games the extra social utility will be worth it.

Druid // Oracle (Feyspeaker)

Basics: Med BAB, d8, Fort and Will, 6/4 skills, two full casting, Cha Wis (physical)?

Normally not a bad combination for a caster, with two diverse spell lists and an array of other features for mobility, defense, and utility. Capable of entering combat as a secondary role by making use of a reach or natural weapons build (Lunar is good for the latter). Feyspeaker is a massive upgrade with casting stat synergy and some extra skills and spells at the modest cost of two levels of wild shape.

Druid // (Anti)Paladin (Feyspeaker)

Basics: Full BAB, d10, Fort and Will+, 6/4 skills, full and 4-level casting, physical Cha Wis

Using normal alignment restrictions, this is only possible if you take Grey Paladin, and it's not really worth that. Even if you take it with a normal paladin, the MAD is a pain. Exception: Feyspeaker archetype. Charisma-based casting, extra skills, all the paladin's melee power plus a solid full casting progression and the ability to wear armour. Fantastic if you can snag it without Grey Paladin, and very good even if you do need to give up Divine Grace and paladin immunities.

Druid // Psychic

Basics: Med BAB, d8, Fort and Will, 4 skills, two full casting, Int Wis

With the druid covering the physical and the psychic concentrating on the mental, you have a very diverse set of magical effects to choose from. Neat and unusual option for a spy between shapeshifting, mindreading, and enchantment. Recommend Self-perfection discipline since it gives you Wis to AC when unarmoured/ in wild shape, and the other abilities aren't bad. Pure Body is especially handy if you have a druid archetype that trades in Venom Immunity.

Druid // Ranger (Goliath, Skinshaper)

Basics: Full BAB, d10, all saves, 6 skills, full casting, physical Wis

This looks obvious for a nature warrior, but you end up with more overlap than synergy. Natural weapon style feats are disappointing, most of your ranger spells are also druid spells, and unless you juggle archetypes you duplicate woodland stride. Works better as a weapons build or if you can make a confident favoured enemy choice, but usually I would recommend Druid//Slayer instead.

Druid // Rogue (Green Scourge)

Basics: Med BAB, d8, all saves, 8 skills, full casting, physical Wis

With wild shape and rogue skills you make a great scout, and you should take the Scout archetype because sneak attacking when you pounce is your main combat perk for this combo compared to Druid//Slayer. Flame Blade is a nice way to deliver sneak attacks (and debilitating injuries) against touch AC, and Green Scourge gives you the ability to cast it spontaneously, add throwing and returning, and even change the energy type to electricity or cold. Weapon Finesse applies, though not Dex to damage. The duration is short, and energy immunity and SR will be problematic in the long run, so I’d still recommend carrying a mundane weapon. Bonus: Green Scourge’s scentless ability is an upgrade on trackless step for someone who expects to do a lot of sneaking around.

Druid //  Skald

Basics: Med BAB, d8, all saves, 4 skills, casting

Druid // Slayer

Basics: Full BAB, d10, all saves, 6 skills, full casting, physical Wis Int

Excellent scout, assassin, or mauler. One of the more versatile gestalts, with lots of utility and full casting but still outstanding in combat with full BAB plus self-buffs (both spells and studied target). TWF is handy for the Goliath druid, and archery works for a Skinshaper – otherwise you'll only want one or two natural weapons compatible feats.

Druid // Sorcerer (Empyreal or Feyspeaker)

Basics: Poor/Med BAB, d8, Fort and Will, 6/4 skills, two full casting, Wis Cha

Most bloodlines and archetypes make this a moderately good combination: a caster with a good variety of spells and good durability but two casting stats. Wild Shape is useful defensively and for utility, but you probably won't have the stats for combat effectiveness. Sylvan bloodline is thematic and lets you pick up a domain without losing your companion. Orc is a neat option for a combat/blasting build – druids have their share of damaging spells – though the natural armour and size increase don't stack with Wild Shape, so that might be best if you're planning on taking Nature Fang. Supernaturalist Druid with the Abyssal Bloodline makes an interesting natural weapons/summoning build, though stats are tight. Empyreal turns you into an entirely Wis-based caster and is your best bet for getting the stats for a combat capable character - if your GM lets you crossblood it with Orc or Abyssal all the better. Alternatively, Feyspeaker makes you Cha-based for a really excellent casting build.

Druid//Spiritualist

Basics: Med BAB, d8, Fort and Will, 4 skills, full and partial casting, Wis (physical?)

Druid // Summoner (Feyspeaker)

Basics: Med BAB, d8, Fort and Will, 6/4 skills, full and 6-level casting, Wis Cha (physical?)

Broad spellcasting options, mostly support and control, and durable enough. Feyspeaker hugely recommended due to better stat synergy, skills, and the fact that the loss of BAB and armour is irrelevant after factoring in the gestalt. Feyspeaker also works well with Synthesist, since you'll be using the synth suit instead of wild shape.

Druid // Swashbuckler (Nature Fang, Skinshaper, Feyspeaker)

Basics: Full BAB, d10, all saves, 6/4 skills, full casting, Dex Wis Cha

Precise Strike doesn't work with natural attacks, so this one needs a weapons combat build to pay off. With a Dex-based combat style that generally means Nature Fang or Skinshaper, though if your stats aren't great also consider Feyspeaker to consolidate casting and panache under your Cha score. While Feyspeaker doesn't get a combat buff like Nature Fang or Skinshaper, you do get extra skills, spells, and keep wild shape at -2 levels for scouting purposes. Consider also Nature Oracle//Swashbuckler.

Druid // Warpriest

Basics: Med BAB, d8, Fort and Will, 4 skills, full and 6-level casting, physical Wis

Very buff-dependent to reach combat strength, but does have good action economy and a nice variety of spells (including all necessary healing magic). Size increases give good value with sacred weapon damage dice. Avoid Nature Fang as it takes too many actions to buff. Wild Shape vs Goliath Druid?

Druid // Witch (Feyspeaker//Seducer)

Basics: Med BAB, d8, Fort and Will, 4 skills, two full casting, Wis Int

Druid//Wizard provides a more diverse casting list.

Druid // Wizard

Basics: Med BAB, d8, Fort and Will, 4 skills, two full casting, Wis Int

“The Merlin” - a character who derives great magical power from their deep understanding of the natural world and its laws. Excellent versatile spell list and reasonably good defenses. Use Wild Shape defensively or for scouting. Invest in Dex and Weapon Finesse and you could even use a weapon halfway competently.

Fighter

The fighter has the potential to excel in a number of styles of combat. Unfortunately, it also has several major weaknesses: it lacks out-of-combat utility, resistance to magic, and the ability to improve performance in the toughest fights. The best fighter gestalts patch these weaknesses while complementing one or more fighter combat styles. The most straightforward choices are part-casters and divine full casters which patch these weaknesses with improved saves, skills, and buffs. These casters also benefit from the solid combat base and generous bonus feats of the fighter. Combining fighter with other martial classes tends to leave you with an over-specialized character, but sometimes you can stack potent combat abilities while still mitigating the downsides.

Fighter typically gestalts less well with full arcane casters due to arcane spell failure issues and conflicting action economy. This can be mitigated in a few ways. A ranged build minimizes the danger associated with little or no armour, and fighters make effective archers. The Arcane Armour training feat (available at level 3) lets you cast in a Mithral Shirt with no spell failure at the cost of a swift action, while Arcane Armor Mastery (level 7) lets you cast in a Mithral Breastplate (or if you’re using it from 3.5, a Celestial Plate). The Child of Acavna and Amaznen gives improved armour resistance but losing weapon training is probably not worth it. A reach build improves action economy as you can use your standard action to cast spells while making attacks of opportunity. And of course you might as well make use of Arcane Strike.

Advanced Weapon Training abilities

  • Armoured Confidence - a nice intimidate bonus for builds that give you fun things to do with intimidate.
  • Armed Bravery and Fighter’s reflexes - handy for covering weak saves
  • Trained initiative - handy for caster fighters or sneak attacking fighters
  • Warrior Spirit - a versatile weapon buff, particularly useful for fighter//martial combinations.

For archetypes:

  • If your second class encourages the use of light or no armour, look at Dawnflower Dervish, Dragonheir Scion, Mutation Warrior, Skirmisher and Lore Warden. Skirmisher also brings you up to 4 skills/level, while Lore Warden adds a bonus 2 skill ranks to be spent on any Int-based skills. That said, if you decide to keep armour mastery, consider the advanced armour mastery abilities Master Armourer and Armoured Master with the Sprightly Armour feat.
  • Eldritch Guardian gives you a potentially combat-capable familiar at low cost - useful for flanking buddies or teamwork feats.
  • Drill sergeant gives you tactician at the cost of bravery and advanced weapon training options.
  • Roughrider gives a number of bonuses for fighters planning on doing mounted combat with a pet from another class - losing advanced armor and weapon training hurts, but note your attack and damage bonuses from Mounted Mettle also apply to your mount.
  • Trench fighter gives you dex to damage with firearms, so it’s nice to pair with other firearm-focused archetypes that don’t give that bonus.
  • For a theme game, the Blackjack fighter is an interesting archetype for everyone to have, as it gives you access to a neat tactics ability and you can still customize your combat style using weapon training and some of your bonus feats.
  • Other archetypes generally focus on improving a specific fighting style such as archery or spear + shield (phalanx fighter) - refer to fighter guides for comments on the effectiveness of these archetypes for the intended purposes.

Fighter // Gunslinger

Basics: Full BAB, d10, Fort and Ref, 4 skills, no casting, Dex Wis

Bonus feats help a ranged combat style come together more quickly and give you room in your build for a few extras. Really low on utility and self-buffing. Trench Fighter

Fighter // Hunter

Basics: Full BAB, d10, Fort and Ref, 6 skills, casting

Fighter // Inquisitor

Basics: Full BAB, d10, Fort and Will, 6 skills+, 6-level casting, physical Wis

Good combat base with enough feats to do interesting things, ability to self-buff, and good utility.

Fighter // Investigator

Basics: Full BAB, d10, all saves, 6 skills+, 6-level “casting”, physical Int

Lots of in combat and out of combat skill with no real weak points and quite a lot of staying power – extracts and inspiration are limited use but most of your abilities aren't. Studied Combat and Weapon Training provide big static attack and damage bonuses – try Combat Expertise to turn some of that into defense. Don't forget the Mutagen discovery as an Investigator talent.

Fighter//Kineticist (Mutation Warrior+Martial Master)

Basics: Full BAB, d10, Fort and Ref, 4 skills, pseudo-casting, Dex Con

The kinetic fighting style doesn't have much use for bonus combat feats, and weapon training doesn't work with blasts. With Mutation Warrior for a Con mutagen and Martial Master to swap out weapon training this is OK, but consider Fighter//Druid or Kineticist//Paladin or Slayer.

Fighter // Magus

Basics: Full BAB, d10, Fort and Will, 4 skills, casting

Armour training advances nicely between fighter and magus.

Fighter//Medium

Basics: Full BAB, d10, Fort and Will, 4 skills, partial casting, physical Cha

The champion and guardian give you a good boost to the fighter's primary combat role, and the others add secondary roles. But since the fighter is fairly lacklustre, this combination is particularly dependent on your ability to predict and access the spirit you need – Champion and Guardian don't add much aside from their combat boosts.

Fighter // Mesmerist

Basics: Full BAB, d10, all saves, 6 skills, 6-level casting, physical Cha

A more subtle way to add magic to your fighter. Aim to use spells out of combat, with your in-combat magic focused on your debuffing stare and on using tricks to control the battlefield.

Fighter // Monk
