Basics: Full BAB, d10, all saves/Fort and Ref, 4 skills, no casting

  • Unarmed fighter archetype has some nice benefits, though losing advanced weapon training means this isn’t a no-brainer.
  • fighter//monk; kung-fu master. A Fighter/Zen Archer monk would be the unrivaled king of ranged combat, with a lot of scouting skills and high mobility.

Fighter // Occultist

Basics: Full BAB, d10, Fort and Will, 4 skills, 6-level casting, physical Int

Good combat base, lots of buffing and utility, debuffing or control options if you can get your Int high enough for good DCs, no problems with armour or shields. Consider Haunt Collector.

Fighter // Oracle

Basics: Full BAB, d10, Fort and Will, 4 skills, full casting, physical Cha

Strong in combat, self-buffing and support through the Oracle, and plenty of feats for a reach build if you desire. I recommend a mystery that has good non-combat options, such as Ancestor, Lunar, Stone, or Wind.

Fighter // (Anti)Paladin

Basics: Full BAB, d10, Fort and Will+, 2 skills, casting

Viking gets Rage Powers for Lesser Celestial Totem

Fighter // Psychic

Basics: Full BAB, d10, Fort and Will, 2 skills+, full casting, physical Int and Wis or Cha

Thanks to a lack of somatic components, this makes a fairly effective warrior mage which can handle a range of combat styles (in contrast to the much more limited Magus). Action economy is your biggest issue. This can be addressed by some combination of a reach weapon style in order to sneak in extra attacks on casting turns, making use of the psychic's handful of swift/immediate action spells, or pre-buffing. Utility is also a strong consideration for spells and discipline since the Fighter largely lacks it. Lore Warden's abilities get a boost from the Knowledge bonus of – surprise – the Rebirth discipline.

Fighter // Ranger

Basics: Full BAB, d10, Fort and Ref, 6 skills, 4-level casting, physical Wis

Fighter already has a good number of feats, so the reason to take Ranger would be some combination of (1) you know you'll be fighting a lot of a particular enemy type (2) you want to skip specific prerequisites, for example to make a Str-based TWF character or (3) you have a lowish point buy. Otherwise, you're better off with a Hunter or Inquisitor.

Fighter // Rogue

Basics: Full BAB, d10, Fort and Ref, 8 skills, casting

The fighter provides the accuracy and durability the rogue lacks, and the rogue brings out of combat utility. Unfortunately the combination still has issues with buffing and with magic resistance. TWF build is probably your best bet – the Two-Weapon Fighter archetype has some options that make you less reliant on full attacks, and you have enough feats to cover the basic line as well as Two-Weapon Feint if you can't rely on flanking. Alternatively, Lore Warden brings you up to 10 skill ranks per level and adds minor combat bonuses including Combat Expertise - it’s a good choice if you want to use combat maneuvers. Consider Sneaking Precision, which gives you a fairly reliable debuff (or extra damage if you take Sneaking Critical). Remember you qualify for Critical Mastery, so if you want you can add two conditions any time you crit, and a third when you sneak attack twice in a turn.

Fighter // Skald

Basics: Full BAB, d10, Fort and Will, 4 skills, casting

Fighter // Slayer

Basics: Full BAB, d10, Fort and Ref, 6 skills, no casting, physical Int

Not bad, but consider Fighter//Investigator for better saves and utility, and at least as good combat skill.

Fighter // Sorcerer

Basics: Full BAB, d10, Fort and Will, 2 skills, casting

Not one of the better fighting//arcane combos, even with a lightly armoured fighter archetype. You'll want an archetype that trades away armour training, which is essentially useless because of spell failure. Since you have few swift actions, Arcane Strike is a good feat. As usual you have your melee bloodlines.

Fighter//Spiritualist

Basics: Full BAB, d10, Fort and Will, 4 skills, casting

Fighter // Summoner

Basics: Full BAB, d10, Fort and Will, 2 skills, 6-level casting, physical Cha

  • Lore Warden Fighter // Synth Summoner would have insanely high CMB and could grab size, extra reach, and special attacks to chain off normal hits for tripping, pulling, pushing, and/or grabbing.

Fighter // Swashbuckler

Basics: Full BAB, d10, Fort and Ref,  4 skills, no casting, Dex Cha

Fighter // Warpriest

Basics: Full BAB, d10, Fort and Will, 2 skills, 6-level casting, physical Wis

Your utility is pretty poor, but the warpriest adds support and much needed self-buffing ability to the fighter, with good action economy. Consider shield bashing – you certainly have the feats for it.

Fighter // Witch (Scarred Witch Doctor)

Basics: Full BAB, d10, Fort and Will, 2 skills, full casting, physical Int

Tactician is an interesting archetype, as it gives you an extra 2 skills/level and gives you an initiative bonus, the cavalier’s tactician, and two minor intelligence-based support abilities, though delaying weapon training isn’t great.

Fighter // Wizard

Basics:  Full BAB, d10, Fort and Will, 2 skills, full casting, physical Int

Tactician is an interesting archetype, as it gives you an extra 2 skills/level and gives you an initiative bonus, the cavalier’s tactician, and two minor intelligence-based support abilities, though delaying weapon training isn’t great. Look for schools that have martially oriented powers, such as Conjuration (Teleportion) Wizard - adding Dimensional Agility gives a lot of mobility to a reach build.

Gunslinger

The gunslinger is, unsurprisingly, very focused on its gun. It works best with classes can improve its ranged combat through martial or magical abilities; good Will saves, skills, and a backup option such as switch-hitting or magic are a plus. It also works passably for a switch-hitter when pared with a melee focus, or as a ranged backup for a caster, but this is usually not ideal because the gunslinger's intense focus doesn't provide much to someone who wants ranged combat to be a secondary option. Keep in mind that the gun does need 3-5 feats to be moderately functional, on top of the gunslinger's class features. The only archetype with notable gestalt implications is Mysterious Stranger, which works best when paired with a Cha-based full caster who won't  be using their gun every round, but will have lots of panache and a nice damage bonus for Focused Aim.

Gunslinger // Hunter

Basics: Full BAB, d10, Fort and Ref, 6 skills, 6-level casting, Dex Wis

Strong offence with some buffing and utility. Could use stronger buffs and a good will save - consider Sacred Huntmaster Inquisitor.

Gunslinger // Inquisitor

Basics: Full BAB, d10, all saves, 6 skills+, 6-level casting, Dex Wis

Bane is highly effective when paired with a large number of ranged attacks, and the Destruction judgment adds more damage (you don't need the to-hit from Justice). Between Cunning Initiative and Gunslinger's Initiative you're a super fast draw. Plus good utility.

Gunslinger // Investigator

Basics: Full BAB, d10, all saves, 6 skills+, 6-level casting, Dex Wis Int

Ranged Study is practically required as a 5th or 7h level feat so you can use Studied Combat/Strike with your gun, which is unfortunate since the gunslinger already needs so many feats. However, once you get your feats in a line you do have excellent ranged damage, the potential to enter melee, good buffs and great utility.

Gunslinger // Kineticist

Basics: Full BAB, d10, Fort and Ref, 4 skills, pseudo-casting, Con Dex Wis

Guns and blasts don't play together without a conductive gun, and even then you can only use energy blasts and won't be able to use gather energy. The kinetic blade melee option, defenses, and utility are still useful, but not enough to make this exciting – especially since the best energy blast for a conductive gun (blue flame, pure pyrokineticist) comes with the worst defense and utility abilities.

Gunslinger // Magus (Eldritch Archer)

Basics: Full BAB, d10, all saves, 4 skills, 6-level casting, physical Wis Int

Base magus is melee focused, so it doesn't get much out of the gun that it wouldn't get from any other full-BAB class. Eldritch Archer, despite the name, works just fine with guns. The combo is a bit MAD but has good defenses, high damage potential, and moderate versatility depending on spell selection.

Gunslinger // Medium

Basics: Full BAB, d10, all saves, 4 skills, partial casting, Dex Wis Cha

Gunslinger // Mesmerist

Basics: Full BAB, d10, all saves, 6 skills, 6-level casting, Dex Cha Wis

Good damage, debuffing, control, and utility. You can try Mysterious Stranger if your stats are stingy.

Gunslinger // Monk

Basics: Full BAB, d10, all saves/Fort and Ref, 4 skills, no casting, Dex Wis

Great switch-hitter with just Dex and Wis. You'll have lots of grit and ki and your monk and gunslinger AC bonuses stack. Grab weapon finesse and an agile amulet of mighty fists for your unarmed strikes, or if that's too much investment take Sensei for Wis to hit with unarmed strikes. The former build gives you more freedom to take fun archetypes, but the latter adds support and a few skill bonuses to helps out with your otherwise mediocre utility. Far Strike and Zen Archer archetypes give you extra ranged combat feats for more specialization, but most of their abilities are limited to thrown weapons and bows respectively so overall it's a bad tradeoff for versatility. Unchained is lacklustre here – you already have full BAB and don't need mobility as much, but lack a good Will save. Sohei's weapon choices don't match up well. Kata Master is an interesting option since your panache and grit pools would merge, giving you a flexible set of tricks.

Gunslinger // Occultist

Basics: Full BAB, d10, all saves, 4 skills, 6-level casting, Dex Int Wis

Get yourself a +2 dex item and magic gun with the transmutation implement. Then get yourself something fun. Battle Host with a panoply bond gun is tempting because you can ignore the consequence of a single misfire – but a second one will still blow up the weapon in your face and then you're screwed, so think carefully.

Gunslinger // Oracle

Basics: Full BAB, d10, all saves, 4 skills, full casting, Dex Cha Wis

Gunslinger//Cleric has better stat synergy, but this is still a serviceable combination of weapon skill, self-buffs, and support magic. If you want to rely more heavily on casting, Mysterious Stranger puts the focus on your Cha.

Gunslinger // (Anti)Paladin

Basics: Full BAB, d10, all saves+, 4 skills, 4-level casting, Dex Wis Cha

Fantastic damage potential and survivability, decent support options. Divine Hunter gives you useful ranged abilities.

Gunslinger // Psychic

Basics: Full BAB, d10, all saves, 4 skills, full casting, Dex Int Wis

Not a whole lot of synergy between the two classes, but fairly versatile with the capacity for ranged damage, buffs, debuffs, and utility casting. It's your choice whether you want to prioritize casting with a gun as a backup option or prioritize your gun with casting for utility, pre-buffing, and the occasional swift or immediate effect.

Gunslinger // Ranger

Basics: Full BAB, d10, Fort and Ref, 6 skills, 4-level casting, Dex Wis

Less versatile: good utility, but in combat you do guns. Maybe a bit of melee if you pick up Weapon Finesse and a Dex to damage feat. Archery and crossbow style both have useful feats for you, depending on whether you want Point Blank Master or not. Consider using your animal companion as a mount.

Gunslinger // Rogue

Basics: Full BAB, d10, Fort and Ref, 8 skills, no casting, Dex Wis

Sneak attack is hard at range, and you lack self-buffing. Try Gunslinger//Investigator.

Gunslinger // Skald

Basics: Full BAB, d10, all saves, 4 skills, 6-level casting, Dex Wis Cha

Gunslinger // Slayer

Basics: Full BAB, d10, Fort and Ref, 6 skills, no casting, Dex Wis Int

Studied Target is a nice reliable buff for your gun, and archery and crossbow style both have useful feats for you, depending on whether you want Point Blank Master or not. Sneak attack is a little harder to pull off, but nice if you get the jump on your foe or if you want to pull a melee weapon as backup (the finesse rogue talent helps). Stygian Slayer's invisibility helps, too, and you'll want light armour anyway.

Gunslinger // Sorcerer (Mysterious Stranger)

Basics: Full BAB, d10, all saves, 4 skills, full casting, Dex Cha Wis

If you're planning on significant in-combat casting (and why not?) Mysterious Stranger helps you streamline your stats and gives you a nice low-level damage bonus when your casting is lacking and you haven't lined up your feats. See also: Gunslinger//Wizard (spellslinger)

Gunslinger//Spiritualist

Basics: Full BAB, d10, all saves, 4 skills, casting

Gunslinger // Summoner

Basics: Full BAB, d10, all saves, 4 skills, 6-level casting, Dex Wis Cha

Gun, meat shield, a little magical support. Skip Synth.

Gunslinger // Swashbuckler

Basics: Full BAB, d10, Fort and Ref, 4 skills, no casting, Dex Wis Cha

Seems obvious for a sword-and-pistol character, but the gun class and sword class don't provide buffs that help each others' weapons. Daring Champion Cavalier (with Gunslinger) and Savage Technologist Barbarian (with Swashbuckler) both provide buffs the help the sword and the pistol more evenly. Other suggestions?

Gunslinger // Warpriest

Basics: Full BAB, d10, all saves, 4 skills, 6-level casting, Dex Wis

Extra feats from both classes help you cover the ranged basics, plus you have good support and self-buffing. Sacred weapon enhancement is a pretty good deal for a gun once you get rapid shot. The warpriest's heavy armour proficiency is a waste. I personally prefer Gunslinger//Inquisitor for a bit more utility but this is a very strong option.

Gunslinger // Witch (Scarred Witch Doctor)

Basics: Full BAB, d10, all saves, 4 skills, casting

Gunslinger // Wizard

Basics:  Full BAB, d10, all saves, 4 skills, full casting, Dex Int Wis

You can't shoot spells and bullets at the same time, and your features don't do a lot to reinforce each other. Still, at absolute minimum you're a wizard with good durability, and there will probably times when it will be more efficient to use your gun than your spells. Spellslinger deserves some special mention here. You give up a lot – arcane bond, school specialization, cantrips, and an extra two opposition schools for a total of four – so this is not necessarily the best choice. However, you do get the ability to significantly enhance the DCs or ranged touch spells, rays, and cones, and to sacrifice spell slots to enhance your gun. Consider also Gunslinger//Eldritch Archer Magus, possibly with a one-level dip in Spellslinger.

Hunter

Hunter is a real pet class. It doesn't just have a pet, it's designed around the pet, with most of its features improving the pet in some way. That means that in a small party the pet can easily fill the melee role while you focus on casting or ranged damage, and even in a high-power game it's possible to build and buff the pet to contribute meaningfully if you use teamwork feats wisely.

The melee build is perhaps the most potent, but also the least versatile, as both the hunter and the companion fill the same role. This makes it less good for a small party, but very nice in a high power game. Flanking feats such as Outflank and Precise Strike add significant boosts to both the hunter and companion, especially to builds with a large number of attacks. Pack Flanking allows you to “flank” when adjacent to your companion, which allows for mounted builds. Since you'll generally want to pair Hunter with a martial class, it's likely you'll end up missing a good Will save; the Hunter's above-average Wisdom helps but doesn't eliminate this weakness.

Ranged builds are slightly more versatile than melee ones, but the focus of both pet and master is still on damage. I'd only suggest this build if you really want an archer, but your group needs a frontliner. In this situation, make sure you prioritize your pet's defences since it'll take a lot of hits. You'll be looking to build like a ranged hunter, but select a second class with a good set of archery features.

Caster builds are highly versatile. The Hunter provides a competent frontliner in the pet, a baseline of martial competence if you don't want to cast, and a starter set of spells. The second class should provide the primary casting – ideally Wis-based and with the ability to wear armour. Teamwork feats will be significantly less useful to both you and your companion; consider trading them for a domain and the celestial/fiendish template using the Divine Hunter archetype.

The pet-free option, Feral Hunter, is quite similar to a Druid but with better skills, partial casting, a Ref save instead of a Will save, and an animal focus that's slightly more versatile than a free stat belt. The value of this trade depends on the other half of the gestalt as well as the level. The Feral Hunter is best at low levels where its skills and early-access Ranger spells pull a lot of weight, while the Druid becomes more powerful at high levels with more potent casting (especially 7th-9th level spells) and advanced elemental forms.

Generally the Hunter is designed for wilderness settings. If you're playing in an urban game, try the Roof Runner archetype, or even Sacred Huntmaster Inquisitor.

Hunter // Inquisitor

Basics: Med BAB, d8, all saves, 6 skills+, two 6-level casting, physical Wis

This is a good small-party option, with a wide range of spells and skills, a strong pet for the melee role, and the potential to buff yourself for combat. Preacher, Cloaked Wolf, or Divine Hunter swap out surplus teamwork feats.  However, your buffing will have trouble keeping up in a high-power gestalt situation. Consider Druid//Sacred Huntmaster for an equally strong pet but with stronger casting.

Hunter // Investigator

Basics: Med BAB, d8, all saves, 6 skills+, casting, physical Int Wis

Hunter // Kineticist

Basics: Med BAB, d8, Fort and Ref, 6 skills, 6-level and pseudo-casting, Dex Con Wis

I prefer Druid//Kineticist for the good Will save.

Hunter // Magus

Basics: Med BAB, d8, all saves, 6 skills, two 6-level casting, physical Int Wis

Hunter // Medium

Basics: Med BAB, d8, all saves, 6 skills, two partial casting, physical Wis Cha

Hunter // Mesmerist

Basics: Med BAB, d8, all saves, 6 skills,  two 6-level casting, physical (?) Wis Cha

Fun stuff combining stare/tricks with companion?

Hunter // Monk

Basics: Med/Full BAB, d8/d10, all saves/Fort and Ref, 6 skills, 6-level casting, physical Wis

Good secondary roles in scouting & support casting. A couple of good ways to build your primary role:

  • Unchained Monk gives you the best overall combat skills but you want a very high Wis since you lose a good will save in exchange for Full BAB. Works fairly well as a pet-free version with Feral Hunter: see Druid//Monk for Wild Shape strategy. You can take Monastic Mount as a ki power, though mounted combat wastes much of the UnMonk's innate maneuverability. Instead consider:
  • Sohei, to take mounted combat feats as bonus feats and can flurry with a lance (use Mounted Skirmisher!) It also tolerates a modest Wis since it has a good base Will save and can wear light armour, so feel free to start with a Wis 12. You'll probably still want to ditch the armour as your class bonus improves and magic armour bonuses become reliable. Unmounted, this is a good reach build with a polearm of your choice – Paired Opportunists lets you give your pet extra AoO, too. Feral Hunter doesn't mesh well with weapons. You can also flurry with a bow as a late game second option, but if you want to specialize in archery take:
  • Zen Archer. After level 3 able to grant flanking bonuses to its hunter companion while still attacking with a bow (don't forget Gravity Bow). Bad match with Feral Hunter since you can't use a bow when wild shaping and the animal focus benefits aren't great for the Zen Archer. You can easily get Wis high enough to take advantage of control spells on the druid list, though for a casting focus consider:
  • Sensei for a support/control build. Focus on Wis, send your companion into melee, and use Wis to hit and maneuver mastery to trip, disarm, etc when not casting. Plays a bit like a maneuver bard but nature focused, more SAD, and with a big nasty pet attached. Surprisingly not bad with Feral Hunter since inspire courage works well with your improved summoning and you can snag extra maneuvers (or scouting utility) from wild shape. Animal Focus (tiger) gives you the best summons and a good stat benefit. However, Druid//Sensei is a better pet-free option.

Hunter//Occultist

Basics: Med BAB, d8, all saves, 6 skills, two 6-level casting, physical Int Wis

Hunter // Oracle

Basics: Med BAB, d8, all saves, 6 skills, full and 6-level casting, Cha Wis physical?

Support magic (without stat synergy), decent skills, and a pet. Try Druid//Oracle, Ranger//Oracle, or Voice of the Wild Bard//Nature Oracle.

Hunter // (Anti)Paladin

Basics: Full BAB, d10, all saves+, 6 skills, 6- and 4-level casting, physical Wis Cha

Hunter // Psychic

Basics: Med BAB, d8, all saves, 6 skills, full and 6-level casting, Int Wis (physical?)

Hunter // Ranger

Basics: Full BAB, d10, Fort and Ref, 6 skills, 6- and 4-level casting, physical Wis

Overlapping abilities and spell lists make this underwhelming. Use an archetype such as Divine Tracker to trade away the ranger's animal companion. Sacred Huntmaster Inquisitor//Ranger or Hunter//Slayer are a bit more diversified.

Hunter // Rogue

Basics: Med BAB, d8, Fort and Ref, 8 skills, 6-level casting, physical Wis

Despite only getting medium BAB and HD, you can pull off a very effective combat build by flanking with your companion. Outflank helps with accuracy. Hunter 540 provides an example progression (note use of Pack Flanking to expand flanking options to include companions that are adjacent or sharing space). Consider Hunter//Slayer if you want to hedge your bets a bit and be slightly less reliant on having your pet in position.

Hunter // Skald

Basics: Med BAB, d8, all saves, 6 skills, two 6-level casting, physical Wis Cha

Hunter // Slayer

Basics: Full BAB, d10, Fort and Ref, 6 skills, 6-level casting, physical Wis Int

Teamwork feats, sneak attack, and a flanking buddy make you a formidable melee presence. Good utility, though not a whole lot better than hunter or slayer individually.

Hunter // Sorcerer (Empyreal)

Basics: Med BAB, d8, all saves, 6 skills, full and 6-level casting, Wis (physical, Cha)

Empyreal is great. If you focus on support or no-save spells you can make a reach build, or pump Wis for superior casting. Either way, versatile spell list with good durability and a furry buddy watching your back in melee. Works OK with Feral Hunter.

Hunter//Spiritualist

Basics: Med BAB, d8, all saves, 6 skills, two 6-level casting, physical Wis

Hunter // Summoner

Basics: Med BAB, d8, all saves, 6 skills, two 6-level casting, physical Wis Cha

Hunter // Swashbuckler

Basics: Full BAB, d10, Fort and Ref, 6 skills, casting

Hunter // Warpriest

Basics: Med BAB, d8, all saves, 6 skills, two 6-level casting, physical Wis

A little behind in the combat basics, but

Hunter // Witch

Basics: Med BAB, d8, all saves, 6 skills, casting

Hunter // Wizard

Basics:  Med BAB, d8, all saves, 6 skills, full and 6-level casting, Int Wis

Inquisitor

The Inquisitor's big strengths are self-buffing and utility (particularly social, investigative, and tracking). It works very well with most martial classes. Their Bane ability is particularly effective for archers and other combat styles involving making a large number of attacks with a single weapon.

Inquisitor can be gestalted effectively with wis-based full casters. Int-based full casters can also work with the Living Grimoire archetype, though this reduces your overall weapons combat ability and pushes you into using a light mace (albeit one with scaling damage dice).

Most archetypes are minor thematic variations, but some offer significant benefits for certain types of builds. Sacred Huntmaster and Monster Tactician are good choices for casting builds in a small party. Preacher is good if you can't find useful teamwork feats. Teamwork feats tend to be melee-slanted, but ranged characters should look at Escape Route, Friendly Fire Maneuvers, Lookout, Swap Places, Target of Opportunity, and Volley Fire. Alternatively, if you’re building an archer and feel like being able to really ruin a spellcaster’s day, take Spellbreaker combined with the Spellkiller Inquisition, which adds a +6 bonus to concentration checks to cast within your threatened area and an extra +2 if you hit them with a ranged attack. Sanctified Slayer and Relic Hunter are good if you anticipate a lot of combats in an adventuring day. Sanctified Slayer adds a straightforward swift-action combat boost.

Relic Hunter is a bit more complicated, offering a powerful but limited selection of utility and/or martial powers at the cost of reducing the scope of your spell list. It's a great archetype for a casting build, which get more benefit from implement powers than the typical inquisitor buffs, and can cover some of the casting basics with their other spell list. Martial builds have more to lose, but should also consider the Relic Hunter if the overall build needs more utility and already has a lot of swift actions. See Occultist for notes on implement focus powers, though keep in mind that with fewer focus powers you should be making choices based more on resonant powers and spell list, which affects choices as follows:

  • Similar to the occultist:
  • Abjuration - a smattering of core defensive spells. Resonant and base powers pretty good.
  • Divination - an array of moderately useful utility spells. Resonant and base powers are great, focus powers are worthwhile – top choice for the Relic Hunter.
  • Better for the Relic Hunter:
  • Enchantment is more versatile, including buffs like Wrath, Heroism, and Prayer in addition to mind control – this makes it a good choice for a support or combat build. Powers  skippable.
  • Evocation gets smite spells, light spells, Blistering Invective, Divine Favor, and Divine Power. Since focus powers add energy rays (base power), blasts, and walls, the inquisitor again ends up with more versatility from this school. Only thing you're really missing is force effects.
  • Less good for the Relic Hunter:
  • Transmutation's spell list is lacklustre. The resonant and base powers are good enough that martials still need this school, but casters can wait until level 4 or 7.
  • Conjuration basically just has healing, and the Side Step power.
  • Illusion gets Invisibility, the “Disguise” line, and that's about it.
  • Necromancy is pretty thin with only Inflict and a few not-fantastic debuffs.

Inquisitor // Investigator

Basics: Med BAB, d8, all saves+, 6 skills+, two 6-level casting, physical Int Wis

Relies too much on buffing for effectiveness, and stat synergy is poor. Living Grimoire is a half-step better, with only one mental stat required. In an intrigue-based game, it might go to green thanks to good utility (stern gaze, detect alignment and discern lies work very well with investigator) and decent defences. But the combat end is still below average for gestalt, with the sacred weapon/tome and solo tactics leaving you only slightly ahead of a single-class investigator.

Inquisitor//Kineticist

Basics: Med BAB, d8, all saves, 6 skills+, 6-level and pseudo-casting, Con Dex Wis

Bane doesn't work on blasts, since you need to “wield” the affected weapon. Sanctified Slayer's studied target  and the Destruction and Smiting judgments should work; Smiting is particularly nice as a way of dealing with DR/alignment. Consider archetypes that give up bane and not much else, such as the Trackless Operative or Secret Seeker. Relic Hunter is another option. One way or another, you'll get decent but not fantastic buffs and some extra utility on top of the kinteicist's competent damage and potentially strong defense/utility/mobility.

Inquisitor // Magus

Basics: Med BAB, d8, Fort and Will, 6 skills+, two 6-level casting, physical Int Wis

MAD, swift action heavy, and a lot of overlap on the basics. Living Grimoire reduces MAD, but the “light mace” is a terrible weapon for a magus.

Inquisitor//Medium

Basics: Med BAB, d8, Fort and Will, 6 skills+, two partial casting, physical Wis Cha

Inquisitor // Mesmerist

Basics: Med BAB, d8, Fort and Will, 6 skills+, two 6-level casting, physical Wis Cha

Too unfocused, MAD.

Inquisitor // Monk

Basics: Med/Full BAB, d8/d10, all saves+, 6 skills+, 6-level casting, physical Wis

The really nice thing about this – aside from Wisdom synergy – is how effective Bane is when you're making a bunch of attacks with a single weapon (ie flurry). Unchained gives you great melee power with good mobility and excellent special durability between improved evasion, stalwart, and purity of body (additional defensive bonus feats or ki powers optional). Zen Archer is your ranged option, slightly less durable but massively Wis-focused with Wis to hit, AC, initiative, monster identification, and possibly social skills; consider Preacher to replace the melee-focused teamwork feats. Either way, great skills and a few casting tricks to supplement your primary combat role. Other archetypes are mostly fine but not as impressive. Biggest issue is how many swift actions you use. Consider Relic Hunter for passive buffs; you can actually keep Bane as a standard action if you take the Transmutation implements.

Inquisitor // Occultist

Basics: Med BAB, d8, Fort and Will, 6 skills+, two 6-level casting, physical Int Wis

With the inquisitor's toolkit your best bet is a martial build, taking Trappings of the Warrior with either Haunt Collector for the Champion spirit, or Panoply Savant if you're short on Focus (you probably will be) and don't mind delaying your utility implements. Living Grimoire helps if your stats are middling, though the tradeoffs aren't trivial. If you want an inquisitor with implements you're better off with the Relic Hunter Inquisitor paired with a full Wis-based caster or martial.

Inquisitor // Oracle

Basics: Med BAB, d8, Fort and Will, 6 skills+, full and 6-level casting, physical Wis Cha

Unfocused in terms of your primary combat strategy, no stat synergy. If you do go this route I’d generally recommend a reach build with combat mystery; studied combat being a move action is less limiting if you’re not full attacking. Lore isn’t as useful for you as the Alchemist//Oracle since it doesn’t have as big an effect on your offense, but it could make a thematic build for a combat-light game.

Inquisitor // (Anti)Paladin

Basics: Full BAB, d10, Fort and Will+, 6 skills+, 6-level and 4-level casting, physical Wis Cha

Massively durable between Lay on Hands, Stalwart, and Divine Grace. Potentially brutal offense if you can get all your buffs active (Relic Hunter makes this somewhat easier). Not enough feats to be really versatile in combat, but good out of combat versatility. Stats are demanding, but you can minimize need for Dex by suiting up in full plate or alternatively go for a dex-based build. With Lay on Hands and a good AC you don't need all that much Con.

Inquisitor // Psychic (Relic Hunter)

Basics: Med BAB, d8, Fort and Will,  6 skills+, full and 6-level casting, Int Wis

Strong in detective and intrigue plotlines, with a lot of mundane and magical abilities for investigation and manipulation. Also a pretty good selection of support spells from both lists, and debuffs mostly via Psychic. The inquisitor's personal combat buffs can be used to make you a passable backup combatant, but I recommend using Relic Hunter to swap them out for more versatile implement powers (which can include combat abilities if you wish). Faith is a solid discipline, though anything Wis-based is fine. You could even try a Cha discipline with Living Grimoire, though as this doesn't actually reduce MAD, I don't recommend it. Consider also Investigator//Psychic.

Inquisitor // Ranger

Basics: Full BAB, d10, all saves+, 6 skills+, 6- and 4-level casting, physical Wis

Thematic hunter, very verastile, capable of a lot of self-buffing. All good saves plus Evasion and Stalwart means you'll shrug off lots of pain. Also has plenty of skills and utility spells. You can use the combat style for switch hitting or to invest in a style that's usually too feat-intensive for the Inqusitor, like Weapon and Shield – though keep in mind Bane and TWF aren't a terribly strong combination since you can only enhance one of your weapons.

Inquisitor // Rogue

Basics: Med BAB, d8, all saves+, 8 skills+, 6-level casting, physical Wis

Not enough offense. Try Inquisitor//Slayer.

Inquisitor //  Skald

Basics: Med BAB, d8, all saves, 6 skills+, casting

Inquisitor //  Slayer

Basics: Full BAB, d10, all saves+, 6 skills+, 6-level casting, physical Wis Int

Another thematic hunter with lots of self-buffs and utility. Sneak Attack works nicely with the flanking-based teamwork feats, and Sacred Huntmaster can give you a very strong flanking buddy. Avoid spells and talents with DCs.

Inquisitor // Sorcerer (Relic Hunter or Monster Tactician, Empyreal)

Basics: Med BAB, d8, Fort and Will, 6 skills+, full and 6-level casting, Wis (Cha)

Too MAD to make good use of the Inquisitor's combat buffs, and there are better options for adding utility to the sorcerer. Relic Hunter and Monster Tactician replace the combat buffs with more useful abilities. Even better, Empyreal bloodline gives you excellent Wis synergy as a casting stat and bonus to Inititiative and, with the right inquisition, social skills. Stick to casting with one of the aforementioned Inquisitor archetypes, or if your stats are good enough try a reach build.

Inquisitor//Spiritualist

Basics: Med BAB, d8, Fort and Will, 6 skills+, two 6-level casting, physical Wis

Inquisitor // Summoner

Basics: Med BAB, d8, Fort and Will, 6 skills+, two 6-level casting, physical Wis Cha

Inquisitor wants to enter combat, summoner isn't so sure. The MAD doesn't help. Teamwork feats are easier to use with an eidolon around, and the eidolon can also benefit if it takes those feats.

Inquisitor // Swashbuckler

Basics: Full BAB, d10, all saves, 6 skills+, 6-level casting, Dex Wis Cha

Decent melee base with self-buffing and utility. Not very versatile in combat. Takes a lot of swift actions - consider Relic Hunter for more long term buffs. Alternatively, Paladin//Swashbuckler for better stat synergy.

Inquisitor // Warpriest

Basics: Med BAB, d8, Fort and Will, 6 skills+, two 6-level casting, physical Wis

Definite issues here. You don't want to focus on casting (or you'd play Inquisitor//Cleric) but you've got only average BAB/HD. You need a lot of buffing to make up that gap, but most of your buffs are swift actions (Judgment, Bane, Fervor, Sacred Weapon). You can make it work, but it's tricky and will lag behind builds pairing either Inquisitor or Warpriest with a suitable full BAB class. Consider Relic Hunter Inquisitor to replace Judgment and Bane with passive benefits.

Inquisitor // Witch (Living Grimoire)

Basics: Med BAB, d8, Fort and Will, 6 skills+, full and 6-level casting, Int Wis

Inquisitor // Wizard (Relic Hunter, Monster Tactician, Living Grimoire)

Basics:  Med BAB, d8, Fort and Will, 6 skills+, full and 6-level casting, Int Wis

No casting stat synergy. Inquisitor can't carry this one in combat but doesn't provide much help for a casting build without the Relic Hunter (but see Occultist//Wizard) or Monster Tactician, which is useful in a small party for throwing more bodies on the field before opening up with Wizard casting. Living Grimoire is also an option – it doesn't add to your casting like the previous two, but SAD is nice and you're at least getting most of the Inquisitor utility. Strongly consider Investigator//Wizard.

Investigator

A canny and versatile class, the investigator has a lot of things that frontliners want – extra saves, lots of skills, magical utility, and two juicy combat self-buffs. Studied Combat can be activated as a move action (swift with Quick Study), while Mutagen is available starting at level 3 as a long-duration prebuff. Int-based casters also pair fairly well with the Investigator, but usually the Alchemist is a better match thanks to its strong Fort save and access to the Cognatagen (which the investigator, oddly, doesn't get).

Investigator//Kineticist

Basics: Med BAB, d8, all saves, 6 skills+, 6-level and pseudo-casting, Con Dex Int

Studied Combat and Studied Strike work with the kinetic blade and encourage melee style – if you want ranged blasting, go Alchemist//Kineticist. This is a good combination for the Elemental Annihilator – Investigator provides plenty of utility, devastating infusion compensates for the fact that you're not actually Full BAB, and the static damage bonuses from both classes make TWF very effective. Quick Study makes sure that studied combat doesn't get in the way of gather power (or full attacks) and the Con mutagen is also a big boost.

Investigator // Magus

Basics: Med BAB, d8, all saves, 6 skills+, two 6-level casting, Int & physical

Studied Combat is really handy for the Magus since it gives you a damage and accuracy booster that doesn't drain your arcane pool or spell slots – and is more reliable than the Sneak Attack you could get from the vivisectionist alchemist. You end up with greater than full BAB. Mutagen is useful for you as long as you watch out for the Int penalty on the Str boosting version – consider a rapier-based Dex build. Good stat synergy, especially with the Empiricist archetype which reduces your need for Wis and Cha. The biggest downside is that you can't use your extracts with spell combat.

Investigator//Medium

Basics: Med BAB, d8, Ref and Will, 6 skills+, casting, physical Int Cha

The archmage and hierophant are disappointing since the seance boon (and crafting feats) don't work with your extracts, and you probably can't afford both an Int and Cha good enough for serious casting. Champion is your best bet, and it's not a bad one – though you'll probably occasionally want other spirits if you anticipate an unusual day.

Investigator//Mesmerist

Basics: Med BAB, d8, Ref and Will, 6 skills+, two 6-level casting, physical (?) Int Cha

Investigator // Monk (Unchained)

Basics: Med/Full BAB, d8/d10, all saves, 6 skills+, 6-level casting, physical Int Wis

MAD and swift action heavy, but quite nice with Unchained which can make good use of Investigator buffs and the studied combat bonus. Compared to the Monk//Rogue you have less peak damage and need to manage your actions more carefully, but all good saves and more support versatility with extracts. Avoid Zen Archer since there isn't great stat synergy and you need an extra feat for ranged studied combat. Sohei is not bad if you really don't want to invest in Wis.

Investigator // Occultist

Basics: Med BAB, d8, all saves, 6 skills+, two 6-level casting, Int and physical

For a resourceful and analytical character who is always after the truth. Between Studied Combat and Transmutation implements, you're able to buff yourself into combat competence  and still have tons of non-combat tricks up your sleeve. Divination implements are a useful and thematic choice. You'll want Trappings of the Warrior eventually, but it can probably wait until level 6 or even 10.

Investigator // Oracle

Basics: Med BAB, d8, Ref and Will, 6 skills+, full and partial casting, Cha Int (physical?)

Decent enough for support and utility, with the potential to pick up a weapon in a pinch with Studied Combat, but synergy is mediocre.

Investigator // (Anti)Paladin

Basics: Full BAB, d10, all saves +, 6 skills+, 6 and 4-level casting, physical Cha Int

Powerful and durable in melee, lots of utility, and some support and debuff potential. The biggest challenge here is managing your swift actions, since both the Investigator and Paladin rely on them for buffing. The second biggest challenge is stats. If you're having trouble covering the stats, consider Archaeologist Bard//Paladin.

Investigator // Ranger

Basics: Full BAB, d10, all saves, 6 skills+, 6 and 4-level casting, physical Int Wis

Strong in melee, and can work well at ranged with archery combat style and the Ranged Study feat. Tons of utility. Stat-intensive.

Investigator//Psychic

Basics: Med BAB, d8, Ref and Will, 6 skills+, full and 6-level casting, Int and Wis or Cha

Excellent mastermind with mundane and magical investigation and manipulation abilities, lots of support magic, and some debuffing. Studied Combat is a good enough buff to make you a competent melee combatant in a pinch as long as you put a little effort into physical stats – I recommend Weapon Finesse. Consider Studied Defense if you don't expect to be on the offensive much. Psychic Detective is redundant and not recommended despite letting you use psychic Phrenic Amplifications on Investigator effects.

Investigator // Rogue

Basics: Med BAB, d8, Ref and Will, 8 skills+, 6-level casting

Studied Combat adds important accuracy and Studied Strike can be used with Sneak Attack, so this is actually quite good. Your first few rogue talents should probably be the combat feats (finesse, weapon focus, and combat trick). Take a rogue archetype to replace the duplicate Trap Sense – lots of them do, though they aren't much good. Or, if you have good enough stats for a charisma bonus, take Ninja instead and get access to more tricks.[a]

Investigator // Skald

Basics: Med BAB, d8, all saves, 6 skills+, two 6-level casting, Int Cha & physical

Investigator // Slayer

Basics: Full BAB, d10, all saves, 6 skills+, 6-level casting, physical & Int

Though it feels a bit weird, you can combine all your key combat boosts – Studied Target, Studied Combat, Sneak Attack, and Studied Strike – though Quarry overlaps. This gives you massive static bonuses on attacks with, at higher levels, relatively little setup. TWF is extremely effective under these circumstances. Consider Two-Weapon Feint, which makes it easier to get in sneak attacks – you can qualify as early as level 3. The Combat Expertise prerequisite is also useful for converting some of your massive accuracy bonus to a defensive bonus. You can apply debuffs using both your Sneak Attack and Studied Strike, with saves based on Int for both, and have tons of skill and utility options.

Investigator // Sorcerer (Sage)

Basics: Med BAB, d8, Ref and Will, 6 skills+, full and partial casting, Cha Int

Focus on buffs with Investigator and you don't need much Int.

Investigator//Spiritualist

Basics: Med BAB, d8, all saves, 6 skills+, casting

Investigator // Summoner (Synth)

Basics: Med BAB, d8, Ref and Will, 6 skills+, two 6-level casting, Int Cha physical?

Increased versatility in your spell list, but not much synergy. Synthesist can be competent in melee. Bard//Summoner is significantly better.

Investigator // Swashbuckler (Inspired Blade)

Basics: Full BAB, d10, Ref and Will, 6 skills+, 6-level casting, Dex Int Cha

Dex mutagen is a big boon for buckling swashes. Studied Strike and Precise strike are both precision damage, which makes you a bit overspecialized, but Studied Combat at least is an insight bonus. Inspired Blade gives you a bit more kick for your Int, which is enough to take the combo up a step. Consider Empiricist if you want to focus even more on Int, though since you're already motivated to have a good Dex and Cha it won't make a big difference.

Investigator // Warpriest

Basics: Med BAB, d8, all saves, 6 skills+, two 6-level casting, Int Wis & physical

MAD, and needs a lot of swift actions to buff you up from average BAB. Consider Arsenal Chaplain or Mantis Zealot to cut down on swift actions on the warpriest side. Alternatively, using Studied Target as a move action works fairly well with Vital Strike.

Investigator // Witch

Basics: Med BAB, d8, Ref and Will, 6 skills+, full and 6-level casting, Int

Mindchemist//Witch is a better gestalt, but that doesn't mean that this one's bad – you get a lot of skills, some useful extracts, and a lot of int synergy (especially with the Empiricist). You'll also be able to stand up in melee if you have to. Studied Defense is worth a look since you won't find the to-hit bonus as useful as characters with a more martial focus – though note that Studied Combat and Studied Strike both work just fine with the White-Haired Witch's attacks.

Investigator // Wizard

Basics:  Med BAB, d8, Ref and Will, 6+skills, full and 6-level casting, Int

As above, it's usually better to take Mindchemist over Investigator, but if you really want skills in addition to your arcane goodness, this will do fine. The Divination school is thematic.

Kineticist

Broadly, you have three options.

First, focus on blasts. Your second class should be a martial class that can improve your blasts. This means general bonuses to weapon damage like Studied Combat – not effects that improve manufactured weapons or spells. Gestalting with partial casters can work well for ranged energy blasters who don't care as much about accuracy or HP. Elemental Annihilator and Kinetic Knight are good archetypes for blast-happy builds, with the latter serving as a heavy armour melee-only option.

Second, elementally enhance attacks with Kinetic Fist or Energize Weapon. This adds a little more than half a point of damage per kineticist level to your attacks – mediocre, and it costs burn until level 5, but after that it's an unlimited bonus. You can also debuff with substance infusions if you can handle the burn. Some of the defence talents are excellent, and ranged and area blasts and utility talents add some versatility. For this type of build the other gestalt half needs to handle the martial style. Note that Energize Weapon is more limited than Kinetic Fist – it works on only a single weapon (no TWF) and only with energy blasts (no terrakinetic weapons). Air is a good elemental choice for Energize Weapon builds using electric blasts, the magnetic infusion (free with energize weapon at level 11) and wings of air. Note also that holding manufactured weapons prevents you from gathering power.

Third, combine with a full caster for improved durability and  extra combat options. Single element builds are safer as casting gestalts since the casting half provides more strategic versatility.

See also Rylar's guide to gestalting the kineticist.

Kineticist // Medium

Basics: Med BAB, d8, all saves, 4 skills, partial casting, Con Dex Cha

This is most effective as a kinetic blade user, making use of the champion's abilities enhancing full attacks. Note however that it's not quite clear whether blasts count as “spells” for purposes of the damage bonuses that the spirits grant, meaning that the damage bonus may or may not apply to blade attacks.

Kineticist//Mesmerist

Basics: Med BAB, d8, all saves, 6 skills, 6-level and pseudo-casting, Dex Con Cha

Kineticist // Monk (Unchained)

Basics: Med/Full BAB, d8/d10, all saves/Fort and Ref, 4 skills, pseudo-casting, physical Wis

Ultimate bender it's not. Since monk doesn't give you anything to enhance blasts, you're forced into strategy two: Kinetic Fist or Energize Weapon. This means you really need the Unchained Monk's full BAB and HD. Hydrokineticist's defence is particularly useful when you don't wear armour. For other options mixing fists and elemental magic, check out Monk//Druid, Monk//Empyreal Sorcerer, Kineticist//Brawler, and Kineticist (Elemental Ascetic)//Cleric (Ecclesitheurge).

Kineticist // Occultist

Basics: Med BAB, d8, all saves, 4 skills, 6-level and pseudo-casting, Con Dex Int

Trappings of the Warrior doesn't work with blasts, so I suggest using energy blasts for better accuracy. There aren't a whole lot of synergistic options aside from Transmutation's resonant power and maybe a Haunted (Champion) implement – Legacy Weapon doesn't work on blasts (though you can use it on friends' weapons). That means you're looking for defensive options and versatility. Try to coordinate spell, power, and talent selections. For example, an aerokineticist probably wants celerity instead of the quickness focus power – in contrast, conjuration implements do a better job than kinetic healer. Evocation is generally inferior to and doesn't synergize with your blasts, but it does provide alternative energy options and force effect. This makes it useful as a fallback option, especially for single-element builds.

Kineticist // Oracle

Basics: Med BAB, d8, all saves,  4 skills, full and pseudo-casting, Con Dex Cha

Not a lot of synergy, but decent versatility. Divine Power and similar buffs are helpful with blasts. With a relatively low HD and BAB, consider staying at range for safety and/or using energy blasts for better accuracy. Thematically tempting to overspecialize, for example with a Pyrokineticist//Flame Oracle. Try to instead pick complementary elements & mysteries, such as Fire & Solar, or Void & Dark Tapestry. Note that the Dance of the Blades and Wood Bond powers only work when wielding an appropriate weapon, so they don't help with metal or wood blasts.

Kineticist // (Anti)Paladin (Geokineticist)

Basics: Full BAB, d10, all saves +, 4 skills, 4 level casting, Con Dex Cha

Versatile combo with some synergistic ability. Blasts provide melee and ranged combat options with relatively little feat investment, and infusions allow debuffing. Smite makes your blasts more lethal and also allows them to bypass DR (a major weakness for physical blasts). Though Lay on Hands doesn't remove burn it does make it less dangerous and also provides a healing option. Depending on element you can also pick up added defenses or utility. Geo wins because

Kineticist // Psychic

Basics: Med BAB, d8, all saves,  4 skills, full and pseudo-casting, Dex Con Int and Wis or Cha

Kineticist // Ranger

Basics: Full BAB, d10, Fort and Ref, 6 skills, 4-level and pseudo-casting, Dex Con Wis

Combat styles are not all that useful (unless you're an Elemental Annihilator) but all kineticists can at least use some of the ranged feats, and favoured enemy applies, so combat abilities synergise reasonably well. Mounted Combat is also an option if you want to ride your animal companion. Good assortment of utility and defensive abilities depending on build.

Kineticist // Rogue (Telekineticist)

Basics: Med BAB, d8, Fort and Ref, 8 skills, pseudo-casting

Sneak attack does work with blasts and being able to hit touch AC helps with accuracy, though your defenses aren't great when you take burn into account. You do get access to some pretty nice utility – telekineticist deserves special mention for its ability to use sleight of hand and disable device at range and its at-will invisibility starting at level 6. You also get the ability to sense invisible things in turn. Aerokinesis is a good second choice for flight and an electric blast.

I'm right now playing a Telekineticist/Rogue (Phantom Thief). He's a LOT of fun. 

Kineticist // Skald

Basics: Med BAB, d8, Fort and Ref, 4 skills, casting

Kineticist // Slayer

Basics: Full BAB, d10, Fort and Ref, 6 skills, pseudo-casting, Con Dex Int

Strong combat presence with good utility. Blue assuming you can use studied target on blasts – sneak attack definitely works but is not as reliable a bonus. Between the two bonuses, melee is a more effective strategy, but you're pretty effective at switch hitting as with just Precise Shot from the archery style. Telekineticist notably grants invisibility and some long-range thievery skills, but any element is a good choice.

Kineticist // Sorcerer

Basics: Med BAB, d8, all saves, 4 skills, full casting, Con Cha Dex

While different in format, the abilities from each class can do very similar things (such as blasting, flight, and invisibility), so make careful selections to avoid overlap. Spell damage bonuses from your bloodlines don't affect your blasts, so consider using the sorcerer magic to do things other than blasting. Overwhelming Soul makes you  more SAD, but also limits your ability to use the more powerful kineticist abilities so it's a bit of a wash.

Kineticist//Spiritualist (Ectoplasmatist)

Basics: Med BAB, d8, all saves, 4 skills, casting

Kineticist // Summoner

Basics: Med BAB, d8, all saves, 4 skills, 6-level and pseudo-casting, Con Dex Cha

Good number of options here, but not much synergy – features from your two classes just don't overlap.

Kineticist // Swashbuckler

Basics: Full BAB, d10, Fort and Ref, 4 skills, pseudo-casting, Dex Con Cha

As far as I can tell, your kinetic blade is considered a light or one-handed piercing weapon as long as you pick a blast type that does piercing damage – so start with Earth, Aether, or Wood, with composite blasts from Earth, Void (Gravity), Air, Fire (with wood only), or Water (cold, with wood only). If I'm right about this, you get a strong melee focus with ranged capability. Depending on build you can also get moderate to excellent defense, mobility, battlefield control, and utility. If you can't use Swash stuff with Kinetic Blade, don't bother.

Kineticist // Warpriest

Basics: Med BAB, d8, all saves, 4 skills, 6-level and pseudo-casting, Con Dex Wis

Sacred Weapon won't help your blasts, and you shouldn't need the bonus feats, so Kineticist//Cleric or //Paladin is better. If you really want to go this route, consider Mantis Zealot to replace Sacred Weapon with Sneak Attack. Sacred Fist is OK with Kinetic Fist – still not an ideal style, but probably better than Elemental Ascetic (note: don't combine the two).

Kineticist // Witch (Old Scarred Witch Doctor)

Basics: Med BAB, d8, all saves, 4 skills, full casting, Int Con Dex

Durable enough for a caster/blaster, with lots of debuffing and some support and control options. Between simple blasts and hexes you can basically go all day, and still have the potential to throw down high level spells or accept burn when you want to pick it up a notch. If you're using the pre-eratta SWD this goes up to blue/purple thanks to fantastic Con synergy.

Kineticist // Wizard

Basics: Med BAB, d8, all saves, 4 skills, full casting, Int Con Dex

The kineticist provides a boost in durability, extra potential for spontenaity, and more low-level staying power on top of the versatility of the wizard. While most casting features don't boost blasts, you can get double mileage out of Spell Penetration and Elemental Focus.

Magus

The action economy advantage of spell combat is really strong in gestalt, and makes the Magus one of the best classes to combine with spellcasters, especially Int-based ones. Broad Study lets you use your gestalt spells with your magus abilities at level 6. The magus also does fairly well with full-BAB classes that complement its one-handed combat style. Psychic classes can be problematic because their thought components make spells difficult to cast defensively, which the magus does frequently. The magus tends to be a bit more MAD so avoid classes that require Wis or Cha. Also keep in mind that the magus is very swift action heavy. Eldritch Scion would appear to make a good fit for Charisma-based classes, but the delay in Spell Combat and the requirement to refresh your Mystic Focus every two rounds to use magus abilities is a very steep price.

Kensai is a strong archetype when paired with most non-armour wearing classes, thanks to its unarmouerd defense. Spire Defender is worth looking at for gestalts that get armour proficiency from their non-magus side, since you get Combat Expertise, Dodge, and a minor skill bonus in exchange for just Spell Recall. Eldritch Archer supports a ranged combat style, and Myrmidarch works both in melee and at range and gains access to Weapon Training, at the cost of some magical power.

Magus // Medium */*

Basics: Med BAB, d8, Fort and Will, 4 skills, two partial casting, physical Int Cha

The champion's best abilities don't work with spell combat, and the archmage's flexibility doesn't mean as much for a prepared caster – plus you only have average BAB, and are MAD. Don't bother.

Magus // Mesmerist **

Basics: Med BAB, d8, all saves, 6 skills, two 6-level casting, physical Int Cha

Tricks and Stare are handy, but your stats are spread too thin and your BAB is low.

Magus // Monk */*

Basics: Med/Full BAB, d8/d10, all saves, 4 skills, 6-level casting, physical Int Wis

MAD, unarmed strikes aren't the best weapons for the magus, and Spell Combat and Flurry are not compatible since they are both pseudo-TWF. By working carefully to mitigate these issues you could make something halfway functional (moving the combo from red to yellow). General strategies:

  • Use Ascetic Style (temple sword) to improve your crit range. Costs 2-4 feats depending on how far up the chain you go, and a swift action to activate.
  • Use multi-touch spells, which work better than one-off spells if you plan to alternate between spell combat and flurry, and conserve your relatively limited spell slots.

Specific archetype combinations:

  • Eldritch Scion//Unchained Scaled Fist reduces MAD by swapping both classes to Cha-based, and gives you full BAB and HD. Eldritch Scion’s low-level restrictions on spell combat are less onerous when you can Flurry instead.
  • Eldritch Archer//Zen Archer. The main synergy here is simply specializing in the same weapon, but both archetypes are pretty good at that, so this mostly works. Note that while you can’t use Spell Combat or Manyshot with Flurry, you can take Manyshot as a monk bonus feat and use it with Spell Combat. If you do this, skip Rapid Shot - the attack penalty isn’t worth it.
  • Master of Many Styles // Kensai (temple sword), AKA “Sword Style Master.” The bonus Weapon Focus feat qualifies you for Ascetic Style at level 1, and you can combine it with other styles. Take Combat Style Master at level 5 to eliminate the pesky swift action cost, and at level 8 your always on +3 to attack mitigates the loss of full BAB. Canny Defense gives you extra unarmoured AC. Better in a game with a generous stat allotment and not too many combats per day - between diminished spellcasting and the lack of Flurry getting in the way of Spell Combat, you’ll run out of spells fast.

Tiefling Martial artist monk+Fiend Flayer Magus to reduce effect of taking Con damage for arcane pool pts

Magus // Occultist ***

Basics: Med BAB, d8, Fort and Will, 4 skills, two 6-level casting, physical & Int

This gish//gish is not as reliable and durable as a good gish//martial, nor does it have the raw world-bending power of a gish//full arcane. You've also got two significant conflicts. First, Trappings of the Warrior requires a shield, which interferes with spell combat unless you take Skirnir, which doesn't come together until it actually gets spell combat at level 8 and thus is un-advisable unless you start at high levels. Second, spell combat doesn't work with focus powers so it doesn't improve the occultist's action economy as much as one would like. However, you've got a versatile set of abilities and some methods for keeping your swordmagery respectable.  Offensive tips:

  • Transmutation implements are a must. Legacy weapon stacks with the arcane pool enhancement, allowing you to get a +1 bane (whatever) weapon right out the gate.
  • Haunt Collector archetype is strongly recommended. Champion spirit gives you a passive weapon damage bonus and a short-term boost to attack rolls based on focus invested. Archmage also adds to spell damage with a short-term Int still boost for utility. Haunt implements that have poor resonant powers but good spell lists and ideally some good focus powers. Necromancy implements are a great choice; see also conjuration, enchantment, and illusion.
  • Evocation implement adds a modest extra bonus to evocation spells. The focus power Radiance also works well with a typical crit-fishing magus.
  • Your to-hit is low, so take Weapon Focus and consider Arcane Accuracy and Accurate Strike Arcana.

Use occultist spontaneous casting for staples like Shield or things that aren't on the magus list, which include by school:

  • Abjuration – A couple utility spells like Alarm, Arcane Lock, and Nondetection, plus Resist and Protection from Energy, Magic Circle Against [], Break Enchantment, Dimensional Anchor, Freedom of Movement, Globe of Invulnerability, Spell Immunity, Life Bubble, and Antimagic Field.
  • Conjuration – The biggest thing here is Cure access, but as a bonus you get Mage Armour, Minor Creation, Major Creation, and Create Demiplane.
  • Divination – Everything worthwhile except Detect/Read Magic, Arcane Sight and True Seeing.
  • Enchantment – Basically everything; magi don't do enchantment.
  • Evocation –  A handful of spells: Frost Fall, Call Lightning, Deeper Darkness,  Invisibility Purge, Tiny Hut, Resilient Sphere,  Sending, Call Lightning Storm, Blade Barrier, Contingency.
  • Illusion – Disguise Self, Magic Aura, Disguise Other, Misdirection, Invisibility Sphere, Greater Invisibility, Illusory Wall, Permanent Image
  • Necromancy – Most spells, including False Life, the Inflict line, and Harm.
  • Transmutation – Mostly a range of utility spells such as Ant Haul, Pass Without Trace, Air Step, Darkvision, Knock, Make Whole, Rope Trick, Warp Wood, Wood Shape, Shrink Item, Air Walk, Echolocation, Control Winds, and Fabricate. Also a handful of combat spells: Lead Blades, Versatile Weapon (early-access) Magic Vestment, Rusting Grasp, Transmute Rock to Mud.

Magus // Oracle **/*

Basics: Med BAB, d8, Fort and Will, 4 skills, full and 6-level casting, physical Int Cha

MAD is a pain, BAB is a pain, defences aren't great. Decent variety of spells, and action economy is good. Broad Study helps you get the most out of nasty touch spells. Consider the Wind mystery for the Vortex Spells revelation, which will stagger your target on a spellstrike crit. Also, flight. Add warsighted if you don't like many of the other revelations. Lore is a good alternative for defraying MAD. Note that Winter’s Freezing Spells revelation does not work with Frostbite.

Magus // (Anti)Paladin

Basics: Full BAB, d10, all saves +, 2 skills, 6- and 4-level casting, physical Int Cha

MAD, and your best abilities are almost all competing for your swift actions. On the other hand, they are good abilities. Deep Marshal//Stonelord is an interesting archetype combination thematically and it gets rid of your MAD issue by reducing your need for Cha (lay on hands uses only) and Dex (you get medium armour immediately); biggest downside is needing to use dwarven weapons on a magus.

Magus // Psychic ***

Basics: Med BAB, d8, Fort and Will, 2 skills+, full and 6-level casting, physical Int and Wis or Cha

I would like to be more excited about this, but the extra mental stat requirement compared to a Magus//Witch or Wizard and the existence of the Kensai for armour issues makes the Psychic a little less shiny. There's also the fact that the thought component makes psychic spells difficult to cast defensively as the magus often does (the Intense Focus amplification helps). Still, you get magus action economy with an extended array of spells, including a broad selection of divination and enchantment and some good staple buffs for spontaneous casting.  Decent choice if you want lots of casting with a non-Kensai archetype like Myrmidarch.

Magus // Ranger (Myrmidarch, Skirnir, Eldritch Archer)

Basics: Full BAB, d10, all saves, 6 skills, 6- and 4-level casting, physical Int Wis

Slayer works better with the typical magus einhander style. However, switch-hitting works with Myrmidarch, shield bashing with Skirnir, and archery is extremely effective with the Eldritch Archer. Divine Marksman is a good archetype for archers or switch hitters, and since it gets rid of Ranger spellcasting it removes your need for an above-average Wis.

Magus // Rogue **

Basics: Med BAB, d8, all saves, 8 skills, 6-level casting, physical Int

The biggest draw is the no-strings-attached Dex to damage. You can also use Dimensional Assault to flank with yourself, which makes landing your first Debilitating Injury (AC debuff) easier, and you’ll get buckets of skill ranks. Sylvan Trickster’s hexes make good use of high Int but can’t be used with Spell Combat or Spellstrike. Alternatively, consider Kensai//Eldritch Scoundrel for more magical versatility at the cost of some skill ranks and sneak attack progression. Still, expect accuracy and durability issues. If you can do without Rogue’s Finesse consider Magus//Slayer for better martial ability, or gestalt either Magus or Rogue with a full caster if that's your focus.

Magus // Skald

Basics: Med BAB, d8, all saves, 4 skills, casting

Magus // Slayer ****

Basics: Full BAB, d10, all saves, 6 skills, 6-level casting, physical Int

Excellent set of combat and utility abilities. You can pick up extra combat feats like Weapon Finesse or Weapon Focus, take archery style feats (with the Eldritch Archer, or Myrmidarch for switch hitting) or grab shield bashing with Skirnir. Quarry lets you automatically confirm crits, which is great if you've got spell damage riding on it. The dimensional dervish feat chain lets you flank with yourself for an easier sneak attack. A little heavy on the swift actions, but not too badly.

Magus // Sorcerer *** (Kensai + Sage *****)

Basics: Med BAB, d8, Fort and Will, 2 skills, full and 6-level casting, physical Int Cha

Being able to spam basic combat spells is very nice. Stat Synergy and unarmoured AC are super important here, so Kensai and Sage bloodline make a big difference. If your GM will let you combine Wildblooded with other archetypes, consider taking Crossblooded with a combat bloodline, or adding Eldritch Scrapper for flexible combat feats.

Magus // Spiritualist

Basics: Med BAB, d8, Fort and Will, 4 skills, casting

Magus // Summoner ** (Synthesist ***)

Basics: Med BAB, d8, Fort and Will, 2 skills, two 6-level casting, physical Int Cha

Not enough personal combat ability to hold its own, not enough casting to rely on that. Synthesist is a bit more workable because it makes it easier to afford the physical stats you need and adds personal combat abilities. Note that because the Synth can't wear armour, Kensai is a solid choice here.

Magus // Swashbuckler *** (Inspired Blade ****)

Basics: Full BAB, d10, all saves, 4 skills, 6-level casting, Dex Int Cha

The swashbuckler's fighting style synergises well with the magus (Precise Strike works with spell combat) and the bonus feats are very welcome. Inspired Blade's Int to panache is the reason you're not taking Daring Champion. Unfortunately Fencing Grace no longer works with Spell Combat, but the rapier is still a decent weapon, and you can get it Agile. Since you automatically qualify for Fencing  Grace, it might even be worth taking it for Dex to damage when not using spell combat before you can afford Agile. Both classes use a lot of swift actions so look for archetypes and feats granting passive abilities.

Magus // Warpriest **

Basics: Med BAB, d8, Fort and Will, 2 skills, htwo 6-level casting, physical Wis Int

MAD, uses too many swift actions, and too much overlap on the basics. That said, the action economy is excellent (Fervor + Spell Combat = two spells and a full attack), so this is worth considering if you have really good stats. Dervish Dance is very helpful in this respect.

Magus // Witch **** (Kensai, Hexcrafter, White Haired Witch)

Basics: Med BAB, d8, Fort and Will, 2 skills+, full and 6-level casting, physical Int

Magus // Wizard **** (Kensai *****)

Basics: Med BAB, d8, Fort and Will, 2 skills+, full and 6-level casting, physical Int

You're a wizard who gets an additional Int-based partial casting progression and can also function in combat with good action economy, so right off the bat this is pretty cool. Kensai is an obvious choice since you get Int to AC instead of the armour that would interfere with your wizard spells. You also get Int to initiative, number of AoO, crit confirmation, and surprise round damage, plus some other minor bonuses. Diminished spellcasting and loss of spell knowledge and knowledge pool are less important when you have full wizard casting backing you up. While a Diviner specialization will skyrocket your initiative, consider also Evocation (Admixture) for making sure your Shocking Grasp always uses the right energy type, or Transmutation (Enhancement) if your stats and AC still need buffing. Accuracy may be a  little low. You can boost it with Weapon Focus (which Kensai gets for free), Accurate Strike arcana, and prioritizing weapon enhancement bonus over properties.

Medium

The medium is best as a “secondary” class for gestalt, which is to say that you should use your other class to define your usual tactics and then use spirits to either supplement your primary role or increase versatility.  This works best with full-BAB classes, since the Champion and to a lesser extent the Guardian offer good combat abilities for general use and most martials will get a lot out of the ability to select increased casting or skill abilities for specific missions; the good Will save is an added bonus. If the proficiencies granted by the Champion and Guardian are irrelevant, you don't have to worry about losing proficiency with key gear when you pick a different spirit and can channel a weaker spirit at levels 1-5 for extra spirit surge.  However, casters can also benefit from the seance bonuses of the archmage or hierophant and from the choice between expanded spell options, various skill or defence options, and (for some) the champion's ability to enter combat.

Consider Spirit Dancer for more flexibility in switching between spirits. Also note that while the medium's psychic spells aren't subject to armour spell failure, the ones they get from the archmage spirit are arcane and can be spoiled by your armour.

Medium//Mesmerist

Basics: Med BAB, d8, Ref and Will, 6 skills, two partial casting, physical Cha

Medium // Monk (Unchained Scaled Fist)

Basics: Med/Full BAB, d8/d10, all saves, 4 skills, partial casting, physical Cha Wis

Unchained Scaled Fist gives you two key things: full BAB and stat synergy. The champion is underwhelming since sudden attack doesn't work with flurry of blows and flying kick gives you mobility without fleet charge. The spirit bonus is still welcome in combat and you can channel a weaker spirit to get extra surge, but consider a Guardian or Marshal instead at higher levels. A nice perk of this build is that unlike most martial//mediums you can use the archmage without worrying about armour.

Medium//Occultist

Basics: Med BAB, d8, Fort and Will, 4 skills, two partial casting, physical Int Cha

Quite a lot of day-to-day flexibility between your spirits and allocating your mental focus, but it's going to take a lot of work to fill any role competently, and the stat requirements are hefty.

Medium // Oracle

Basics: Med BAB, d8, Will, 4 skills, full and partial casting, Cha (and physical?)

While the single good save hurts, the Oracle definitely benefits from the increased spell flexibility of the archmage and hierophant and can benefit from both seance bonuses. A modest investment in longspear reach tactics gives you a good non-spell option and lets you fill in for a frontliner with the Champion or Guardian spirit. The arcane staples on the medium's base list (haste, heroism) are also appreciated no matter the spirit. Bonus: thematic synergy between channeling spirits and the oracle's mysterious power.

Medium // (Anti)Paladin

Basics: Full BAB, d10, Fort and Will+, 4 skills, two 4-level casting, physical and Cha

Armour spell failure will be a bit of a problem for the archmage, but otherwise the . The hierophant's paladin code taboo is a freebie for you since you already need to follow it.

Medium // Psychic

Basics: Med BAB, d8, Will, 4 skills, full and partial casting, Int Cha

This combination is more fragile than I like, but the Medium does add day-to-day versatility to the spontaneous Psychic. Heirophant and Marshall are most complementary since they add support capability with the ability to wear armour, but the others could still be useful in some situations. Aside from spells borrowed from spirits, the medium's list is largely a subset of the Psychic's – though that still lets you pick up a few more spells known, and you can use them with phrenic amplifications.

Medium // Ranger

Basics: Full BAB, d10, all saves, 6 skills, partial casting, physical Wis Cha

TWF and archery work really well with the Champion's damage bonus. Don't invest too many resources in casting, though with a decent stat allotment you'll be able to take advantage of the magical flexibility of the Archmage and Hierophant; remember that some archery feats benefit rays.

Medium // Rogue

Basics: Med BAB, d8, all saves, 8 skills, partial casting, physical and Cha

Medium // Skald

Basics: Med BAB, d8, all saves, 4 skills, casting, physical and Cha

Medium // Slayer

Basics: Full BAB, d10, all saves, 6 skills, partial casting, physical Cha Int?

TWF and archery work really well with the Champion's damage bonus.

Medium // Sorcerer

Basics: Med BAB, d8, Will, 4 skills, full and partial casting, Cha (and physical?) 

The archmage seance bonus is pretty useful for a blaster sorcerer, and the ability to select different daily spells greatly increases your flexibility. You can also use hierophant to get access to completely new spells powered by the same casting stat, feats, items, etc. You're a bit fragile, though, since you can't use the medium's armour proficiency.

Medium//Spiritualist

Basics: Med BAB, d8, Fort and Will, 4 skills, casting

Medium // Summoner

Basics: Med BAB, d8, Will, 4 skills, two partial casting, Cha

Unless you're a synthesist, build for casting. The summoner doesn't otherwise get enough combat abilities to make a credible threat in gestalt, even with champion. If you want to give the champion's seance bonus to allies, use marshal. If you plan on using summoned monsters and not just the eidolon, strongly consider spirit dancer so you can grant summoned creatures your seance bonus.

Medium // Swashbuckler

Basics: Full BAB, d10, Ref and Will, 4 skills, partial casting, Dex Cha

This is a good choice if you want to emphasize the medium thematically and to use a variety of different spirits. The swashbuckler supplies reliable combat competence without requiring much investment in feats or stats. This means that while all martials will be effective when channeling the champion, you'll also have the charisma and casting feats to back up the archmage or hierophant (and a decent AC if you doff armour to avoid impeding the archmage's casting).

Medium // Warpriest

Basics: Med BAB, d8, Fort and Will, 4 skills, partial casting, physical Wis Cha

Works OK for TWF and archery between the champion's static damage bonus and the warpriest's sacred weapons and bonus feats. However accuracy is low and you'll rely heavily on the champion spirit for your combat contribution, meaning switching out spirits is risky business. Using paladin or battle oracle instead of warpriest is recommended.

Medium// Witch

Basics: Med BAB, d8, Will, 4 skills, full and partial casting, Int Cha

Medium // Wizard

Basics: Med BAB, d8, Will, 4 skills, full and partial casting, Int Cha

I highly recommend Medium//Sorcerer instead; the archmage's spell flexibility isn't nearly as useful for the wizard as the sorcerer, and you need an extra stat.

Mesmerist

Similar to the bard but more debuff-focused, the Mesmerist works well with charisma-based warriors and casters. Warriors benefit from increased utility, better saves, and some the swift and free action debuffs and control effects associated with the Mesmerist's Stare and Trick abilities, and from the ability to use traditionally arcane defenses like Displacement with armour. Note that with Painful Stare putting a lot of hurt behind your first hit in a round, this works very well with builds that don't normally full attack (large vital strikers, chargers, reach builds). Casters benefit in particular from the Stare's ability to weaken Will saves or SR, and have an easier time maintaining a high enough Charisma to get the most out of the Mesmerist's spells, which often require saving throws. Because of this trend towards spells with saves, Mesmerist is particularly sensitive to MAD gestalts.

Enigma – invisibility, 4d6 sneak

Fey Trickster – Hunter spell list, nature powers

Mesmerist // Monk (Unchained Scaled Fist)

Basics: Med BAB, d8, all saves, 6 skills, 6-level casting, physical Cha Wis

Not enough casting for a caster focus. Unchained Scaled Fist gives you an OK martial base and Cha synergy. Consider Bard//Monk or Mesmerist//Bloody Knuckle Bloodrager. Building this one without Scaled Fist leaves you uncomfortably MAD, though if you have really good stats you might try a reach build with Sohei.

Mesmerist // Occultist (Silksworn)

Basics: Med BAB, d8, all saves, 6 skills, two 6-level casting, Int Cha  physical

Strong utility, but the MAD is a problem for your offence. You could use Trappings of the Warrior and Haunt Collector to work up a passable martial presence, but Bard//Occultist works better for that. In an intrigue-based game, you'll get good mileage out of Silksworn as it gives you more focus to work with, more magical versatility, and some sneaky/social benefits. The mesmerist is pretty focused on enchantment and illusion with some divination, so abjuration, conjuration, transmutation, evocation, and necromancy implements add the most versatility – though divination is still worth taking for the resonant and focus powers, and consider illusion around level 6-10 for shadow beast.

Mesmerist // Oracle (Heavens)

Basics: Med BAB, d8, Ref and Will, 6 skills, full and 6-level casting, Cha

Very SAD combination with strong support and debuffing abilities, some battlefield control, and good skills with a particularly social bent. Heavens mystery gets a special mention for the will save penalty from Hypnotic Stare and the fact that Mental Potency stacks with Awesome Display for some outrageously effective pattern spells. Of course, there's nothing wrong with using Lore, Nature, or Lunar to turn you into a Charisma powerhouse.

Mesmerist // (Anti)Paladin

Basics: Full BAB, d10, all saves +, 6 skills, 6- and 4-level casting, physical Cha

This combination has a strong physical presence coupled with good action economy for support, debuffing, and battlefield control, as well as a solid socially-leaning skill list. The flavour lends itself a bit more easily to the sinister Anti-Paladin, but most of the Mesmerist's abilities are still appropriate for Paladins, depending on how your GM interprets “honourable” behavior. For example, Meek Facade is a great trick for attracting attacks to a paladin, Gift of Will is a completely unobjectionable way to support an ally, and the Mesmerist's Stare works equally well when making the unjust quail in their shoes as when bending the weak to the will of the strong. Immunity to fear is handy for a psychic caster, especially if you've used the otherwise redundant Towering Ego to compensate for trading away Divine Grace with an archetype.

Mesmerist // Psychic

Basics: Med BAB, d8, Ref and Will, 6 skills, full and 6-level casting, Int Cha

Want to play with peoples' minds? This is for you. Tons of enchantment and illusion, some divination; range of buffs and debuffs with some battlefield control. Rewards careful planning between setting up Mesmerist Tricks and your ability to apply Phrenic Amplifications to Mesmerist spells.
