Having two casting stats isn't quite ideal, but with various save-penalizing and DC-boosting effects you should be able to get stuff to stick. While this is definitely good, it's also worth noting Mesmerist//Sorcerer for increased spell diversity.

Mesmerist // Ranger

Basics: Full BAB, d10, all saves, 6 skills, 6- and 4-level casting, physical Wis Cha

A bit stat heavy, but enough tricks to make it worth it.

Mesmerist // Rogue

Basics: Med BAB, d8, Ref and Will, 8 skills, 6-level casting, physical Cha

Good con man, weak in combat. Invisibility and feinting (preferably with  Vexing Daredevil) make it a little easier to pull off sneak attack, but you'll still have accuracy issues, and Mesmerist is too weak for a primary casting role. Mesmerist works better with Investigator, Vivisectionist Alchemist, or Slayer; Rogue works better with

Mesmerist // Skald

Basics: Med BAB, d8, all saves, 6 skills, two 6-level casting, physical Cha

Mesmerist // Slayer

Basics: Full BAB, d10, all saves, 6 skills, 6-level casting, physical Cha Int

The slayer appreciates the Mesmerist's sneakiness. In particular, the Invisibility spell and feinting abilities help you get Sneak Attack. Consider combining a two-weapon style with two-weapon feint (Consummate Liar means you only need Dex 15 to qualify) and the Vexing Daredevil archetype – remember that you can still cast psychic spells while holding two weapons. Unless you have unusually good stats, I would avoid Slayer talents with DCs in order to focus on Cha for Mesmerist spells.

Mesmerist // Sorcerer

Basics: Med BAB, d8, Ref and Will, 6 skills, full and 6-level casting, Cha

Excellent range of SAD casting with few vulnerabilities (watch that Fort save) and a good handful of other tricks between the Mesmerist and your bloodline. Bloodlines that involve manipulating others, such as Fey, Infernal, and Serpentine, are both thematic and synergistic with the Mesmerist's focus, but it's also perfectly fine to diversify a bit more with the Sorcerer. Psychic Inception, Umbral Mesmerist, and Undead Bloodline are all options for opening undead up to mind-affecting spells from either class.

Mesmerist // Spiritualist

Basics: Med BAB, d8, all saves, 6 skills, two 6-level casting, Wis Cha

Mesmerist // Summoner

Basics: Med BAB, d8, Ref and Will, 6 skills, two 6-level casting, Cha

The minion build. Decent array of support and control spells and effects with stat synergy, good skills, light armour, and you're fielding an eidolon (or other summons).

Mesmerist // Swashbuckler

Basics: Full BAB, d10, Ref and Will, 6 skills, 6-level casting, Dex Cha

Mental trickery gives the swashbuckler more ability to control the battlefield and hamper enemies; spells give you utility, pre-buffing, and a backup plan if your sword isn't working. Minimal stat requirements keep Mesmerist DCs high (and give you lots of panache) without sacrificing ability to hold up in melee. Vexing Daredevil is thematic, but feinting actually doesn't do all that much for you – I would still prefer to keep the Bold Stare improvements.

Mesmerist // Warpriest

Basics: Med BAB, d8, all saves, 6 skills, two 6-level casting, physical Wis Cha

Too MAD, not enough combat competence to justify Warpriest. You want Mesmerist//Cleric or Oracle, or maybe Medium//Warpriest.

Mesmerist // Witch

Basics: Med BAB, d8, Ref and Will, 6 skills, full and 6-level casting, Int Cha

Mesmerist // Wizard

Basics: Med BAB, d8, Ref and Will, 6 skills, full and 6-level casting, Int Cha

Monk

On their own, most monk variants don't have the offense necessary to stand up beside other classes. However, they do have a lot of defensive or mobility options and other neat tricks that can be very valuable when paired with a more active class, whether martial or caster – and the variants that do have strong offense still work well for characters that want a little extra punch. Unarmed strikes optional. If going without armour hurts, look at the Sohei archetype or archetypes that get rid of flurry and/or fast movement (such as Sensei or Master of Many Styles) which lose less when wearing armour. Remember to use Qinggong to trade out any abilities you won't use (slow fall, high jump) for handy spell-like abilities. There's something for everyone!

First off, characters that use Charisma will want either Scaled Fist (dragon themed charisma based monk), or the Nornkith (charisma based fey themed monk). Only the Scaled Fist is compatible with Unchained Monk, which gives it a significant advantage in

Characters that want ranged combat as a primary strategy or a complement to Wis-based casting will love Zen Archer. It comes with great offense and good mobility. You lose out on evasion and poison/disease immunity, but keep unarmoured AC, saves, and some defensive bonus feats. Less good for Int or Cha casters, but still worth looking at.

Sohei is your pick for mounted combat, reach, or switch hitting (with thrown weapons or bow and temple sword) thanks to its ability to flurry with unusual weapons. Weapon Training is a fairly powerful passive boost, especially with gloves of dueling. It also gives you access to advanced weapon training and weapon mastery feats. For a thrown build, for example, you can take Focus Weapon and Trained Throw for damage increase and Ricochet Toss to retrieve your weapon. MAD combos that can't afford a good Wis will appreciate light armour, at least at low levels.

Other melee builds generally want Unchained Monk for superior mobility and strong offense, especially if the second class doesn't already have full BAB. Full-BAB classes have more options. Flowing Monk, Maneuver Master, and Tetori give you better battlefield control through combat maneuvers. Master of Many Styles makes it really easy to use combat styles including Ascetic Style, and unlike most archetypes you keep all your special defenses – it's also relatively easy to pair with other archetypes. Hungry Ghost Monk gives you vampiric powers in exchange for monk resistances, and is especially good with crit-fishing builds.

Wis Casters should consider Sensei for a support/control build with good use of combat maneuvers, at the expense of mobility. It is compatible with Ki Mystic for extra support at the expense of special defenses. Master of Many Styles is good for defense and mobility with Crane, Snake, Monkey, and Panther Styles. Elven Battle Style is also a good choice for Int-based casters if you don't mind the two pre-requisites. Note that having a monk weapon is not significant without flurry – the exception is if you want Ascetic Style.

Note: while monks are generally required to be lawful, you can get around this requirement with the Enlightened Warrior trait (be adopted by aasimar if necessary) or the Martial Artist of Menhir Guardian archetypes. This is useful for gestalting with barbarian or divine casters following Chaotic deities.

Monk // Occultist (Zen Archer, or Unchained Scaled Fist // Silksworn)

Basics: Med/Full BAB, d8/d10, all saves, 4 skills, 6-level casting, physical Int Wis/Cha

Normally the MAD makes this one difficult, really only decent with the offensively strong Unchained monk or maybe the Zen Archer, since shield-free monks can't use Trappings of the Warrior. However, there is a superior option, and it involves emulating dragons both in martial arts style and taste for bling. Giving up armour isn't a problem since you have Cha to AC and Focus, and giving up panoplies isn't a big deal because they're not great choices for the monk. The only downside is that your casting is still Int-based – I recommend getting just enough Int to cast spells and avoiding DCs. Transmutation, Abjuration, Conjuration, Divination, and Illusion are top choices, though you can get a bit of mileage out of Evocation (see: energy ray base power, floating disk, daylight, wall of force) and Necromancy (necromantic servant, soulbound puppet, false life, sands of time, death ward). Note that you can use Legacy Weapon to enhance a monk's unarmed strike.

Monk // Oracle (Unchained Scaled Fist)

Basics: Med/Full BAB, d8/d10, all saves, 4 skills, full casting, physical Cha Wis

Ability synergy is key here, and once you're taking Scaled Fist you might as well go unchained because there aren't any other compatible archetypes you'd be interested in. This gives you full BAB, mobility, good defences, and of course full casting. You can build as a caster and use the monk for mobility, defence, and a backup role – the mobility angle is especially nice for healers. Or you could do monk-style combat with oracle providing extra buffing and support. Note that the Monk's Cha to AC doesn't stack with the oracle revelations that allow you to use Cha instead of Dex to AC – but all those revelations that let you summon armour just got really useful.

Monk // (Anti)Paladin (Scaled Fist)

Basics: Full BAB, d10, all saves +, 4 skills, 4-level casting, physical Cha Wis

Pros: Great saves, lots of immunities and special defenses, full BAB with ability to combine Flurry & Smite (with Crusader's Flurry if you prefer your deity's weapon to the monk options), potentially very mobile. Cons: swift action heavy, minimal utility, conflict between heavy armour paladin and no armour monk. Keep in mind:

  • Unchained Scaled Fist for top mobility and Cha synergy. Check out the Ki Guardian power to let you roll saves for allies using your probably-excellent-Grace-enhanced save bonuses.
  • Sohei for mounted: less MAD (Wis 12 is fine) and has Weapon Training and monastic mount to buff a Divine Bond mount. You lose poison immunity (and disease immunity if you swap it out on the paladin side) but your saves are high enough to cope.
  • Zen Archer eliminates the feat barrier to the very effective archer paladin. With Wis to hit and AC, and Weapon Specialization/Smite/Ki Arrows for damage you don't need as much in the way of physical stats or any armor. Priorities: Wis=Cha>Str=Dex>Con>Int. You lose evasion and poison immunity, but do you care?
  • Kata Master is a neat option if you've got great stats and want to melee. You get a Cha-based pool of panache and some swashbuckler tricks, and give up nothing much.
  • I do not recommend Enlightened Paladin. While it seems a logical combination, Personal Trial is generally weaker than smite (unless you fight a lot of non-evil opponents) and you have an overlapping UAS damage progression and ki pool. If you're a fan of the archetype consider Enlightened Paladin // Unarmed Fighter.

Monk // Psychic

Basics: Med/Full BAB, d8/d10, all saves, 4 skills, full casting, physical Int Wis/Cha

Phrenic strike is a very useful amplification because it lets you deliver a touch spell with an  UAS in the same round as you cast it, instead of needing to carry a charge. For disciplines, self-perfection is a definite winner despite the redundant AC bonus - thematic and gives you a great set of bonus spells with useful abilities for a more martial character. Combine with mutation mind for someone who seeks perfection through pushing their body to the absolute limit, getting strength bonuses and other handy abilities in the process. Overall, I'd recommend Unchained, Zen Archer, reach Sohei, or Sensei, in order of most combat-focused to most casting-focused, with Mutation Mind being useful to the Unchained or Sohei builds. Unchained Scaled Fist is an option if you want a Cha discipline, but it's not a big difference in power.

Monk // Ranger

Basics: Full BAB, d10, all saves/Fort and Ref, 6 skills, 4-level casting, physical Wis

Good combat base, lots of bonus feats, damage bonus on lots of attacks, good utility, good mobility with the right build. For an unmounted melee character that's Unchained (despite the low Will – Wis will compensate). Mounted on your animal companion, consider Sohei. And then there's Zen Archer. All the Ranger's archery feats are also on the Zen Archer's list, but mostly this means that you'll end up taking Dodge, Mobility, or Combat Reflexes in addition to the archery staples. You can also opt for a more mystic build such as Sensei with the Ranger's full BAB backing you up.

Monk // Rogue (Unchained)

Basics: Med/Full BAB, d8/d10, all saves/Fort and Ref, 8 skills, no casting, physical Wis

Fully Unchained on both sides, you get a mobile skirmisher with excellent damage potential when combining flurry with sneak attack. Also strong defences, good utility, and some debuffing between monk powers like stunning fist and sneak attack riders. Scout is a good archetype since at level 8 any flying kick is a sneak attack. Also strongly consider the Dimensional Savant feat line, since flanking with yourself lets you make sure you've got sneak attack as long as you have ki. It's a lot of feats, but you're not using them on TWF. Try to pick up Iron Will since your will save will be a bit behind. Ninja also works. You get one shared ki pool instead of two separate ki pools, which makes you more flexible but also likely short on ki. Much less effective without Unchained Monk due to poor accuracy. If you want a different type of Monk, go Monk//Slayer.  For a wild debuffing build with a bit of multiclassing, check out Kazumetsa Raijin’s suggestions here and here.

Monk // Skald

Basics: Med/Full BAB, d8/d10, all saves, 4 skills, casting

Monk // Slayer

Basics: Full BAB, d10, all saves/Fort and Ref, 6 skills, no casting, physical Wis Int

Swift action heavy. The big draw over Monk//Rogue is that this doesn't need UnMonk to be effective. A thrown weapons build with Sohei gets neat weapon training tricks (like Trained Throw or easy access to Ricochet Toss) and benefits from thrown weapon style feats. Or try a Master of Many Styles or Maneuver Master, using TWF instead of the flurry you give up.

Monk // Sorcerer (Empyreal or Scaled Fist)

Basics: Med/Full BAB, d8/d10, all saves, 4 skills, full casting, physical Wis or Cha

Lots of defences, mobility, full casting, all good. Strong melee potential between the monk base and sorc buffs. Frostbite and Chill Touch are nasty when delivered with a Flurry of Unarmed Strikes. And you've got two options for stat synergy: Scaled Fist Monk for Cha or Empyreal bloodline for Wis.  If you don't want to invest in physical stats you can go Wis and take Zen Archer for ranged damage or Sensei for extra support and combat maneuvers. On the other hand, the bloodline flexibility with Scaled Fist gives the option of taking a more combat-focused bloodline like Orc or Abyssal – or the Eldritch Scrapper archetype which cannot strictly be combined with Empyreal due to both replacing the 9th level bloodline power. (Though a GM with a more lenient interpretation of the wild bloodlines may allow them with such archetypes).

Monk//Spiritualist

Basics: Med/Full BAB, d8/d10, all saves,  4 skills, casting

Punch people while yor standphantom punches people. Get an Anger or Dedication Focus Phantom, put points in performance dance or acting so you pose with skill, say ORA ORA ORA, and name your standphantom after a song. Bonus points if the first and last names of your character start with Jo, Gio or a similar sound, no matter their race. Double jeopardy points if you choose your touch spells known inside a theme as your standsphantoms power.

Monk // Summoner (Unchained Scaled Fist, Synthesist)

Basics: Med/Full BAB, d8/d10, all saves, 4 skills, 6-level casting, physical Cha Wis

Normally not a lot of synergy. The unchained scaled fist gives you a full-BAB partial caster with stat synergy, which is pretty good. Add Synthesist and it gets a bit nuts. Your unarmoured AC will be great. You can also make a really strong teleporting build with Dimensional Assault plus Pounce by level 9 (using the synthesist's Maker's Jump ability). Note that many offensive evolutions are linked to your natural attacks; while it's perfectly effective to use your evolutions for utility, defence, and ability score increases, you may also want to consider taking Feral Combat Training in order to incorporate a single beefed-up natural attack into your Flurry.

Monk // Swashbuckler (Scaled Fist)

Basics: Full BAB, d10, all saves/Fort and Ref, 4 skills, no casting, Dex Wis Cha

As written, Precise Strike works with Flurry, which gives you excellent damage potential. Unfortunately, there aren't many light or one-handed piercing monk weapons, with cestus and bich'hwa being your best options. You can add the unarmed strike to that if you take Snake Style, or daggers if you take both Flying Blade and Far Strike Monk and make a thrown weapon specialist. Slashing Grace does not work with Flurry, so if you want dex to damage you'll need an Agile weapon. You are also hungry for swift actions and have mediocre utility, which makes this combo merely pretty good. Scaled Fist is a moderate improvement for the Cha synergy, but not enough to make the combo great.

Monk // Warpriest (Sohei, Unchained//Arsenal Chaplain)

Basics: Med/Full BAB, d8/d10, all saves, 4 skills, 6-level casting, physical Wis

Tempting – you have stat synergy, a bunch of combat-focused abilities, and some spellcasting. The enhancement bonus from sacred weapon supplements an expensive AoMF. The Airless Touch blessing of the Void domain works very well with Chokehold or Kraken Throttle – force the air from someone's lungs and then choke them so they are immediately in danger of unconsciousness. However, it has some problems. First, you don't actually have full BAB without Unchained. Second, you're very heavy on swift actions. Third, sacred armor is useless to you if you can't wear armour (it doesn't have language allowing it to affect clothing as if it were armour with a +0 AC bonus). Finally, sacred weapon overlaps with monk's improved unarmed strike damage, which is wasteful. Archetypes make a big difference.

  • Arsenal Chaplain gives you Weapon Training for a great passive bonus and gets rid of Sacred Armor. If you're using UAS, Ascetic Style, or a large weapon, the cap on Sacred Weapon damage won't bother you.
  • Unchained Monk gives you actual full BAB and d10 HD, with Warpriest patching the poor base Will save. Works well with Arsenal Chaplain.
  • Far Shot Monk gives you a bunch of thrown weapon feats and the ability to flurry with them, which go marvelously with Arsenal Champlain's weapon training (and Trained Throw, and Ricochet Toss). You can even get your sacred weapon damage back with Focused Weapon.
  • Sohei allows you to wear light armour, thus benefiting from sacred armour, and gives you Weapon Training (flurrying with trained weapons). If you take Weapon Focus (UAS) you can make up for the Sohei's stunted UAS damage progression. Divine Commander optionally gives you a mount to use with the monastic mount ability. Good if you're not taking Arsenal Chaplain.
  • Mantis Zealot replaces sacred weapon with sneak attack (less swift action competition), and sacred armor with a thematic uncanny dodge ability (unfortunately still requiring a swift action to activate, which is especially limiting with uncanny dodge, but something is better than nothing). Generally not as good as Arsenal Chaplain, but worth considering.
  • I do not recommend Sacred Fist, which just adds more overlap. It may be worth taking if you want a monk archetype that gives up Flurry: Sensei (lots of Wis, some support), Master of Many Styles (9 bonus style feats, up to 5 styles at once), or Maneuver Master (Flurry of Blows and Flurry of Maneuvers stack). However, note that Sacred Fist, unlike Monk, does not grant a BAB increase while flurrying, which means accuracy is a problem.

Monk // Witch (White Haired Witch, Old SWD, Seducer//Unchained Scaled Fist)

Basics: Med/Full BAB, d8/d10, all saves, 4 skills, full casting, physical Int Wis

Witches have a lot of close range or touch effects; the monk makes these easier to deliver with strong defense and mobility. Hex Strike is a good feat. White Haired Witch in particular enjoys some fun maneuver abilities that benefit from monk maneuver training and bonus feats. Tetori is notable for really beefing up your hair's grappling abilities. Note that Feral Combat Training allows you to use your hair as a flurry attack.  As usual, the old Con-based Scarred Witch Doctor makes an excellent melee monster – or combine Seducer with Scaled Fist (Unchained) to switch all your class features to Cha.

Monk // Wizard

Basics:  Med/Full BAB, d8/d10, all saves, 4 skills, full casting, physical Int Wis

This one is about adding durability, mobility, and a physical combat option to the wizard. It fills that function respectably, though I would recommend Kensai//Wizard instead, or even Esoteric Magus//Wizard.

Occultist

The occultist is an extremely versatile class, but individual occultists are limited by implement school selection and amount of mental focus. Because Focus is such an important resource, an occultist normally wants more intelligence than spellcasting alone requires, so watch your MAD! Your other class should guide your role and thus implement selection:

If your other class is martial, you want Transmutation for offence, and usually at least one of Abjuration or Illusion for defence (mirror image). Divination's a tough choice – the powers are great, but to get the most out of them you're diverting focus from Transmutation. Definitely take it if you expect to alternate between combat and non-combat days. Otherwise it depends on how much Focus you have and whether you have racial Darkvision. Conjuration's got some good utility, and Side Step. Evocation is fine as a backup option, and the force spells are useful, but it's not high priority. Necromancy is probably a pass - but since the Necromantic Servant shares your BAB and HP it can make a handy extra body in a small party or if you need a disposable flank partner. Enchantment is skippable. Armour doesn't interfere with occultist spells, so feel free to suit up if you get heavy proficiency. Haunt Collector archetype with the Champion is a nice damage buff and is best applied to the conjuration or necromancy schools.

Casters are looking to fill in any holes in their spell lists and for synergistic casting benefits. The latter come from necromancy (undead creation), conjuration (minor duration boost), and evocation (damage boost plus shape mastery). Haunt Collector with the archmage or heirophant spirits can also be a nice boost if you cast a lot of damaging or healing spells. The Mage's Paraphernalia gives you metamagic abilities and expanded access to divination, evocation, and necromancy spells.

Partial casters work a bit better with the Occultist than most other part-hybrids because you can build the occultist with a bit more martial or caster focus than most hybrids. A martial occultist//part caster will want to take the Trappings of the Warrior panoply to get full BAB with one weapon. This can limit your fighting style options depending on how your GM interprets the use of a shield. It also cuts down on your options for utility schools compared to the martial//occultist (see above), but usually the non-occultist part caster has a good amount of utility. A casting occultist//part caster often wants Silksworn as this increases your amount of focus and number of implement schools.

In terms of archetypes, Silksworn is a great pair with unarmoured classes, since you get bonus implement schools and spells per day in exchange for losing the ability to cast in armour. It also gets to add both Intelligence and Charisma to its Mental Focus, which is helpful when gestalting with charisma-based classes (though note you still cast using Intelligence). Similarly, if you gestalt Occultist with something that needs a lot of Wis, you can take Reliquarian for Wis-based focus and keep your Int modest – though in this case consider taking Relic Hunter Inquisitor instead. The Relic Hunter gets at least as many implement schools as the Reliquarian and is entirely Wis-based, though it does sacrifice focus powers and by strict RAW can't take Panoplies (but ask your GM as this may be an oversight). Panoply Savant is also worth a look.

Occultist // Oracle

Basics: Med BAB, d8, Fort and Will, 4 skills, full and 6-level casting, Int Cha physical?

MAD makes a combat build difficult. Casting works better, especially if you stick to support, utility, and if it's a small party gestalt, minions. Themes:

  • Blasting. Flame and Winter are the best mysteries for this, though Solar also works. Evocation implements and a haunted implement with the archmage spirit add damage. Since metamagic works nicely with blasts, consider Mage's Paraphernalia for Metamagic Secret. Seeker archetype's level 15 ability is also a nice cheap metamagic option since you'll be using your mystery spells a lot.
  • Healing. Life oracles are great healers and the occultist can take that even further – or make a slightly better healer out of an oracle whose main role is elsewhere. The saint's regalia panoply improves Cure spells, and an implement haunted with the hierophant improves all abilities that restore HP (though not fast healing – technically Life Link is not fast healing, but check with your GM). Purge Corruption is a handy early-access condition removal.
  • Undead Master. Prioritize Cha, take Necromancy implements and either the Juju or Bones mystery. Necromantic Servant and Soulbound Doll give you early-game minions and scouts. Necroccultist boosts your Necromancy DCs and gives you access to more necromancy spells from the wizard list. Alternatively, if you're hurting for stats or want more versatility and you can deal with losing armour, take Silksworn. With a lower Int you'll want to pick up spells like spectral hand, death ward, or sands of time with necromancy, and take support/utility schools like transmutation, divination, abjuration, illusion (mirror image, displacement) and conjuration (mage armor, teleportation). Armour of Bones is also a nice revelation for this combo.
  • Battle: Trappings of the Warrior, probably with Panoply Savant for extra focus since your Int will be low. For later implements try Illusion and Conjuration since spells like Mirror Image and Dimension Door will be useful even without much focus – save just a few points for Side Step and Shadow Beast.
  • Utility/Versatility: Silksworn//Lore Oracle. Lots of mental focus, and Cha to AC from Sidestep Secret improves your unarmoured AC. Mental Acuity revelation improves your Int. Has versatile magic from extra implements, plus the arcane archivist and spontaneous symbology revelations. Focused Trance and Think On It give you excellent Knowledge checks, though Lore Keeper is probably skippable since you'll want good Int. Plenty of potential on face skills.

Occultist // (Anti)Paladin

Basics: Full BAB, d10, Fort and Will+, 4 skills, 6- and 4-level casting, physical Int Cha

Quite MAD, and Silksworn makes you give up armour. You can still get buffs and utility out of the Occultist, but the Bard//Paladin is more efficient at that and gets better saves to boot.

Occultist // Psychic

Basics: Med BAB, d8, Fort and Will, 4 skills, full and partial casting, Int and Wis or Cha

Armoured and shielded – or using a two-handed reach weapon - this combination is unusually front-line capable for something with so many magical tools at its disposal. Tricks from both classes synergize well, since phrenic amplifications work on occultist spells and the conjuration and evocation implement powers work on spells cast as a psychic.

  • Build for a secondary melee role. Take Panoply Savant (Warrior), with Abjuration and Transmutation as your starting implements and Trappings of the Warrior at level 2. You now have effectively full BAB, a small assortment of combat buffs, and medium armour. At 6th level and higher, Divination and Illusion are good picks for utility.
  • Casting-focused build. Take Silksworn, along with a Cha-based psychic discipline. Without armour you need to stay out of melee, and your phrenic amplifications no longer work on arcane occultist spells – but that also means your occultist spells don't get shut off by emotion effects, and you get a wider range of magical tricks to play with. This is your best bet if you're short on stats.
  • Intermediate. Keep your armour, take Transmutation as one of your starting schools, and get enough strength to wear the armour and hit something at low levels when spells are limited.  Don't invest in combat going forwards. In the long run, Transmutation will still be useful for defence and support, and armour's nice to have if you end up next to something nasty. Divination can also be used to boost your attack at low levels and provide utility going forwards.

Occultist // Ranger

Basics: Full BAB, d10, all saves, 6 skills, 6- and 4-level casting, physical Int Wis

Pretty well-rounded for combat and utility, and you can cast psychic spells while TWF – though archery is also an excellent choice. Consider Occultist//Slayer if the need for a Wis score is crimping your style, though having access to ranger spells does give you a bit of flexibility with how you get spells such as lead blades or resist energy.

Occultist // Rogue (Unchained Eldritch Scoundrel // Silksworn)

Basics: Med BAB, d8, all saves, 8 skills, 6-level casting, physical Int

You could make a halfway decent attempt at combat with Trappings of the Warrior, in which case you may want to detour into Illusion at 2 for invisibility and mirror image, and take Divination at 10 for assorted utility and buffs. But that just leaves you with an inferior Occultist//Slayer, so why bother? If you're looking to do something interesting (and halfway effective) with this combo, take Unchained Eldritch Scoundrel with Silksworn and make a sneaky caster build. This gives you a versatile base set of wizard spells, albeit at 6-level progression, to be supplemented with the occultist's best powers. Rays and other weapon-based spells get a bit of extra damage and flexible debuffing with sneak attack + debilitating injury). Ability priorities are Int > Dex > Cha: Int for magic; Dex for initiative, AC, ray accuracy, and weapons combat; and Cha for extra focus and skills. If you've got spare feats, accomplished sneak attacker can make up for some of the lost sneak damage. While you lack the overall power of Rogue//Wizard or Sorcerer, there's a few advantages to this build. First, you're a bit more physically resilient with a good Fort save and access to danger sight and the abjuration school powers. Second, the transmutation implement and divination’s sudden insight make you better at physical backstabbing if necessary as a backup option. Third, some focus powers (eg Mind's Eye and Unseen) are better than comparable full casting options. Finally, being able to grab healing spells from Conjuration may be useful depending on party composition. School priorities:

  • Divination is almost required. You can't sneak attack what you can't see, and Third Eye prevents opponents from hiding in darkness or invisibility – those are your tricks! The perception bonus and Mind Eye are also big boosts to your scouting ability. Sudden insight can help a key attack land (applying debilitating injury to soften them up for the follow-up) or boost an important skill check, and danger sight keeps you safe.
  • Illusions are great for defence and trickery. Unseen helps you get sneak attacks, though as it's expensive to maintain while attacking you'll want another method, such as ninja vanishing trick, darkness, or:
  • Necromantic Servant can act as a flanking partner.
  • Evocation's energy ray is a handy sneak attack delivery device.
  • Transmutation's Dex boost and legacy weapon are strongly recommended for physical backstabbing.
  • Conjuration, as mentioned, gives you access to healing as well as teleportation. Servitor can also create flanking partners, albeit less durable ones than Necromantic Servant.
  • Abjuration and Enchantment are fairly straightforward. The focus powers are fine, but you can grab key spells through Eldritch Scoundrel if you don't want to bother with these schools.

Occultist // Skald

Basics: Med BAB, d8, all saves, 4 skills, two 6-level casting, physical Int Cha

Lots of issues. MAD, overly spread out between combat and casting, and Raging Song prevents Occultist casting. Either bard or barbarian works better.

Occultist // Slayer

Basics: Full BAB, d10, all saves, 6 skills, 6-level casting, physical Int

Excellent combat ability between the slayer's base abilities and the occultist's buffing, with lots of utility options on both sides. No somatic components, so you can cast while TWF. Invisibility from illusion implements helps you get sneak attack.

Occultist // Sorcerer (Sage or Silksworn)

Basics: Med BAB, d8, Fort and Will, 4 skills, full and 6-level casting, Cha Int

Sage bloodline lets you go SAD Int. Then take Mage's Paraphernalia, using the Metamagic Knowledge power to gain metamagic feats which you can then use for either class's spells without increasing casting time via the Metamagic Adept bloodline ability – or use the Metamagic Master  ability to use metamagic without increasing spell level (again, as written with either class's spells). The required implement schools (divination, necromancy, evocation) are also pretty good for this combo, with evocation adding another blasting damage bonus (and you can haunt the necromancy implement with the archmage for yet another damage bonus, making this a great blasting build). Of course, most of this works with different bloodlines if you can support two casting stats. Silksworn also adds stat synergy – it cuts off metamagic shenanigans with Mage's Paraphernalia but gives you a lot more flexibility with implement schools.

Occultist//Spiritualist

Basics: Med BAB, d8, Fort and Will, 4 skills, casting

Occultist // Summoner

Basics: Med BAB, d8, Fort and Will, 4 skills, two 6-level casting, Int Cha physical?

Works well in a small party as a versatile mage with a strong melee companion – otherwise underpotent compared to Bard, Sorcerer, or Bloodrager//Summoner. Toss-up between Silksworn and Mage's Paraphernalia. You can make a combat build with Synthesist, though you have to use a manufactured weapon and mithral buckler to make use of Trappings of the Warrior, which is less than ideal. Summoners are pretty focused as casters, so most of the implement schools add variety:

  • New things – take for:
  • Divination – Scouting and scrying. Summoners get Detect/Read Magic, See Invisibility, Tongues, and True Seeing.
  • Enchantment – Mind control, especially humanoids. Summoners get charm/hold/dominate monster, Heroism, and a handful of incidentals.
  • Evocation – Blasts, force effects, light. Summoners get only nine evocation spells, including Wind Wall, Wall of Fire, and Wall of Ice.
  • Illusion – Deception. Summoners do get Blur, Invisibility, and Displacement, so if you're just looking for defensive illusions you can skip this school.
  • Necromancy – Single-target debuffs, undead minions, deception... summoners just get seven necromancy spells as of writing.
  • Synergy:
  • Conjuration – The resonant power applies to tons of summoner spells, and getting access to healing is nice. There are also a handful of other spells the summoner doesn't get, such as Create Food and Water, Sepia Snake Sigil, Secret Chest, and Getaway. Servitor is weaker than the summoner's SLA but you can use it while your eidolon is active so it's not a waste.
  • Some overlap:
  • Abjuration – Summoners get most of these but are notably missing Freedom of Movement and Antimagic Field. Overall pretty skippable – though being able to get a resistance bonus while your eidolon also wears a cloak is nice.
  • Transmutation – Summoners get some good buffs but the occultist adds other useful transmutations including: Magic Weapon, Pass Without Trace, Air Step, Darkvision, Make Whole, Magic Vestment, Shrink Item, Stone Shape, Air Walk, Echolocation, Control Winds, Fabricate, Telekinesis, Transmute Mud/Rock, Animate Objects, Disintegrate, Transformation. Better if your eidolon uses a manufactured weapon, which gives you a target for Magic Weapon and Legacy Weapon.

Occultist // Swashbuckler (Inspired Blade)

Basics: Full BAB, d10, all saves, 4 skills, 6-level casting, Dex Int Cha

Decent martial base, lots of buffs. Dex focus and free feats make it easier to devote resources to casting. Inspired Blade takes it up a notch since you won't need to rely on Cha for panache. Silksworn works OK if you want both Int and Cha to focus and panache. In this case you want to prioritize defence at level 1 with at least two of Abjuration, Conjuration (mage armour), and Illusion, plus Transmutation for offence.

Occultist // Vigilante

Basics: Med/Full BAB, d8, all saves, 6 skills, 6-level casting, physical Int Cha

Avenger gets you access to strong combat talents plus full BAB immediately and consistently, freeing you up to shuffle mental focus around for utility purposes. Casting focus.

Occultist // Warpriest

Basics: Med BAB, d8, Fort and Will, 4 skills, two 6-level casting, physical Int Wis

MAD and with mediocre basics. If you have great stats and take Trappings of the Warrior you can make something halfway decent with it, but really this is trying to do too much. If your GM lets the Relic Hunter take panoplies, use that instead for better stat synergy.

Occultist // Witch

Basics: Med BAB, d8, Fort and Will, 4 skills, full and partial casting, Int

The Mage's Paraphernalia is a great choice for this gestalt since it gives you access to a broad range of wizard spells. It's also got two good schools for you – Divination has great focus powers, and Evocation gives you some handy force spells that the witch doesn't get. Necromancy is less exciting since the witches get access to the best spells, but they're still pretty good spells and Necromantic Servant ain't bad. Outside the panoply, Illusion's got a lot of non-witch spells and Transmutation and Abjuration each have a few biggies (e.g. Haste, Magic Circle, Freedom of Movement). Conjuration and Enchantment are skippable as most of the good spells are also on the witch list.

Occultist // Wizard

Basics: Med BAB, d8, Fort and Will, 4 skills, full and partial casting, Int

Wizard is obviously the magical heavy lifter, but occultist brings improved durability, a couple of synergistic spell boosts, and a few powers that are better than wizard spells – plus the option to take a secondary healing role with conjuration. For boosting spells you've got the resonant abilities on conjuration (stacks with the conjuration school's summoner's charm), evocation, and necromancy (if you're animating undead – in which case you also want the necromancy school or undead subschool), plus a haunted implement with the archmage spirit. You can also take Mage's Paraphernalia for Metamagic Secret – the base power may occasionally be useful if you really need a wizard spell but don't have a wizard slot. Best focus powers belong to Divination, with Mind Eye and Third topping the list followed by Danger Sense. See also necromancy (Necromantic Servant), Conjuration (Side Step), Illusion (Shadow Beast and Unseen), Transmutation (Mind over Gravity, Size Alteration, and Sudden Speed). Enchantment is the most skippable, followed by evocation if you're not planning on doing a lot of blasting. Silksworn is fine, though the versatility isn't as big a deal with wizard on the other side of the gestalt and the opportunity cost on the Haunt Collector and Panpolies is considerable.

Oracle

As a spontaneous caster with a limited list of spells known, the oracle has a higher level of specialization than most divine casters. Mysteries reinforce this specialization – and thanks to mystery spells, also allow you to specialize in roles not typical of the cleric, such as blasting. As a result, it's fairly easy to find synergies between your oracle's specialty and your second class. However, it's especially important to make sure that your gestalt maintains some versatility. A Fighter//Oracle should make sure their spell selection includes group buffs or summons in addition to personal combat buffs, and a Red Dragon Sorcerer // Flame Oracle should have options other than fire damage. The Spirit Guide archetype can improve versatility, as it gives you a small selection of abilities which you can change from day to day.

The oracle is also notable for its ability to use Cha instead of Dex for purposes of AC and either CMD or Ref saves, through the Lore (Sidestep Secret/Reflex), Nature (Nature's Whispers/CMD), and Lunar (Prophetic Armour/CMD) Mysteries. These abilities are most useful when your second class is also Charisma-focused and/or prefers light or no armour, since your Cha modifier is limited by your armour's max dexterity modifier.

Note also that the Oracle, unlike most divine casters, does not provide a good Fort save, so if your second class also has a poor Fort save you will want other ways to boost that defense.

Like the cleric, the Oracle can be built primarily for combat, casting, or as a reach build.

Combat: You almost always want your other class to have full BAB and no requirement for Int or Wis. Battle Mystery is the obvious choice, though if you want access to a wider variety of revelations consider Ancestor, Dark Tapestry (Many Forms & Wings of Darkness), Metal, Stone, and Flame (Cinder Dance). Wood is a good choice for archers or reach weapon users, and Lunar provides the best combat revelations for a low-Dex build. Consider Warsighted if your chosen mystery has few revelations you are interested in, though note that this will delay your first revelation until level 3 – problematic if it's important to your concept (such as Prophetic Armour) - and you’ll need Extra Revelation for any additional revelations after that.

Reach oracles gestalt similarly to the combat oracle, except they don't necessarily need the second class to have full BAB – just be sure to buff and look out for accuracy-increasing revelations like Wood Bond, Dance of the Blades (Metal), or Spirit of the Warrior (Ancestor). They also have little use for the Dex-replacement revelations since you still need a good Dex for extra AoO.

Casting: Most mysteries will give you useful stuff, but particularly note Bones and Juju for necromancers (plus other offensive options), Flame for blasting, Apocalypse for blasting and controlling, and Heavens for ridiculous debuffing. Also keep in mind the Waves and Winter mysteries, whose Freezing Spells revelation provides an excellent debuff that is extra useful when combined with a class that provides save-based cold spells. Lore’s Mental Acuity gives you up to a +5 inherent bonus to Int, which can be very useful for gestalting with Int-based casters like the wizard, though see below, and the mystery is otherwise lacklustre; if you’re really needing to minimize MAD you can also take Sidestep Secret, but as a caster you probably still want Dex for initiative. Casting oracles are particularly likely to run into the low Fort save issue.

Extended on Lore Mystery: When planning a Lore Oracle / Int caster, keep in mind that the +5 is equal to the increase you’d normally get by putting all of your level-based increases into Int, which more or less gives you level-based advancements to two casting stats at the same rate as a SAD caster. However, you still have to worry about splitting your initial stat allotment and your stat headband budget between the two stats, which means you’re not on the same footing as a SAD caster even after devoting your mystery to this. If your starting stats are generous and versatility is at a premium (for example in a small party) this may still be worth it. Indeed, if you lean into Oracle as a support caster you could potentially use some or all of your level increases and Mental Acuity to increase your Int above normal limits, which is great for DC-focused mages - just make sure your initial stats and expected wealth support enough charisma increases to cast your higher level oracle spells! One last caution: Mental Acuity isn’t available until level 7, so make sure you’ve planned to have acceptable casting stats through level 6.

General: The Time and Wind mysteries are fairly useful all-around with mobility and defensive options, and the Ancestor and Lore mysteries (and the Spirit Guide archetype) are notable for providing all Knowledge skills as class skills. The Life mystery gives you good action economy for healing and is the easiest way for an oracle to handle condition removal.

Oracle // (Anti)Paladin ****

Basics: Full BAB, d10, Fort and Will+, 4 skills, full and 4-level casting, physical Cha

Do you love charisma? This is your gestalt. Charisma to spells, saves with Divine Grace and attacks with Smite, and AC with the Lore, Lunar, or Nature mystery – Lore also lets you add Charisma to Knowledge checks. Alternatively, take the Life Mystery to make a fantastic tank/healer.

Oracle // Psychic *** (Lore ****)

Basics: Med BAB, d8, Will, 4 skills, two full casting, Int Cha

I prefer Cleric//Psychic for the better saves and the versatility of prepared divine spellcasting. However, this still has two full casting classes with diverse spell lists, a d8 hit die, and armour. The main advantage over Oracle//Cleric is the Lore Mystery: a nice, thematic Int boost which mitigates MAD, especially if you use the oracle for support casting. For disciplines, Rebirth gives you a useful measure of flexibility in day to day spell selection. Alternatively, Rapport's ability to add Cha to your save a few times a day patches a major weakness and the status effect is useful for a healer.

Oracle // Ranger

Basics: Full BAB, d10, all saves, 6 skills, full and 4-level casting, physical Cha Wis

Well-rounded combo for combat with skills and support.

Oracle // Rogue (Ninja)

Basics: Med BAB, d8, Ref and Will, 8 skills, full casting, Dex Cha

Strong skills and full divine casting isn’t bad, but defenses aren’t ideal and offense is… tricky. Oracle buffs help, but you’re very reliant for sneak attack for damage and accuracy (since landing a Debilitating Injury - Bewildered is your main accuracy buff). Average BAB isn’t great for TWF progression, either. If you can get sneak attack consistently, then this is green, though again watch your defenses! Otherwise yellow. Strategies for getting sneak attack with this combo:

  • Flanking pet with the Nature or Lunar mystery.
  • Gaze of Flames, either through the Flame mystery or using Spirit Guide channelling the Flame Spirit: lets you see through smoke and fog, which gives you total concealment if you lay down Obscuring Mist and attack from 10ft away using thrown weapons or reach.
  • Invisibility and then Deeper Darkness spells with Shadow mystery; at 11th level the Pierce the Shadows Revelation gives you the ability to see through your Deeper Darkness spell. Added bonus: lots of sneaky revelations.
  • Invisibility with the Wind mystery: gives you 1 round/level of Greater Invis starting at level 9. Very limited use, but spending a round will at least let you slap your first Debilitating Injury on a target.

Ninja has nice charisma synergy and Vanishing Trick, but also lacks the accuracy boost from Debilitating Injury. Consider also Oracle//Slayer for more reliable combat abilities and a good Fort save, or Oracle//Archaeologist Bard if you want to prioritize casting.

Oracle // Skald

Basics: Med BAB, d8, all saves, 4 skills, full and 6-level casting, physical Cha

Oracle // Slayer

Basics: Full BAB, d10, all saves, 6 skills, full casting, physical Cha Int

Well-rounded combo for combat with skills and support. I like the Lunar mystery for sneakiness, Cha to AC, and a flanking buddy.

Oracle // Sorcerer

Basics: Med BAB, d8, Will, 4 skills, two full casting, Cha

Great casting and an assortment of other magical goodies. You want to diversify your spell selection, but also take advantage of abilities like the Orc bloodline's damage boost or the Waves mystery's Freezing spells ability to boost your magic across class boundaries. Saves are a serious weak point – consider Great Fortitude at least, which you can get as a bonus feat from bloodlines such as Draconic, Orc, Abyssal, or Stormborn. Losing armour makes revelations that function like armour more valuable.

Oracle//Spiritualist (Fractured Mind)

Basics: Med BAB, d8, Fort and Will, 4 skills, full and 6-level casting, Cha Wis

Fractured Mind has stat synergy.

Oracle // Summoner

Basics: Med BAB, d8, Will, 4 skills, full and 6-level casting, Cha

Excellent stat synergy and two strong lists for support and battlefield control, with some debuffing potential depending on mystery choice. Can pick up a reach weapon, or enter melee personally as a synthesist, though it's not particularly strong at either. Poor saves make this green instead of blue.

Oracle // Swashbuckler

Basics: Full BAB, d10, Ref and Will, 4 skills, full casting, Dex Cha

Solid option for a melee & support character with access to a lot of buffs to augment the swashbuckler's basic combat abilities. Watch your Fort save.

Oracle // Warpriest

Basics: Med BAB, d8, Fort and Will, 4 skills, full and 6-level casting, physical Cha Wis

MAD, mediocre basics, second cleric spell list doesn’t add any versatility. Try Oracle//Paladin.

Oracle // Witch 

Basics: Med BAB, d8, Will, 4 skills, two full casting, Int Cha

Lack of casting stat synergy is a pain, the oracle and witch tend to have similar access to similar healing and debuffing abilities so versatility isn’t great, and your saves hurt. Lore mystery can get your Hex DCs unusually high but remember that you’ll still need to plan for how to prioritize your stats

Oracle // Wizard

Basics:  Med BAB, d8, Will, 4 skills, two full casting, Int Cha

Better spellcasting versatility than Oracle//Witch, but still no casting stat synergy and painful saves. Again, with Lore you can get an edge on your Int-based DCs, which makes combining debuff/control wizard spells with support oracle casting a reasonable strategy. Consider also Oracle//Arcanist.

Paladin

The paladin's big weakness is out of combat utility.

Paladin // Psychic

Basics: Full BAB, d10, Fort and Will+, 2 skills, full and 4-level casting, physical Int Cha

A little MAD, but tons of defences and being immune to fear makes it just a little less likely that someone will mess with your emotion components. Since the armour is your main advantage over a Paladin//Sorcerer and you can't really afford the Int for offensive spells, you should probably make martial combat your primary role. Psychic magic adds more diverse support options and some utility for coordinating allies or rooting out wrongdoing – Rapport is a nice choice of discipline.

Paladin // Ranger

Basics: Full BAB, d10, all saves+, 6 skills, two 4-level casting, physical Cha Wis

Is your campaign going to focus on fighting some specific type of evil enemy, such as demons? Congrats, you killed them. All of them. Even without your offensive buffs, you're still super durable and have decent utility, and combat styles help you do more interesting things with your weapons. Note TWF and archery are great styles for a paladin that can actually afford the feats.

Paladin // Rogue

Basics: Full BAB, d10, all saves+, 8 skills, casting

Surprisingly strong, with the paladin covering the rogue's combat weaknesses and the rogue providing out of combat utility – plus a good Ref save and Evasion, which with Divine Grace means you laugh at Fireball. If you can Sneak Attack and Smite at the same time you can do massive damage – though check with your GM since some might consider Sneak Attack dishonourable. Consider Ninja to get a few more supernatural abilities powered by Charisma.

Paladin // Skald

Basics: Full BAB, d10, all saves+, 4 skills, casting

Lesser Celestial Totem?

Paladin // Slayer

Basics: Full BAB, d10, all saves+, 6 skills, 4-level casting, physical Cha Int

Durability, bonus feats, and utility. Swift action activation makes using Smite and Studied Target at the same time a bit of a pain, though it's definitely nice to have a combat buff that'll work with any enemy type. Consider using your Divine Bond for a flanking “mount.”

Paladin // Sorcerer

Basics: Full BAB, d10, Fort and Will+, 2 skills, full and 4-level casting, physical Cha

Such sweet charisma synergy that it compensates for the usual combat caster problems. It is easiest toPaladin // Sorc focus on casting and tap Paladin for the defenses, healing, and the ability to swing a sword as a backup option – consider Sacred Servant or Hospitalier for this route. A reach build is also quite effective. It's also possible to make casting the secondary option if you fill up on utility and pre-combat buffs. The nice thing here is that you'll still have a high enough casting stat to get lots of bonus spells and decent DCs. Since your AC will be low for melee, even with Mage Armour, archery is a good option – consider Divine Hunter for the feat help. Alternatively, Iroran/Enlightened Paladin gives you unarmoured AC, and unarmed strikes can be used to deliver multi-touch spells like Frostbite or Chill Touch to good effect. Consider also switching from Sorcerer to Dragon Disciple for more combat on that side of the gestalt. Eldritch scrapper is a good archetype.

Paladin//Spiritualist (Focused Mind)

Basics: Full BAB, d10, Fort and Will+, 4 skills, casting

Paladin // Summoner

Basics: Full BAB, d10, all saves+, 2 skills, 6- and 4-level casting, physical Cha

Thematic combination – a holy warrior with a particularly strong connection with the heavens and the ability to summon angelic allies. Also has good stat synergy, ability to punch face, and lots of options for support. Aura of Justice is nasty with summoned critters.

Paladin // Swashbuckler

Basics: Full BAB, d10, all saves+, 4 skills, casting

(Anti) Paladin // Warpriest

Basics: Full BAB, d10, Fort and Will+, 2 skills, 6- and 4-level casting, physical Cha Wis

Very MAD, but pretty effective if you have the stats to make it work. A bit heavy on the swift actions, but with full BAB and extra combat feats you shouldn't need more than one or two buffs at a time. Channel energy is basically redundant and Sacred Weapon has a similar function to the paladin's Weapon Bond, so you can play with archetypes that give up these features, like Arsenal Chaplain, Chosen One, Sacred Servant, or Sacred Shield. Stonelord Paladin is an excellent choice if you want to focus on Wis – you trade away everything that uses Cha except for Lay on Hands, and get some decent abilities in return. Note that you do lose Channel Positive and Divine Bond, so if those things are important to you make sure you keep them on the Warpriest end. Lack of skills is a major weakness – Cult Leader is a good patch if your GM doesn't think it's too dishonourable and if you don't mind losing bonus feats.

Paladin // Witch (Seducer)

Basics: Full BAB, d10, Fort and Will+, 4 skills, casting

Paladin // Wizard

Basics:  Full BAB, d10, Fort and Will+, 4 skills, casting

Psychic

The psychic is unusual as an int-based spontaneous caster with access to many key arcane buffs and debuffs such as Enlarge Person or Sleep, but without suffering arcane spell failure. This makes them a great pair for full divine casters since you get diversified casting without losing armour. In this case, it's important to pick a psychic discipline that matches your divine class's casting stat. Similarly, Psychics are often better matches for armour-wearing martials than full arcane casters are, though the phrenic pool and discipline place greater than usual stat requirements. Such combinations work best when using spells for utility or pre-buffing – and don't overlook swift action spells like Burst of Speed or Thought Shield. Mutation Mind is potentially a useful archetype for a more combat-oriented Psychic gestalt, though as it grants an Enhancement bonus to Strength it doesn't stack with a magic belt and may be better suited to someone who wants melee to be a backup plan. Unsurprisingly Psychics also generally work well with partial casters, as long as stat requirements are complementary. Phrenic Amplifications will work with psychic spells from another class, which gives you a lot of extra flexibility in how you use them, though it does reinforce your spellcasting vulnerability to emotion effects.

Psychic // Ranger

Basics: Full BAB, d10, all saves, 6 skills, full and 4-level casting, physical Int Wis

Fairly well-rounded. Note that without somatic components you don't need a free hand to cast, so TWF if you so desire. MAD enough that you'll probably need to avoid effects with DCs.

Psychic // Rogue

Basics: Med BAB, d8, Ref and Will, 8 skills, full casting, physical Int and Wis or Cha

The rogue doesn't help your Psychic casting, but the Psychic doesn't have enough buffing capacity to push the rogue into martial competence. The sneaky stuff is fun, but you'll do better pairing Psychic with Investigator (for more diverse “casting”) or Slayer (for more martial skill).

Psychic // Skald

Basics: Med BAB, d8, all saves, 4 skills, full and 6-level casting, physical (?) Int Cha

Psychic // Slayer

Basics: Full BAB, d10, all saves, 6 skills, full casting, physical Int and Wis or Cha

Well-rounded gestalt with lots of capacity for sneakiness. Make sure to snag Invisibility and Greater Invisibility. To reduce stat requirements you'll either need to avoid effects with DCs or else let your phrenic pool and discipline abilities suffer. Rebirth is a good  discipline – or self-perfection if you're willing to sacrifice first level powers for better bonus spells.  Note that without somatic components you don't need a free hand to cast, so TWF if you so desire. You'll need to be a bit more careful with your swift actions than most Psychic//martials.

Psychic // Sorcerer

Basics: Poor BAB, d6, Will, 2 skills, two full casting, Int Cha

Durability issues, two spontaneous casting classes without a shared casting stat (but WITH a very similar spell list), limited synergy between other features...

Psychic//Spiritualist

Basics: Med BAB, d8, Fort and Will, 4 skills, full and 6-level casting, Int and Wis or Cha

Relatively versatile spells for a twice-psychic gestalt since the spiritualist is more cleric-like. Remember you can use Phrenic Amplifications on Spiritualist spells. Fractured Mind works well with Cha-based disciplines.

Psychic // Summoner

Basics: Med BAB, d8, Will, 4 skills, full and 6-level casting, Int Cha

Between the poor saves and significant overlap on spell lists, this is a little underwhelming. Consider Hunter//Psychic for more durability and versatility if you're not picky about the nature of your pet, or Sorcerer//Summoner for more stat synergy and a broader spell list. Still not terrible as long as you pick a Cha-based discipline.

Psychic//Swashbuckler (Inspired Blade)

Basics: Full BAB, d10, Ref and Will, 4 skills, full casting, Dex Int Cha

Dex focus and a charisma-based discipline (suggestion: Rapport or Rebirth) keep your stat requirements manageable, especially if you use Inspired Blade to take advantage of the Psychic's intelligence. A little swift-action starved.

Psychic//Warpriest

Basics: Med BAB, d8, Fort and Will, 2 skills, full and 6-level casting, physical Int Wis

Warpriest doesn't blend well with full casters, but if you want a warpriest with typically-arcane spells this is the way to do it since you don't have to give up armour and can use your Wis for phrenic pool. You'll have to use Psychic spells for prebuffing or utility, because the swift-action effects that work well for a Fighter//Psychic compete with all the Warpriest's swift actions.

Psychic//Witch

Basics: Poor BAB, d6, Will, 2 skills+, two full casting, Int and Wis or Cha

Fragile. But, does get both spontaneous and prepared casting based on the same stat, and the use of different components for the different class's spells does make it less likely your casting will be shut down. Avoid the Abomination discipline – while thematic, it prevents you from using witch spells.

Psychic//Wizard

Basics: Poor BAB, d6, Will, 2 skills+, two full casting, Int and Wis or Cha

As above, getting two very divergent types of casting that are still Int-based goes a long way to compensating for the fragility of this combination. Pick class-specific and staple spells with Psychic and then diversify with wizard. Any discipline other than Abomination is fine, though Faith deserves a special mention for granting access to healing and other typically divine spells.

Ranger

Rangers are well-balanced martials, with good combat abilities, lots of skills, and two good saves. They make synergistic and versatile characters when gestalted with full divine casters, and also work well with most partial casters and some psychic classes. Full arcane casters tend to find their focus split more between spells and weapons, but can still use some ranged combat style feats (such as point blank shot and precise shot) with rays, and spells requiring attack rolls do benefit from favoured enemy. Some martial characters also work well with rangers, depending on fighting style and whether the other class needs utility and a good reflex save.

The most useful Combat Styles for most characters are Two-Weapon Fighting, Weapon and Shield, or Archery. Most combat styles have something to offer, but some feat-light styles such as Two-Hand Fighting or Natural Weapons are less useful than taking Archery to switch-hit. Archers can also get extra tricks with Divine Marksman (reliable damage bonus on non-favoured enemies) or for gestalts with a decent Cha Hooded Champion (panache with bows).

If your enemy types are unreliable (and you don't want to rely on Instant Enemy), you can take the Wild Hunter archetype to trade favoured enemy for animal focus, or wild stalker for rage (this also replaces your combat feats and hunter's bond). Similarly, favoured terrain can be replaced with more reliable but minor abilities using Infiltrator or Shapeshifter (though the latter only works for natural weapons builds). Guide replaces your favoured enemy but also relies more heavily on favoured terrain. Alternatively, check out Slayer. If you're worried your animal companion won't keep up with a high-powered gestalt game, try Divine Tracker.

Rangers have a modest need for Wis to cast their spells, but this is usually not a problem. If your point buy is tight, consider a spell-less archetype such as Divine Marksman, Trapper, or Skirmisher. Note Skirmisher does use Wisdom for uses/day, but it may be preferable to not having enough Wis to cast spells.

Ranger // Rogue

Basics: Full BAB, d10, Fort and Ref, 8 skills, 4-level casting, physical Wis

Sneak Attack, strength-based two weapon fighting, full BAB, and an animal flanking buddy. Plus pretty good utility, despite minimal casting.

Ranger // Skald

Basics: Full BAB, d10, all saves, 6 skills, 6- and 4-level casting, physical Cha Wis

Ranger // Slayer

Basics: Full BAB, d10, Fort and Ref, 6 skills, 4-level casting, physical Wis Int

Overlap in skills and talents (including combat style access) makes this one less than exciting, though your main combat bonuses are compatible. Try Ranger//Rogue, Ranger//Inquisitor, or Investigator//Slayer.

Ranger // Sorcerer

Basics: Full BAB, d10, all saves, 6 skills, full and 4-level casting, physical Cha Wis

The basics look really good but you suffer from the usual action economy problem for combat casters and you need two positive mental stats on top of whatever you're using for combat – which is probably all of them thanks to going unarmoured.

Ranger // Spiritualist (Ectoplasmatist)

Basics: Full BAB, d10, all saves, 6 skills, 6- and 4-level casting, physical Wis

Ectoplasmatist gives you two free magical reach shortswords for TWF.

Ranger // Summoner

Basics: Full BAB, d10, all saves, 6 skills, 6- and 4-level casting, physical Cha Wis

Saves, utility, and support casting all good. Biggest offensive advantage is archery, or TWF if you get your favoured enemy bonus reliably. OK with other combat styles, but Slayer is better for TWF if you don't get your favoured enemy, Cavalier and Barbarian are better for mounted melee builds, and Paladin and Bloodrager are better for most other builds.

Ranger // Swashbuckler (Flying Blade)

Basics: Full BAB, d10, Fort and Ref, 6 skills, 4-level casting, Dex Cha Wis

The ranger and swashbuckler's melee styles aren't very synergistic, thanks to TWF being incompatible with Precise Strike and with Dex-to-damage generally; deceptive, underhanded, and menacing are basically your only worthwhile melee options. Thrown weapons make better use of the bonus feats. Favoured enemy and utility still make this a decent combination, but consider Fighter or something with more divine casting instead of Ranger.

Ranger // Warpriest

Basics: Full BAB, d10, all saves, 6 skills, 6- and 4-level casting, physical Wis

Lots of bonus feats so you can do some really interesting stuff in combat, and a good assortment of skills and support spells. Rangers don't use many swift actions so the warpriest's buffs aren't hard to use. TWF is a great option thanks to Sacred Weapon damage and the ability to ignore Dex requirements, though other styles are also fine.

Ranger // Witch

Basics: Full BAB, d10, all saves, 6 skills, full and 4-level casting, physical Int Wis

Ranger // Wizard

Basics:  Full BAB, d10, all saves,  6 skills, full and 4-level casting, physical Int Wis

I prefer Slayer//Wizard, though.

Rogue

Animal companions provide a reliable means to flank and thus Sneak Attack. Note the Pack Flanking feat, which allows you to flank with an animal companion that is adjacent or sharing your space (including a mount), thus making it vastly easier to flank. To use it, you will either need a feature that lets you share teamwork feats with your companion, or else a Horsemaster’s Saddle.

Rogue // Skald

Basics: Med BAB, d8, all saves, 8 skills, casting

Rogue // Slayer

Basics: Full BAB, d10, Fort and Ref, 8 skills, no casting, physical Int

You don't get both sneak attacks and there aren't enough good rogue talents to be worth getting them from two halves of the gestalt. Try Rogue//Ranger or Investigator//Slayer.

Rogue // Sorcerer (Ninja)

Basics: Med BAB, d8, Ref and Will, 8 skills, full casting, Dex Cha

Moderate durability and lots of skills, and you can use sneak attack on spells that require an attack roll. Touch spells mean high accuracy, though you're rolling fewer attacks than most rogues. Some bloodlines have great stealth and infiltration abilities. Ninja’s Charisma-based ki pool gives you an additional set of tricks, though unless your GM lets you combine it with the Unchained Rogue you’ll miss Rogue’s Finesse and Debilitating Injury.

Rogue//Spiritualist (Ectoplasmatist)

Basics: Med BAB, d8, all saves, 8 skills, 6-level casting, physical Wis/Cha

Ectoplasmatist gives you two free magical reach swordswords for TWF.

Rogue // Summoner

Basics: Med BAB, d8, Ref and Will, 8 skills, 6-level casting, physical Cha

The best thing about this combination is that the Eidolon makes flanking easy. Your accuracy is still poor, and you are still fragile. Try Slayer//Summoner.

Rogue // Swashbuckler

Basics: Full BAB, d10, Ref, 8 skills, no casting, Dex Cha

I really want to like this because it's so thematic, but having only a strong Ref save is a big weakness in gestalt, you have no casting, and your combat styles aren't even all that synergistic – the rogue wants to use TWF to get as much sneak attack damage in as possible, but Precise Strike doesn't support TWF. Ninja is a little better thanks to Cha-based ki, but really you should look at Archaeologist Bard//Swash or Investigator//Inspired Blade.

Rogue // Warpriest

Basics: Med BAB, d8, all saves, 8 skills, 6-level casting, physical Wis

OK for TWF, but needs more basic combat competence. Try Slayer//Warpriest.

Rogue // Witch

Basics: Med BAB, d8, Ref and Will, 8 skills, full casting, Int (physical?)

Can't hold up in gestalt combat, the rogue doesn't help your casting, and you can get skills elsewhere. Consider Slayer (if you do want to fight), Alchemist, or Investigator instead of Rogue.

Rogue // Wizard

Basics:  Med BAB, d8, Ref and Will, 8 skills, full casting, Int (physical?)

Arcane trickster is a great concept, but this can't hold up in gestalt combat, the rogue doesn't help your casting, and you can get skills elsewhere. Consider Slayer (if you do want to fight), Alchemist, or Investigator instead of Rogue.

Shaman

Shamans, like druids, have a back row caster list. Unlike druids they don't substitute shapeshifting. There's a hex, but the duration is much shorter and the progression is a lot slower. If you want a divine blaster/controller/SoDer they're your class, but if you want a front liner or archer their spell list is lousy and their hexes mostly inapplicable.

Basics: Full BAB, d10, all saves, 6 skills, full casting, physical Wis

Rogue // Shaman

Basics: Med BAB, d8, Ref and Will, 8 skills, full casting, physical and Wis

Skald

Skald // Slayer

Basics: Full BAB, d10, all saves, 6 skills, 6-level casting, physical Cha Int
